PETITION.PRESENTERS: BJELKE-PETERSEN; BOSWELL; GUILFOYLE; JESSOP; LAJOVIC; RAE
PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that:
General Revenue Grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 12 citizens), Boswell (from 17 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from three citizens), Jessop (from 78 citizens), Lajovic ( from 11 citizens) and Peter Rae (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliamentary assembled.
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resources base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Lajovic (from 21 citizens) and Ryan (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jessop (from 47 citizens) and Robertson (from 92 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

In the pursuance of justice and fair play, the government's taxation portion must be removed from the home purchasers time payments and transferred to a small levy or taxation deduction from all wages and income in all aspects, including the home purchasers and not this grossly unfair crippling procedure that exists today.
From the foundations to the last coat of paint, interest and inflation expectations are applied to the family homes with interest rates of unreasonable magnitude to the completed structure.
Truly, this is a national monetary obligation, particularly in as far as the home purchaser is concerned and a major cause of wage demands and the grass roots of inflation.
We therefore humbly pray that your House take urgent action to apply such a percentage levy or taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for 'drug pushers' and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called 'soft drugs' such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:
(1) Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
(2) Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by 'drug pushers' through the proposed one oz. legal possession.
(3) Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

(4) Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and licence import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society .
(5) There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper entitled 'A Maintenance Agency for Australia', the report of the National Maintenance Inquiry, has been tabled by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). This study has been proceeding for some considerable time. The essence of the finding of the inquiry is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that only 40 per cent of Australian maintenance orders are fully complied with.
The report also states:
. . . another 40 per cent of orders are never paid at all.

Of course those words come from the summary by the Attorney-General of the inquiry's findings. It indicates quite clearly that many Australian men are avoiding their responsibilities to their former spouses and their children. Of course, this stems in part from two factors: The easy availability of divorce under the 1975 amendments to the Family Law Act and, secondly, a belief that other taxpayers will assume prime responsibility of the husband and father by the payment of widows' pensions and supporting parents benefits.

I took the opportunity during the family law debate last year to have incorporated in Hansard figures showing the cost to the taxpayer of husbands and spouses who are not accepting their responsibilities. Given the fact that I have only five minutes in which to speak I will not repeat those points. Of course, the payment of widows' pensions and supporting parent benefits in circumstances of need is an important factor and a tolerant and charitable gesture is required in certain circumstances. The widows pension, as a part of the Budget, is entirely misnamed. As I have pointed out before, some years ago a change occurred and a majority of the recipients of the widows pension were separated or divorced women rather than de jure widows.

From time to time we hear statements that those receiving the supporting parents benefit are mostly unmarried mothers or, indeed-there have been some quite fantastic statements-that young women deliberately become pregnant in order to become eligible for this benefit. In fact, only about 10 per cent of these recipients are women who have never lived with the father of the qualifying child. Most are separated women. Women and children have been the great losers in the easy availability of divorce. There is not much dispute about that fact. The failure of large numbers of men to pay maintenance for their former spouses and their children-surely they are not former children; a man might divorce his wife but he certainly does not divorce his children-means that a third group of people are now the losers, that is, the ordinary taxpayers .

If, through the development of the welfare state, we allow the state to assume responsibilities for obligations which are clearly our own, how can we argue that a democratic state is built on foundations of personal responsibility? In the maintenance area we need to balance the obligation of the state to assist separated women and children, if they require assistance, to maintain an adequate standard of living and a determination that former spouses-if they are in a position to do so-should not avoid their financial responsibilities for their former spouses and their children. We must accept at face value, with the obvious qualifying statements, the statement in the report that a national maintenance agency could give effect to this principle with substantial savings. It is fair to warn that no one wants to see merely the creation of another bureaucracy designed to provide employment for well paid public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled 'A Maintenance Agency for Australia' of the National Maintenance Inquiry, which I have not had time to read completely because it is an extremely large one, was compiled by the Family Law Branch of the Attorney-General's Department under, I understand, the instructions of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I believe it was one of the 49 matters that he forwarded to his Department to look into. It is, I think, a tribute to that Branch of the Department. It is one of the most comprehensive and best analyses of maintenance needs and the systems available to support those needs that I have ever had a look at. In fact, it runs very close to being as definitive a report on the history and sociology of maintenance systems as it is possible to get. It looks in detail at the legal, financial and operational anomalies, problems and benefits inherent in a wide range of schemes which apply not only in Australia but also overseas, specifically the New Zealand model. It covers the problems associated with defaulters, mostly male, and the severely disadvantaged recipients, mostly female, within the existing systems and then looks at models and methods for avoiding, or at least mitigating, those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question in my mind or in most people's minds that there is a need for change to maintenance payment collection and enforcement in Australia, and indeed that that change is long overdue. As the report points out, there has been an undue and costly history of evasion of payment, reliance on the social welfare system to either top up maintenance payments or to be used as an excuse for not paying maintenance at all or for cheerfully evading it. In fact, anecdotal evidence indicates that some of the fairly wealthy members of society are able to do this quite easily simply by leaving their wives and children with houses and cars and paying the children's school fees. The wives are then able to go to the Department of Social Security for their support. Furthermore, the report makes a statement that many of us have long suspected to be the case, that is, that maintenance payment decisions have usually paid more attention to the respondent's needs than to the needs of the wife and children. Clearly this is quite unsatisfactory.

As Senator Harradine pointed out quite rightly, society expects people to accept their responsibilities in caring and providing for their children. The state's responsibility is to see that this is done. Only if it is not possible for this to be done by the defaulting spouse should the state step in and fill the breach. However, Senator Harradine spoke a moment ago as if men had never evaded their responsibilities to their dependent wives and children prior to the new divorce provisions. As the report points out quite clearly, that is not the case. Men have indulged in that exercise for many years. The report specifically looks at the goldfields situation--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great Australian tradition.

—It has not just been the great Australian tradition. I think it has been a great universal male tradition to skip off and either leave the wife and children to fend as best they can or to leave it to the state to pick up the tab. The Government, therefore, is to be commended for looking seriously at this problem. From conversations I had with the previous Minister for Social Security , I understand that the previous Government was also concerned about the problem . I understand that, like me, Senator Chaney was looking seriously at the New Zealand model at least, although I do not know how much further the previous Government went.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, this Government is to be commended for the action that it has taken and for looking at ways of sheeting home the responsibility for maintenance payments to the person responsible for making them. I understand from a report put out by the Attorney-General that in the first instance the Government will accept the report's recommendations regarding following the South Australian model. I hope that it also takes up the report's recommendations with regard to garnishment and looks further at the use of the taxation system in enforcing and tracing payments of maintenance by the respondent to his or her dependants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the report of the National Maintenance Inquiry, entitled 'A Maintenance Agency for Australia' is extremely good and very comprehensive. I make only a couple of comments in relation to two areas. One concerns the recommendations in relation to taxation and the use of the Australian Taxation Office. The other concerns the recommendations in relation to the Department of Social Security. It seems to me that the arguments against the use of the Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security advanced in this report are not well founded. Indeed, I believe that propositions put up in part of this report are merely straw men to be knocked down. I think that it requires us yet again to look with a little more detail at the notion of creating yet another agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The report suggests that the Taxation Office is not the most appropriate department for tracking people in this country. It seems to me that if one compares the Taxation Office with any other agency that may be established, the other agency must fall far short of the capacity of the Taxation Office to keep track of people in this country. If one is concerned with trying to get as many people as possible to meet their obligations, the Taxation Office must be seen as the office best able to do that. I believe the use of the Taxation Office to collect moneys due and the use of the Social Security Department to pay them out , and the dissociation of those two roles, will eventually lead in this country to socially desirable ends. The most important one concerns the unacceptable situation at the moment of women who have custody of children and who seek to enforce payment from their husbands through their own initiative or through the courts. As is pointed out in this report, that type of pressure on individuals puts them at a grave social disadvantage. I am thinking particularly of those people who do not readily understand the operations of the courts and the various systems in this country. I hope that the Government in its review of this report will look again at the reasons it gives for dismissing the recommendation on page 321:
. . . that no steps be taken to impose upon the Australian Taxation Office a requirement to enforce as a taxation debt a sum of arrears of maintenance.

I do not believe its reasons hold up or are good reasons. Before we look at changing the system, and particularly before we establish yet another agency and another bureaucracy, we should look at the bureaucracies already in place, which have enormous expertise, which have enormous reach into the community and which have the capacity to assume these additional responsibilities with very little change to their structures. For example, the Social Security Department is well able to take upon itself the payment of further benefits to people with very little movement within that Department. The Taxation Office is quite capable of assuming responsibility for the collection of new debts in the community, as it does every year through changes in the law. At the moment I am unconvinced that a new organisation is necessary. Indeed, I am still convinced that it would be superfluous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to deal with these five reports together. They are reports on polyvinyl chloride homopolymer (anti-dumping); passenger and light commercial vehicles-substitution; lawn mowers, certain engines and parts; copper and certain copper products; and fatty acids and certain aliphatic acids, their salts and esters, and so on. I wish to comment more in relation to general policy than specifically about these reports, because I think they represent something that is becoming a matter of some concern. For instance, last year the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) indicated, in answer to quite a number of questions, that he did not know what the particular situation was with regard to one industry or another. One can imagine that as a relatively new Minister, that was a problem. However, when one has an Industries Assistance Commission report in relation to, say, copper and copper products that was given to the Government on 28 February 1983 and a decision is not announced until 26 January 1984, then I think it has gone beyond the reasonable learning stage for a Minister and has reached the stage where perhaps matters are dragging on unduly and are not receiving the expeditious care which they should.

SPEECH.PARA: The motor vehicle industry is another one in which there has been serious concern and a very real urgency for some decision making. The industry had a policy announced in December 1981 which was to apply throughout the 1980s. That policy has been the basis for a large number of investment plans which have been made and, as honourable senators would be well aware, in this industry not only the assemblers but also the parts manufacturers are concerned in very expensive tooling investment should they decide to continue or if they are to be able to continue. A great deal of uncertainity has been shown as a result of certain things such as the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) while in Japan on the restructuring of the automobile industry and then the reinterpretation of those comments at various stages as the reaction in Australia grew stronger.

We have had the IAC report on substitution, the car industry council report on the question of intervention and the extent to which there will be intervention, and it is no wonder, I believe, that there is very considerable uncertainty and instability in the motor vehicle industry. This has been created as a result of there appearing to be a number of people making policy statements on behalf of this Government and no clear enunciation of what is the policy, whether the policy introduced by the former Government will continue, whether reviews being undertaken by the present Government will lead to changes, and whether matters such as export credits and facilitation will be changed or not. These are all causing a growing feeling within the community reflected by the variations in the attitudes between the Government's acceptance of some IAC reports and non- acceptance of others, with the differing statements between varying Ministers and the differences between the free traders and the protectionists, between those who have the sort of view that was expounded by the Prime Minister during his recent overseas trip, in particular, but also in his general statements on matters such as steel. On that matter, apparently, without references to the Ministers concerned and with only the briefest reference to the major industry concerned, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, he entered into lengthy discussion which led to great announcements as though some great discovery had been made. It just so happens that BHP has been exporting steel to China for many years. These are but examples of the problems in the industry which, I believe, it is becoming increasingly urgent for this Government to overcome to clear up some of the uncertainty.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industries Assistance Commission report on the dairy industry received universal comment. Nobody liked it. At best, it was inadequate and terribly disappointing. The approach taken by the Commission in this instance is very puzzling. It failed totally to take into account the realities of both the sociological and the economic aspects of the dairy industry and it failed properly to consider what the results of its recommendations would be. I am well satisfied that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) fully understands the position of the dairy industry. I think he was looking to the IAC to come up with something which the industry, at all levels, could understand and accept and which would be implementable, which these recommendations clearly are not.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty that we face is that the dairy industry in Australia is three separate industries interlocking-the ordinary household fresh milk supply industry, the milk supply for domestic manufacture industry and the export industry, all of which are quite different and operate in different places for different reasons with different degrees of success. We are looking, on the one hand, at how we can provide an adequate quantity of milk at the most economic price and, on the other hand, at how we can maintain sufficient returns to the industry to ensure that that will happen. These two items compete with each other. The IAC says that the present system cannot justify the cost of domestic milk. But, as in so many cases, there is not sufficient recognition of why the price of milk is what it is today. It is primarily to ensure adequate supplies of milk Australia-wide during the worst part of the year. Regrettably, at present this provides a surplus for quite a lot of the year. This surplus goes onto the export market. The prices on the export market at present are diabolical and are likely to worsen considerably.

The industry, at all levels, has given this matter quite a deal of consideration. I regret that it started moving late and has moved fairly slowly and that it has been unable to get unanimous approval for the likely recommendations. The industry has to work to reduce the surplus. It comes back to the same problem that we have had for the last seven or eight years. The industry must reduce the surplus by whatever means possible. The proposition that has now been put forward by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation-that as from 1 July 1984 a 1c a litre levy should be imposed on all milk to support the export surplus-is attacking the problem from slightly the wrong end. That will only work provided at the same time we work to reduce the total amount of milk produced. I believe the only way we will be able to achieve that is by implementing an entitlement scheme such as has been mentioned. I have been suggesting to dairy farmers that they should also consider reducing their inputs into the production of milk with a view to improving their net profit. By not spending so much on production they would reduce the amount of milk produced. I hope that the industry will be able to lead the Government and show the IAC what an imperfect report this is. I hope that we will be able to maintain a reasonably proportioned Australia-wide dairy industry in the years to come.
Debate (on motion by Senator Scott) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December 1983, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important survey. In the early post-war years something like 16,000 Australians took part in tests in Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello areas. Many British servicemen and civilians were also there. Amongst the Australians there were also civilians. The tests were done at a time when not as much was known as is now known about the effects of radiation on people's health. The tests were done under what were then regarded as strict precautions. It was important to be able to look at this situation to determine whether there were any effects upon the Australian people .

SPEECH.PARA: The Government of the day determined that the most intensive survey should be carried out. Indeed, I, as the responsible Minister insisted that it should be done under objective and expert advice so that there could be a health study of as many human beings as could be contacted and a survey of the cause of death of those who had died. The task of locating 16,000 people or their relatives was immense. The task of searching records in the Department of Defence was major. These tasks were undertaken. Some 10,000 or 11,000 people who were alive responded and were invited to fill in questionnaires. Something like 1,500 death certificates were examined. This was done by the Department of Health and the then Department of National Development and Energy. A thorough survey was conducted. Most importantly, every person was led to understand that, if he or she had any worries at all about his or her health, an application could be made to the Department. People could be medically examined and, if they felt that they qualified for compensation, they could approach the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Tribunal. The whole approach was one of humanity, trying to find the truth, trying to offer all those people medical examination and compensation services if they had any such claims.

A report from the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council which, is listed for debate, has given us information. Taken together the two documents are of very considerable importance. In effect, the final report on the Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello areas, indicates that there was no evidence to believe that there had been a pattern of either morbidity or mortality from radiation. At the same time people could apply for compensation.

I commend all those who took part in this survey. I commend the departmental officers in both the Department of Health and the former Department of National Development and Energy. I repeat: Every person who feels that he or she has suffered any disability from those tests has a right to medical examination and a right to approach the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Tribunal. The important thing for Australian people to understand is that the government of the day wanted, and I am sure this Government would want, the most open and searching inquiry and the greatest possible help for those people. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks, principally to take up the point that he raises in referring to the report in terms of the extensive problem of trying to follow up the survey of so many people so long after the event. I think it is very necessary that the survey was done, particularly in that case. It is very pleasing that it was done extensively and thoroughly, but the whole problem is really addressing the stable door after the horse has bolted if I can manoeuvre an analogy in such a manner. The problem and cost of that inquiry and the extent of the problems of following it up, contacting people and even perhaps, within the very nature of the inquiry, raising fear in people who may not have even had it before lead me to make those remarks as a preamble to saying such considerations, I think, are far better dealt with at the time of those people being involved in the work rather than in an inquiry long after the event.

SPEECH.PARA: It may well be that we were not aware as much then as we are now of matters of occupational health and safety. This Government in particular has a very strong commitment to such matters. Future workers in an industry, for example working with radiation the way these people were, will consider those necessary statistics and data at the time of people being involved in their work as a preamble to a necessary series of follow-ups. This will happen more easily because names, addresses and basic data will have already been recorded as part of a person's working life and rights while they are working. Even so, I suspect people had a fair idea of the complications of work in that environment way back then. Occupational health and safety are not new issues, they have been known certainly for all of this century. Quite a few people talked about the hazards of work in the nineteenth century. It is really just that little was done about them. It is still a problem of forcing those people who have to take the health of workers into consideration to accept an economic responsibility of that kind of investigation, data collection or care of workers.

It would be interesting to compare the costs of this review and follow-up against what it might have cost to have established those basic requirements for data collection at the time those people were employed. I suspect it might have been much more economic to have established the baseline data at the time those people were working. Hypothetically, had anybody been found to have had a cancer , a death or illness due to radiation-it seems from the report that was not the case-that cost too would have to have been added to the equation. I think prevention is always better than cure, particularly if one can do that in economic terms. On the other hand, who will ever put a price on a human life? Sometimes we may even have to expend money at no economic gain so as to make the health and work state of our workers less likely to cause illness, death or disease.

The very significant part played by this Government in occupational health and safety considerations were very nicely alluded to in a paper which the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) tabled in this Parliament last year. It referred to the importance of health and safety being predicated on the principles that work environments need to be adapted and designed to suit the needs of people. In the case of work places where radiation is a problem, while we cannot exactly adapt the work place, what we must do is adapt the safety requirements so that radiation levels are kept sufficiently low as to guarantee no health hazards from that radiation to the workers. From time to time as research proceeds safe radiation levels need to be further modified and adapted. If the environment can be modified by reducing radiation levels or making sure workers do not get an excessive amount of radiation; yes, I would support those claims by the Minister that we must ensure occupational health and safety measures are introduced at the time of a person working rather than having an inquiry some 16, 20 or 30 years later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the report 'Atomic Test Personnel' I wish to comment on a matter which is quite extraneous to the direct subject matter; that is, the method of conducting inquiries when the people who are to be subjected to an inquiry have been previously bound by the Official Secrets Act, the Crimes Act or other restrictions upon their rights or capacity to provide information in relation to what they did. In this instance there was a lot of confusion because people had been employed by any one of several departments and were subjected to very severe security restrictions. They were then requested by another department to provide information, much of which could have been in breach of the obligations which they had assumed and could have left them, they feared, subject to being charged, if they had answered in a way which was regarded as a breach of their statutory obligations. Obviously, it was a matter that could be cleared up in a number of instances of which I am aware it was cleared up after some correspondence had been entered into. Perhaps the lesson to be learned is that in future if such an inquiry is held, an assurance should be given at an early stage that there is a total exemption from the obligations which might otherwise apply. I simply raise the matter so that a lesson can be learnt from this inquiry and I hope that people are not concerned in such a way by some future inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December 1983, on motion by Senator Haines:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report before us today is more remarkable for its blandness and for ignoring the real problems and issues relevant to the Australian Wine Research Institute during 1983 than for anything that it actually contains. For example, on page 4 of the report, under the headline 'Staff Activities', it refers to the fact that the Director gave a talk on the Institute to the Barons of the Barossa on 24 June 1983. But the report totally ignores the fact that the first strike in the Institute's history took place in 1983 because of actions and activities undertaken by the same Director. A little further on in the report, under the heading WETICE Scheme it mentions that the Institute has been able to utilise the services of two young people under the Federal Government's work experience training in Commonwealth establishments scheme, but ignores the fact that there are very severe moral problems amongst the exisiting permanent staff caused by the sacking, with no apparent reason-certainly with no specified reason-of two of the Institute's longest serving scientists, Dr Michael Evans and Mr Gunther Zeimelis. One wonders whether the 1984 report will mention the embarassment suffered by the Senior Principal Research Scientist at AWRI, Dr Somers, when he received early last month a merit award for work done at the Institute which was in fact not done by him, but by the two sacked scientists.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem at the Institute is very serious, and one which I have raised previously in this place, as has Senator Crowley. It is becoming so appalling that I have written to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. I do not have time in the five minutes that is allocated to me in the debate on this report to mention all the problems associated with the Institute. Nor have I time even to read out a precis that I included in my letter to Senator Jones. Suffice it to say that, as a consequence of the problems to which I have alluded, a number of staff at the Institute approached several South Australian senators, including Senator Crowley, myself and, I think Senator Messner, and perhaps Senator Teague, who has indicated to me that he wants to speak on this report, although, he is not here at the moment .

As I have already said, we raised the matter in the Senate. I raised the matter , as perhaps did other honourable senators, on a number of occasions with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). My staff also raised the matter on one occasion with a senior member of the staff of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). Despite the fact that the Federal Department of Primary Industry contributes something like a quarter of a million dollars annually to the Institute's running-although the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation contributes more, and I think that may well be part of the problem- Mr Kerin has opted for a low profile on the issues, indicating in his last letter to me that he was keeping a watching brief on what was happening. The staff member of the Minister for Science and Technology simply refused to take any action at all, including raising it with his Minister, on the ground that the Department has no responsibility for the Institute. This is notwithstanding that Institute's links with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which most definitely falls within the jurisdiction of the DST. I wrote to Senator Jones and said, in conclusion:

It seems to me that the only remaining avenue of the staff, both past and present, of the Institute to take if they want justice to be done, is if the Senate is prepared to look into the matter. You may well ask why the concerns of such a small number of people should warrant such extreme action. I can only say that the issues facing those 15 or so people are important to them; that the unilateral decision made by the Director and/or the Council are questionable from a number of points of view; and that the allegation of deviousness and deceit made against some Council members of an organisation in receipt of a large sum of taxpayers' money demand the closest scrutiny.
I therefore urge you-
that is, Senator Jones-

and your Committee to give the most urgent and serious consideration to taking on an inquiry into the nature of the research undertaken by the Institute both currently and in the past; the reasons for the sudden change in the direction of that research-apparently necessitating dismissals of highly respected scientists ; the arrogant behaviour of some Council members and the new Director; the sudden decision to change the terms and conditions under which the staff work; the involvement, if any, of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in these decisions; and the very serious allegations made by staff re their treatment in the past year and the behaviour of some Council members during the Federal C and A hearing.

I hope it falls within the brief of the Committee and that the Committee sees its way clear to take up the matter. I thank Senator Jones, whom I spoke to before I wrote to him, for giving me a sympathetic hearing and taking the matter seriously enough to suggest that in fact I write to him and the Committee putting that suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Haines has said, I too have had a recurring interest in the dispute at the Australian Wine Research Institute. I also found the report of the Institute remarkable for what was missing from it, but I presume that a report that brings us up to June 1983 can be forgiven for its minimal report or what happened in May, when the first strike occurred. However, as Senator Haines said, it was the first strike ever in the Wine Research Institute's history. The report was able to list visits in May, so perhaps a reference to the strike and some report of what happened subsequently might well have been in the 1983 annual report. Certainly Senator Haines and I have given notice that we will be fascinated to read the 1984 report. I must say that reading--
—If there is one; if it has not dissolved before then.

—I do not think it will dissolve. Before I return to the more significant matters that Senator Haines has alluded to, I mention that I find reading reports fascinating for all sorts of reasons. For example, research into such things as the loss of fermentation aroma of volatiles during white wine making certainly sounds a most fascinating piece of research, as does that into the aroma composition of chardonnay wine. What about the mousey off-flavour in wine? I cannot imagine drinking a wine that has gone off with a flavour of mouse . It mentions a further piece of research into the deposits from corks. Those people who have a significant interest in wine keeping, wine storage and wine drinking would no doubt be terribly interested that all these significant matters are being pursued. I do not wish in any way to be seen as diminishing the research done by the Institute; it is just that the titles of research sound quite fascinating and somewhat delightful to read.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the Australian Wine Research Institute is a national institute for research into this very important Australian industry. Research done there is of world significance. Research teams of staff members travel internationally and overseas visitors often visit the Wine Research Institute just because of the significance and quality of the research that is done there. The wine industry in this country is no small matter. In fact, the Government's commitment to this Wine Research Institute in terms of some quarter of a million dollars annually indicates the Government's involvement and preparedness to support and back such research in this industry. We hear often in this place that there should be further research and development, and support for industries. Here is a research group. It has a long history and a great significance. In the last 12 months it has been most violently disrupted by staff dissatisfaction and the behaviour of its so-called employers or management . Morale is low. The two staff members who were originally sacked, I believe, have had the term for their leaving changed from 'sacking', but that happened long after the event and only after considerable activity. The continuing unrest there--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is a dismissal if it is not a sacking?

—I think it comes with a bigger handshake. The real continuing problem of serious importance here is the attempt by those in charge to change the status of employment of the people at the Research Institute. Maybe that could be validly done, but to attempt to do it without any discussion with the researchers is a matter of very grave significance. We hope to see much more reference to that in the 1984 report.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Haines, I have a continuing interest in this matter. I have certainly taken the matter up with Minister Kerin. He has pointed out that, as the Australian Wine Research Institute is incorporated under the South Australian Companies Act, it really is not a matter that he can readily move in and investigate. It has to be dealt with by discussion and manoeuvrings of that sort rather than by heavy handed interference. But Minister Kerin arranged that a member of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations should be in attendance on behalf of the staff at any meetings between staff and management of the Institute. Certainly the staff have reported that the presence of such persons on their behalf has been very helpful, at least in the early rounds of discussion and talks that are necessary during this protracted period of industrial unrest. The Institute is very important. I hope this industrial dispute will be settled soon so that the good research can continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as a South Australian you will not be surprised that three South Australian senators are speaking on the report of the Australian Wine Research Institute. The Institute is based in South Australia, which is the State with the majority production of Australian wine. The Institute is somewhat destabilised at the moment by the impost that the present Government has placed on fortified wines. It may well be that further efforts need to be taken by the Institute to achieve research results that will help to outweigh the disadvantages being suffered in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that has been raised by Senator Haines and referred to by Senator Crowley is the dispute within some elements of the staff of the Institute which has caused disruption and led to anxiety among those employed there. It is my understanding that the Institute's authorities had the power to terminate the two research positions that have been discussed and that those positions have been terminated and severance payments have been made to and received by those staff. It is always possible in a research institution that long-serving or short-serving staff may no longer be involved in research programs when that research institute takes a new direction in the priorities accorded to research being undertaken. As I understand it, that is the ground on which the Institute has made tough decisions to make sure that it is achieving priorities that it has consciously set out for itself.

In noting that, I comment on Senator Haines's suggestion that there be a Senate inquiry into the differences of view or anxieties amongst the staff that may be associated with the two staff positions being terminated. I would be most reluctant for the Senate to be directly involved in such a dispute in any statutory authority within Australia. There are hundreds of statutory authorities and we would need not just this kind of problem or area of discussion and dispute as a ground for a Senate committee weighing in to such a dispute; we would also need to have established very serious grounds for entertaining such a matter. It would need to be in the context of the very purposes of the statutory authority concerned. I am aware that in Australia disputes are before the courts about proper or improper dismissal of staff members in various areas of employment. A great deal would need to be said, in addition to what has already been maintained, for the Senate to be directly involved in such an inquiry. I understand that the Department of Primary Industry has investigated carefully such allegations, or the room for such complaint, and has found them to be groundless and that the governing authorities of the Institute have acted within their powers. I say frankly to the Senate that we would need to be given much more evidence than has been brought before us if we were to become in any way involved in a properly constituted statutory authority.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December 1983, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australia-China Council Annual Report has come up for debate sooner than I had anticipated. I had hoped to be in a position to advise the Senate of the outcome of discussions that I have had in respect of prisoners of conscience in China about which I had something to say in the Senate on 18 November 1983. It appears that the previous Government placed and this Government places considerable importance on relationships between Australia and China. Indeed, the taxpayers of Australia are pouring considerable funds into the development of this relationship. The Australia- China Council has been established and its annual report is now the subject of debate in the Senate. The previous Government and this Government have given lip service to the question of human rights in China. However, it gives me some concern that that lip service has not been translated into intelligent, honest, respectful and effective approaches to authorities in China to ensure that the very strong viewpoint that is held by the Australian population about human rights violations in China is made known to the authorities in China.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have the time in the short five minutes that is made available to us in this sort of debate to go over the various instances of the violations of human rights of individuals and groups of individuals within China. One example of these I relayed to the Senate on 18 November 1983 because of the visit to Canberra at that time of the President of the Shanghai Friendship Society and other colleagues from Shanghai.

There is a growing concern amongst Australians that in China there are violations of human rights which go to the very fundamental relationships between husband and wife. I am aware that the Chairman of the Australia-China Council, Professor Geoffrey Blainey, raised with the visiting delegation the matter that I referred to on that occasion and the matter to which the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, so courteously and efficiently responded. I am also aware of the fact that Professor Geoffrey Blainey, in an address to the National Press Club on 22 November, alluded to growing attention in Australia to the question of human rights in China and expressed the view that this might affect relations between Australia and China in future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December 1983, on motion by Senator Maguire:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Australian National Railways annual report for 1982-83. The Australian National Railways system now incorporates the former Commonwealth railways network, the old South Australian railways and the Tasmanian railways system. It should be noted that Australian National, or the former Commowealth railways, took over the two State railway systems at a time when both of them were making substantial losses.

SPEECH.PARA: The major feature of the 1982-83 report which affects my State is the development of the standard gauge railway from Crystal Brook to Adelaide. That is now in operation at long last. From January 1983 onwards freight has been carried on that railway from Perth and Sydney to the Islington railyards in the northern suburbs of Adelaide. From the middle of 1983 freight was operated into the Mile End yards very close to the city's centre. The new standard gauge passenger service will soon operate to Adelaide. The new railway station at Keswick should be open by the end of this financial year. In all those aspects Adelaide will at long last be connected to the standard gauge network which now links all mainland capital cities.

I believe that Australian National's operations have been affected by the different railway gauges in Australia which are a blight on our transport. In fact, within the boundaries of South Australia alone Australian National operates three different railway gauges. Surely those gauges quite significantly affect the efficiency of the organisation. Rail standardisation, the gradual whittling away of the other two gauges, has been a major spending boost for the South Australian economy. The investment involved in the development of the Dry Creek, Islington and Mile End freight yards has been significant. The new passenger terminal to which I have referred and the new headquarters building for Australian National all involve significant expenditure in the local economy .

Unfortunately in 1982-83 Australian National's deficit increased. The Commonwealth's contribution to finance Australian National's operations rose from $68m in 1981-82 to $102m in 1982-83. I believe that the increase in the deficit significantly reflects the drought conditions and the effects of the economic recession. The latter was particularly severe in respect of the parts of Australia where Australian National operates.

Essentially, Australian National is a freight railway. Eighty-five per cent of its revenue, I believe, comes from freight, so it must be affected by events such as drought and economic recession. For example, in 1982-83 the tonnage of cereals carried by Australian National fell to 400,000 tonnes, a third of the level applying in the previous year when 1.2 million tonnes were carried. The effect of the recession was felt through the decreased carriage of items such as steel from Whyalla. The unfortunate 1982 result has interrupted Australian National's goal of achieving financial viability in a decade. However, it is believed that in the current financial year there can be a move back to the trend of improved financial results. I think that projection reflects the forecast upturn in the economy and the very evident fact that the drought in Australia has now ended.

Part of Australian National's deficit, I believe, reflects its requirements to meet certain social obligations; that is, it has to meet certain community objectives and not just objectives of a commercial or financial nature. For example, it is required to give service to small rural communities. Sometimes that can be uneconomic. It is required to keep some branch lines open although in some cases they make a loss.

In South Australia, Australian National is a significant employer in towns such as Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Peterborough and Tailem Bend. The prosperity of those towns is linked importantly to the railway network. Unfortunately, the standardisation of the railway system has a cost in local terms; jobs will be lost at Port Pirie and Peterborough in South Australia, particularly as a result of the closure of the bogie exchanges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 December 1983, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian bicentennial road development program was a great initiative of the Fraser Government. I am certainly glad that the present Government has carried it on. I wish I could say the same for its bicentennial water resources program which is certainly most necessary and most important in a country which experiences so much drought. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Government has decided to index the excise tax on petrol. I feel that the Government is ripping off Australia's motorists by not allocating the increased revenue raised through the indexed excise tax on petrol to the bicentennial roads program. This was confirmed in Parliament yesterday by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). He said that the reason the additional revenue was not being put into the program was that the coalition Government's legislation setting it up did not provide for any more than 2c a litre being allocated. The point is that the previous Government did not envisage the increased and indexed excise introduced by the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government really wants to ensure the continuation of the bicentennial roads program to the extent required to cover ever-increasing costs, I feel that it could change the program. I have no doubt, of course, that the Government does not want to allocate the additional revenue to the roads program. It wants to boost its coffers so it can direct the money to other areas such as unemployment benefits and things like that. I think that all honourable senators realise that Queensland has an enormous road network, consisting of something like 41,000 kilometres of main roads alone. We are the most decentralised State in Australia and, as such, rely heavily on internal transportation, particularly on our roads.

Every year we seem to have the dreadful situation whereby our Far North and our western areas are cut off by roads because of the rains which unfortunately wash the roads away. Only a couple of weeks ago Mount Isa was completely cut off by road and rail. It was accessible only by aeroplane. I feel that that is a very sad situation at a time when the Federal Government is supposed to be ploughing funds into our roads through the bicentennial roads program. A country such as Australia needs a sophisticated road network linking all our major cities and towns. I consider that it is very important for the Labor Government to recognise this.

Last year the number of vehicles registered in Queensland was up significantly on the figure for the previous year. I suppose one could say that that is due in part to the large number of people who come to Queensland from other States. In Queensland, of course, we do not mind the fact that they want to get away from the socialist governments down south, but the extra toll on our roads is something else. This six-monthly increase in the price of petrol is a very subtle form of revenue gathering of which the average motorist is probably not aware, in any case. I think it is rather sad that Mr Hawke and his Government have not decided to plough these funds into our roads, particularly in Queensland which I like to remind honourable senators from Victoria, is seven times the size of their State. The Bureau of Transport Economics in one of its reports found that the allocation of funds for road construction and maintenance in Queensland was severely less than it forecast Queensland should receive. I emphasise the need to put all increased and indexed excise tax to road building in every state, rather than to Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to this matter. I support Senator Bjelke-Petersen in congratulating the Fraser Government on the implementation of this program. It is certainly an excellent program. From time to time as one travels around the larger States of this Commonwealth one sees the desperate need, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, for the expenditure of funds on our major road network. I hope that our State governments will decide to allocate some portion of their funds towards some of those roads rather than just relying totally upon Federal governments for them, because quite frankly the state of the main roads in some of our larger States is very poor. I can well understand that. They are such large States with such an extensive road network.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to congratulating the Fraser Government, I congratulate former Liberal governments in Victoria for the state of the roads in Victoria. The major arterial networks in Victoria are really first-class. The problem is that motorists in outback Victorian areas are tending to stay off those magnificent roads. Why is this? In Victoria the Cain Labor Government has introduced a driving offence which relates to motorists driving at 30 kilometres an hour above the speed limit. Any motorists convicted of travelling at a speed in excess of 30 kilometres above the speed limit compulsorily loses his licence for three months. That is fair and reasonable in the city of Melbourne. Anyone who drives down Collins Street at, say, 91 kilometres an hour ought to lose his licence for three months. But the trouble with this Cain Labor Government is that it is not able to see beyond the boundaries of metropolitan Melbourne and its suburbs.

When one drives between my city of Warrnambool and the major rural city of Portland one drives on a large, open, wide and flat road in flat countryside. The concern about losing one's licence if one is caught driving at a fast speed is so great that motorists are getting off the highways and taking to the back roads. I see Senator Button smiling, but of course he now gets driven around the place and does not have to worry about driving round rural Victoria. It is to me a matter of great concern to discover, when I move off to a minor road for my own purpose of travelling faster than the speed limit and in the hope of avoiding the police, that not only am I not the only person on the minor roads but also I am travelling along with 22-wheel semi-trailers loaded with 17 tonnes also travelling at excessive speeds and, of course, doing major damage to the road networks which have to be maintained by local government.

The point is that the State Government, by foolishing applying the same rules to outback, rural Victoria and to drivers on those roads as apply to metropolitan Melbourne, is forcing heavy vehicles off the main road. One might say that the market forces are moving drivers of those heavy vehicles off the major roads on to the minor roads, thereby creating an enormous burden for local government in trying to maintain the rural roads system of Victoria. I suggest that with a little foresight the State Government could have done something proper about this. For example, it could recognise that it is much more reasonable to travel a bit faster on a decent freeway or a decent country highway and not limit people in Victoria to 100 kilometres an hour on a four- lane freeway. Anyone driving along at 100 kilometres an hour will find that he is passed by all the trucks in the area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 December 1983, on motion by Senator Lewis:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators know, we have only five minutes to speak to these papers, and five minutes is certainly not enough time in which to deal with this report which is of such grave concern to all pilots around Australia. However, I understand that my colleague Senator Peter Rae might be taking a procedural step following my speech, which I hope will enable us to further examine this report. I draw the attention of Senator Button, who is at the table, to the fact that on 15 December last year Senator Townley, in this chamber, asked for the production of the transcript of just what was said by and to the pilot of the aircraft which crashed, the subject of this report. I ask Senator Button whether he will ask the appropriate Minister to supply the Senate with the transcript of the conversations which took place between the pilot and the air traffic controllers at the time of this accident. The reason is that it seems to Senator Townley, to me and to other honourable senators to whom I have spoken about this matter, that if this pilot had been spoken to sensibly by ground controllers this accident may have been avoided altogether. I use the word 'sensibly', but perhaps more in the sense of someone knowing what he is talking about. As far as air safety is concerned, this might become a matter of great concern to people in the future. The pilot was supposed to be flying at 12,000 feet on his way from Tasmania to Victoria and at 14.52 hours he said to the controller:

SPEECH.PARA: Er Whiskey Juliet Charlie we seem to have been in trouble with-er-fuel here the red-er-warning light comes on and the gauge is down . . .

Nine minutes later he was in the drink in Bass Strait. Then there was a very extensive story which I mentioned in my last speech on this matter about the attempts to rescue him and his passenger. He had some problem with the fuel warning gauge. It seems to us that someone should have been making suggestions to him. For example, would he check his fuel gauges? Would he check his fuel tanks? Would he check his mixture? Would he check his pitch control? Someone should have taken him through a series of safety precautions. It also could very well have been that he might have been advised to reduce his speed, perhaps also to lower his flaps by 15 to 20 degrees to give him a little more ability to maintain height, and it may be that he could have been redirected closer towards land. It took him nine minutes to go into the drink from that point, which seems to imply that he was probably below 12,000 feet at that time. But perhaps he could have reduced his gliding angle and extended his gliding path until he reached land, until he was able, perhaps, to make a forced landing on a beach. When he went into the water he was about 42 nautical miles from Tidal River. It may be that in some way or other, with some guidance, he could have extended his glide path to reach Tidal River.

Those of us who have flown or been involved in other sporting events will know that from time to time panic grips us. The opportunity here was for someone calmly sitting on the ground to talk rational sense-this is why I used the word 'sensibly'-to talk sensible common sense to that pilot. Had that occurred, it may be that this accident could have ben avoided. So for those reasons I, Senator Townley and others would like to see a transcript in regard to what took place between the radio controller and this pilot. We would like the Government and safety officers to start thinking about training radio controllers to have this sort of conversation with pilots who appear to be panicking or in some sort of trouble. I must finish my remarks because time has run out. I hope that Senator Rae will seek leave to continue, so that the debate is not wound up today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, five minutes is not long enough for a subject of the complexity of this to be dealt with. It is my intention to indicate today that I shall tomorrow give notice of motion for a substantive motion to be able to debate this matter fully. I wish to quote from the editorial of the air pilots magazine, the 1983 Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association magazine. It will give honourable senators some idea of the concern which is being expressed in relation to this incident. The second last paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: How long must we continue to tolerate the inefficiencies of the Department of Aviation Search and Rescue Service? How many lives are being needlessly lost through their ineptitude?

Those are fairly strong words to be put in an editorial of a very responsible journal. They indicate the sort of concern. I have been given a brief in relation to this matter by people who were involved. One point which arises from the report is that not only were helicopters which were available to be used not used but also there were numerous fishing boats in the area and, through inadequacies of procedure and communication, apparently no attempt was made to bring those fishing boats into the operation. I understand that one boat was less than three hours steaming time away from where the man had been sighted. If some flares had been able to be dropped in the area where the person had been sighted it may well have been that a fishing boat despatched immediately could have got to the area and found him. I have been told, although this has not been verified to me, that there was one boat very much closer still, which was not brought into the search and attempted rescue.

I just point out those matters and refer also to what Senator Lewis and other honourable senators have said, including you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Tremendous concern has been expressed by a whole cross-section of those concerned with aircraft safety, from pilots right through to passengers, and all others involved. I propose not to seek to continue my remarks in this process but rather to give notice of motion for a substantive motion so that the whole matter can be debated in more detail. I believe it is one that requires that sort of debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
