Debate resumed from 13 December 1983, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in respect of the report of the Department of Aviation for the 1982-83 financial year to make some further comment about the general level of air safety in this country. It is a matter to be greatly prized by Australia that we have a very high level of air safety at all levels, whether that applies to commercial aviation or to general aviation and to the use of such equipment as helicopters and what have you. Clearly, a very high degree of attention has been paid to that by successive governments. The report, on page 27, points out the activities of the flying unit in respect of maintaining that very high level of support and standards at airports in Australia so as to make sure that navigational aids and various equipment used for the guidance of aircraft in this country are maintained at the highest possible standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one concern about the reference in the report to the flying unit which, as honourable senators know, provides aircraft to travel around Australia and check the operation of navigational aids at airports, and the calibration of that equipment, to ensure that it is operating properly. These aircraft are properly fitted out with suitable equipment in order to do that. I am a little concerned to know-and perhaps the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) will be able to ascertain the answer from the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley)-whether any economy measures have been introduced in the Department of Aviation which have reduced the operation of the aircraft that undertake this kind of work. I have some information, which disturbs me, as to cutbacks in this area, and I wonder whether that is correct information. At some stage I would like to have the Minister's assurance that there is no likelihood that air safety may be affected adversely by those kinds of economy measures undertaken by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will seek that information for the honourable senator and see that he is provided with it as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to speak on the annual report of the Department of Aviation for 1982-83. The report documents a very large fall in domestic passenger traffic during that financial year-a figure of 9.3 per cent, which is a large fall by any standards and a very unusual event in civil aviation in Australia in the post-war period. It is very unusual to see such a large decline in passenger numbers. Not only is the recession responsible for the fall in air traffic but also the high and increasing fares charged for domestic travel in Australia, to such a point that many Australians can no longer afford air travel.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very pleased to note that during the financial year 1982-83 capital injections were made for both Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd. For most of the period of the former Liberal Government these organisations were starved of capital. Only belated moves were made at the end of the life of that Government to provide further capital for those two important public enterprises in Australia. I am pleased to note that the present Government approved a $90m capital injection for TAA and an extra $60m for Qantas. I am sure that both of those amounts will enable the airlines to keep down the debt servicing costs they are facing at the moment-the high interest bills-at a time of a depressed market.

I am pleased also to note that the sale of TAA which had previously been called for by certain individuals, is no longer to occur. The report of the Department of Aviation confirms government policy on that matter. The report confirms the continuing move away from the use of identical equipment by the two domestic airlines. Over the last 20 or 30 years all of us have noted that both airlines have had identical numbers of aircraft of the same types. The move began with TAA purchasing the Airbus aircraft and during 1982-83, the period to which this report relates, Ansett Airlines of Australia received its first wide-bodied jets -Boeing 767s. So the two major airlines now have significantly different aircraft. At the end of the financial year TAA have five Airbus aircraft operating and Ansett was operating three Boeing 767s.

During 1982-83 the Adelaide International Airport became a reality. This is something that residents of South Australia had been calling for for many years. After so many years of having to travel in the opposite direction when making overseas trips at great inconvenience and with great loss of time, Adelaide residents can now travel overseas direct. I think South Australia was definitely neglected by previous Commonwealth governments in the area of air travel. It is interesting to note that Adelaide was not only the last mainland capital city to get direct international air services but also, as I pointed out in my previous speech this morning, the last mainland capital city to be connected to the standard gauge railway network. I think we have really been sold short in this area of transport policy.

In response to a question on notice from me during 1983 it was revealed that in the first four months of operation of Adelaide International Airport some 28,400 passengers passed through the terminal. In the first nine months of 1982-nine months compared with four months-Townsville carried only 23,000 passengers and Darwin 28,000. I simply note that both of those centres had an international airport before Adelaide did but that the number of passengers passing through Adelaide is vastly in excess of the combined numbers passing through Townsville and Darwin. The report also refers to work being completed at Adelaide Airport for the introduction of domestic wide-bodied jets. Unfortunately, although the very expensive social investment in improved taxiways and aprons has occurred, the two major airlines still have no scheduled domestic wide-bodied jet services to Adelaide.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council is parallel to the paper discussed earlier today relating to atomic test personnel. The Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council is a very distinguished body charged with very important work. The Council had put out a report on its investigations over a number of years into the possible radiation effects upon those who had been in the area of atomic tests at Maralinga, Emu, Monte Bello and other adjacent areas. It had concluded from its examinations that there was no evidence of specific effects of radiation. This was a valuable adjunct to the test to which I referred earlier when speaking to the paper on atomic test personnel which examines the history, their records and dosimeter readings, which measure radiation levels, of some 16,000 Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish specifically to pay tribute to a man, recently deceased, who was Chairman of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council from 1973. I refer to the late Professor R. J. Walsh. Professor Walsh contributed more than most Australians to public life in this country in very many fashions. He was not only the Chairman of the Council but also he chaired and led many investigations in his time. At the University of New South Wales, he was the first Professor of Human Genetics in Australia. He was the guiding light, the mainspring, in establishing the blood bank in Australia and was an authority on that very special matter. He was a very distinguished senior member of the Australian Academy of Science. He was Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of New South Wales. Indeed, the list of his accomplishments is so long that it would take more than the time I have left to refer to it. He was chairman of the inquiry into the crown of thorns starfish on the Great Barrier Reef. He was a very influential member of the Australian Population and Immigration Council and an authority on Papua New Guinea and many other matters. When a person has made these kinds of quite outstanding contributions over such a range of matters I think it is only fitting that, when part of that person's work comes before this Senate, we should pay him tribute. We have been very fortunate in Australia in having men of particular greatness who have contributed unceasingly to the work and value of this community. I pay tribute to Professor Walsh and to his family.

I also pay tribute to the Council for its work. In this whole sphere of ionising radiation, that is, the carcinogenic effects on human organs and tissues, there has been a growing body of knowledge over recent decades. It is very important that we have bodies of this kind contributing to our knowledge. It is very important that people of such distinction add to our storehouse of knowledge. Therefore, in paying tribute to the late Professor Walsh, I also pay tribute to the Council. I think those who knew Professor Walsh would join me in that tribute.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Debate resumed from 23 August 1983, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most honourable senators have some background knowledge of this matter. A paper was put down by the Government at the time the original Budget measures were announced on Budget night. That paper outlined at that time the way in which the new assets test would operate as it was then conceived by the Government. Since then we have had various other changes to the modus operandi of the assets test to a point where really that paper is outdated and does not truly reflect the present position of the Government. The Government has announced that it will refer the whole matter of an assets test to a panel of community based organisations in order to get some better understanding of what it intends. I can only applaud that move at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The original statement has been followed by a confusing number of other statements, not made to the Parliament but made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in various other places extending exemptions in some cases-I refer to the lifestyle package-and in others, making more clear perhaps, from the point of view of the Government, what it originally intended. I refer to various matters such as the effects on renters, which was the subject of a later statement, the effect on farmers, small businessmen and so on.

The point I really wanted to make was that the statement was very incomplete in terms of its consideration by the Government. It lacked the detail which was necessary to inform people properly as to their obligations and what would be intended by the Government when it finally introduced the system on 1 November. I think that can point only to the Government's incompetence in this area. It certainly points up the confusion that has developed in the Australian community ever since the announcement was made in the Budget. It does the Government no credit at all to blame the Opposition for going about and talking to people in the community, and, as it has claimed, stirring up the community against the assets test. Judging from the way in which letters have been flowing into my office-I am certain that it is happening to other honourable senators as well- there is absolutely no doubt about the level of confusion in the community at present. For that reason I seek leave to continue my remarks later as I believe the matter should remain on the Notice Paper for later debate.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that we are debating today a ministerial statement that was brought down on 23 August and we are still looking at it some six months later I think speaks volumes for the problems we are facing in this chamber with regard to papers and statements generally. It is quite extraordinary that we should now be faced with looking at a statement which is no longer really relevant, as Senator Messner has pointed out. He mentioned, in the few words he had to say, the immense amount of confusion that has been evident in the community with regard to the Government's proposed assets and income test legislation. If his office has been getting the volume of mail that mine has, he certainly did not have the normal rest period to which parliamentarians can look forward in January. Despite the fact that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) put out an extremely comprehensive document late last year, for which I would like to thank him, which answered a lot of questions that have been raised, it was simply not possible to make everybody aware of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The major anomalies in the legislation that were behind the Australian Democrats belief last year that the legislation had to be held over at least until this session were, mainly, the 10 per cent notional assessment that was to be applied to all non-exempt assets. This meant that any pensioner who had money in the bank or who had investments paying less than 10 per cent income per year was going to have that asset assessed as if indeed it was paying 10 per cent. That applied not only to the people who were, quite clearly, trying to avoid their responsibilities by putting money in non-interest bearing accounts, but also to those people who had amassed, in total, amongst all of them, something like $31 billion in Australian savings banks and financial institutions paying less than 6 per cent. A large number of those people would be pensioners who wanted ready access to their money. They were not necessarily large amounts they had in those accounts but these amounts were still going to be assessed at 10 per cent. The same applied to people who had shares in Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd which may well have been left to them by a parent or by a deceased spouse. Since I am one of those people who has assets in BHP I can assure honourable senators that the yield the company was paying annually is nowhere near 10 per cent, it is not even a third of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about capital gains?

—Well, capital gain is not something that is affecting these people at the moment. I daresay the honourable senator has something up his sleeve which will catch people with capital gains in due course. I do not want to debate that matter at the moment. The other problem that was concerning people was the application of the $30,000 leisure package which included hard assets only; that is, the people who had been in a reasonable income bracket all their lives and who had been able to acquire a holiday home, or a caravan, or a high power speed boat, or whatever, were able to have the value of these assets taken into account as non-exempt. The people who preferred to save their money for an annual holiday on the Gold Coast, Tasmania, the Barossa Valley, Perth or whatever had those savings taken into account and assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, as far as we were concerned the Government's proposal did nothing to prevent money going to the wealthy or to precipitate, in any way, its going to the needy. Indeed, I will stand by the notice of motion that I have had on the Notice Paper for something around 18 months. It calls for the incorporation or introduction of a national portable contributory superannuation scheme. I understand there was a comment from an honourable senator in this place yesterday who claimed that this was going to require an impost of another 5 per cent on people's taxation. I point out that at the moment the percentage of personal income tax which is paid out in age pensions equals 28 per cent. That amount alone should indicate to some people that a pension ought to be a right or that if we do introduce a national, portable contributory superannuation scheme it should not need anything like the imposition of a 5 per cent tax levy. It has pleased a lot of us that the Government has delayed, by its own action, the imposition of what was an anomalous and iniquitous piece of legislation. However, I would have much preferred the Government to withdraw the Bill altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six months ago both in the Budget and by ministerial statement the Hawke Labor Government indicated that it proposed to introduce a property test on aged pensions, the property test having been abolished in 1976. In the subsequent six months enormous confusion and insecurities have been expressed throughout the whole community, particularly amongst those who are aged and who are dependent upon the pension. These people have structured their assets and living standards as they understood the Hawke Government had given a firm promise that nothing would happen. Despite the fact that week by week and month by month the subject was raised in a major way, the Government stuck to its grounds that it would go ahead with the assets test. Despite the fact that week by week the ludicrous circumstances of the assets test were revealed, the Government went on until, a week ago, a surprise statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-a statement unknown to his Cabinet, unknown to his Ministers-was made at the National Press Club.
—Oh, that is not true.
—Indeed, I thought I heard Senator Button say yesterday that he had not known--
—Yes, you did. That is right.
—Well then let me say again this was unknown to his Cabinet.
—Unknown to his Ministers, you said.

—It was unknown to his Cabinet and Senator Button is a senior member of Cabinet; it was unknown to his Ministers because Senator Button is a senior Minister. Unknown to them he went to the Press Club and said that the assets test, as proposed and as developed by his Minister, was a mistake. He did not say the nature of the mistake. He said that it was a mistake. He said this without being able to offer an alternative, without being able to say: ' Look, it is a mistake. What we will do is A, B and C'. He ultimately devised some means to get out of this dilemma by saying: 'We will get another investigation'.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been in office for a year. Despite its promise that it would not fiddle with the social service age pension and despite the fact that for the last six months the Australian community has been in turmoil on this matter, the Government is at a point now where it has admitted that the assets test was a mistake and yet it has no way of coming forward and saying: 'But the correct policy is A, B and C'. On the contrary, it is now trying to hide behind a panel, to move the decision making to others. This is an utterly ludicrous situation. The Government is saying 'Yes, there will be an assets test', and so again the confusion arises. What will it be? Will we be able to have our caravans and our holiday homes? Will we be able to put the jewellery and art collections under the floor? All this nonsense has gone on week by week and extremely ludicrous paradoxes have emerged in this situation. Despite all these things the only thing the Government can say is: 'It is not we, the Government who are to blame, it is the wicked Opposition and the community outside which are confusing the pensioners. We are not to blame'. The Prime Minister said: 'It is a mistake'. When he was asked whether it was being done because of Senate opposition, he said: 'No, it is because we realise that it is intrinsically, inherently a mistake'. Do not let anyone, including the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) say that what is happening now is because of some alleged distortions by us. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I seek leave to make a brief statement on the subject.
—I will deal with the first point. Is leave granted for Senator Sir John Carrick to continue his remarks?
—Will the honourable senator move the resumption of the debate?
—I am not terribly clear on this matter. I would not stand in the way of the Minister making a statement.
—What you are trying to do is cut the debate off.
—Let me make it perfectly clear because the Minister, as usual, is trying to distort this matter. I said I would not stand in the way of the Minister making a statement.
—Thank you. Why didn't you seek leave?
—I was querying with the Deputy President whether he would want me to move the resumption of the debate. Having had that offensive remark, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Despite the tone of Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks, I happen to believe that this is a very serious and very important subject. It cannot be dealt with in a series of five minute speeches such as this. The simple fact of the matter is that we have an aging population. We have a large expenditure on retirement incomes in this country. Over the years we have had a very distorted picture. Distortions were created in the system through the taxation benefits which were available to those who were able to take lump sums and therefore get a considerable advantage over those who had weekly superannuation payments or weekly small income payments and over those who were on the base rate pension. Those people who have been fortunate enough to have assets from which they can gain an income but who, under the strange definitions that exist in our system, have had that income termed as 'capital gains' have had an extraordinary advantage-and still have an extraordinary advantage-over those who are on base rate pensions or those who receive small weekly payments. So, by everybody's admission, there is a distortion of the system, a distortion which the previous Government did nothing about and a distortion which it aggravated in 1976 when it made changes to the system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear and plain that the vast majority of people in the community agree with a needs based system of the type we are trying to introduce. I merely reflect, with regard to Senator Sir John Carrick's remarks, it is very strange that the turmoil and problems that he saw in the community were not reflected in the recent by-elections. The Australian Labor Party gained a swing of 1.8 per cent in Richmond-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, go on. Tell us about Hughes.
—It remained the same in Corangamite-
—Tell us about Corangamite.
—I am telling the honourable senator that it remained about the same in Corangamite and in Hughes the swing against the Government was less than the average swing in by-elections in this country.
—Tell us why your Prime Minister dropped this proposal.

—I suggest to Senator Sir John Carrick that we should not debate this serious subject on that basis. We should look at what needs to be done-and no one denies that something needs to be done. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that we remained firmly committed to the principle of an assets test, the principle of ensuring that we have a needs based retirement benefit system, excluding assets, only including income. Senator MacGibbon, who is trying to interject is, above all, the person in this place who defends privilege and those who have extremely high incomes. I will not bother to talk about his remarks. Of course, there has been considerable controversy and uncertainty. I have said that in this place before and the Prime Minister has said it. We would have preferred to have passed the legislation so that we could demonstrate to people that about 85 per cent of pensioners in the country would not be affected . But it was quite clear from statements by all of the Opposition parties that the legislation would not have been passed. So what we are doing-
—That is not what your Prime Minister said. He said it was a mistake.

—Senator Walters, of all people, should never act in this chamber as a defender of the underprivileged, the poor or low income earners. Her attitude and lifestyle make that offensive to the average person in the community.
—It is no use resorting to abuse. There is absolutely no use at all in that.

—I was responding to Senator Walters's abuse. We are setting up a panel. I earnestly ask honourable senators to wait and see who is appointed to that panel and to allow that group to look at the legislation, to look at the propositions which are brought up by various pensioner groups and various other groups in the community, and to consider its recommendations in a sane and sensible way, without all of this nonsense about harassing people. It is a serious problem. It is something that this community must face. It is something that governments have not faced until now. If we do not approach it in a sane and sensible way, with economic and social rationality, we will continue down the path we are following now. We will hear honourable senators on the other side of the House repeatedly talking about the high cost of welfare, the high cost to the taxpayer, and at the same time we will hear members of the community speaking for the disadvantaged groups bewailing the fact, quite justifiably, that the base rates of pension are too low, that disadvantaged people with children receiving pensions and benefits are receiving inadequate support, that people who are in private rental accommodation are receiving inadequate support. All of those things are true.

SPEECH.PARA: The only way we can correct those distortions in our community, the only way we can correct those inadequacies in income support in the community, is to look at the system that we have now and see whether we cannot have some rational change. To suggest that a serious attempt-which is continuing-to make up for those inadequacies is in some way aimed at harassing people, and to raise red herrings of the type raised by Senator Sir John Carrick about jewellery, is not assisting and will not assist rational debate in this area. I hope that in the next few months, as the panel looks at the matter and has the opportunity to listen to positive suggestions from the other side of the House-which I think is terribly important and which we have not had until now-and is able to look at it in a calm and rational way, the benefits will be felt by all of us, not only by pensioners and politicians but also, in particular, by the taxpayers of this country who must pay for the social security system. I ask people to look at it in that light and debate it in that light. It is all very well to impute all sorts of evil and horrible motives to me or the Government. I suggest the issue is far too important to be looked at in that way and I hope that in the future it will be looked at in a sensible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr Acting Deputy President. If Senator Grimes thinks he can intimidate me he is picking on the wrong person. There is no chance in the world that Senator Grimes will ever succeed in intimidating me into not speaking, or not interjecting when he is speaking. He said that I should be the last person in the world to try to defend pensioners because I have a certain lifestyle. If he intends to attempt to initimidate me into not speaking my mind in this place he has chosen the wrong person. How dare he, with an income of, what, $70,000 a year and all the ministerial perks that he receives, refer to my lifestyle.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters claimed to have been misrepresented but I think she has gone well beyond trying to explain the misrepresentation and is now making a series of invectives against my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—Senator Walters, I think you have expanded your subject matter a little. Just confine your remarks to your personal explanation. There is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I cannot defend myself against Senator Grimes's abuse by referring to his lifestyle when he has referred to mine I am very concerned about the Standing Orders. I am now speaking to the point of order raised by Senator Ryan.
—Senator Walters, you must restrict your remarks to what you claim is a misrepresentation.

—I return to what I was saying. When Senator Grimes decided to abuse me I interjected that he had not acknowledged that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had said he had made a mistake. There was no abuse on my part. I merely said that he had refused to acknowledge the Prime Minister's comment.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Walters has now ranged well beyond any explanation of any misrepresentation that may have occurred. She is now debating what the Prime Minister might or might not have said.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. What in fact happened was that Senator Grimes was speaking and Senator Walters interjected, 'But the Prime Minister said it was a mistake', to which the Minister replied that she had made an abusive or offensive remark. Senator Walters is quite entitled to speak to the misrepresentation by the Minister. I draw the Chair's attention to that.
—Speaking to the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, you may recall the ruling of the President yesterday when he said that no interjection could be regarded as a misrepresentation.
—Senator Walters, you may continue if you keep entirely to the personal explanation.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Actually I have completed everything I wanted to say about the matter. I underline the point again that if Senator Grimes thinks he can intimidate me, perhaps because I am a woman-I am not quite sure of the reason-he has chosen the wrong person; he has no chance in the world. He has resorted on many other occasions to personal abuse. There is no way that I will succumb to that type of intimidation.

—by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. The basis of Senator Walters's claim for misrepresentation was that I had attempted to intimidate her and attempted to stop her speaking. I deny this. In fact I would never attempt to prevent Senator Walters speaking; I would not be capable of doing so. I know of no one in this place who would be capable of such a thing. I was speaking and Senator Walters interjected. She interjected in a way that I thought was offensive and I replied. Both Senator Walters and Senator Sir John Carrick are sensitive characters in this place. They will sit in this chamber and interject but when the speaker-me or anyone else-replies to their interjections they do not like it at all. They do not like being responded to in a vigorous way, as I responded to Senator Walters. If they do not like such responses I suggest they stop interjecting. I suggest they remember President Truman's dictum. Senator Sir John Carrick, when on this side of the Senate, used to get terribly upset about the way in which some of us responded to him when he abused us.
—You were the architects of abuse.

—If Senator Sir John Carrick really wants a debate in this place about his previous associations in New South Wales I will enter into that any time he likes. Senator Sir John Carrick stood in this place as Leader of the Government in the Senate and blackguarded us over and over again. He never liked the response. I will respond every time to the interjections that he makes. I will respond to the personal remarks that Senator Walters makes in this place. I make no bones about it.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I make the point that if we are talking about offensiveness, I see the Minister's remarks in regard to Senator Walters' earlier remarks as being absolutely outrageous in the circumstances. All that was sought was a direct reference to a previous remark of the Prime Minister. It is the Minister who is sensitive about this issue because he knows that the Prime Minister said something against his interest.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, can I ask on what basis Senator Messner is speaking at the moment?
—He is speaking on a point of order.
—He did not take a point of order.
—Order! I call the Senate to order. I believe there has been too much debate and interaction on this subject. I suggest that we carry on with the business of the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 May 1983 on motion by Senator Scott:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ULURU (AYERS ROCK-MOUNT OLGA) NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May 1983, on motion by Senator Kilgariff:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 11 of the report refers to Yulara Village. While it is not part of the reserve it is part of the report and I wish to make some comment on Yulara Village and the old village. Recently I was at Ayers Rock for the opening of the Four Seasons Hotel. It is a magnificent place. Yulara Village is a credit to the authority that brought it about. The original plan regarding Yulara Village was that when it was completed the old accommodation would become redundant. Indeed in the report it was stated that the development of Yulara Village would mean that visitor accommodation now provided by the commercial ventures in the enclaves of the Park would become redundant.

SPEECH.PARA: While there have been very many controversial matters relating to the rock, such as its ownership, it is not my intention to discuss those today. Briefly, I wish to discuss the problem of the old accommodation that is now standing at Ayers Rock. A confrontation seems to be developing between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen. Mr Cohen sent a telex stating that the Federal Government had full intentions of demolishing the buildings when Yulara was completed. On the other hand Mr Holding, who has recently had talks in the Northern Territory regarding the old motel area, gave an unequivocal assurance that the Government would respect the private management of Yulara and would not allow the Aboriginals to use the buildings for accommodation to compete with Yulara. This has always been the arrangement. Of course, the Minister who is responsible for the park itself said the buildings will be demolished. However, Mr Holding, who gave an assurance one day that the buildings would be demolished, was reported later as telling Aboriginals that they would be able to use the facilities. As I understand, Mr Holding is proposing this and not the Aboriginal people. I sent a letter to Mr Holding which reads:

In your reported discussions with the aboriginal people at Uluru/Ayers Rock last week, you stated that the original old motels of Ayers Rock could be restored and used for other purposes. This is despite the fact that the acquisition of these motels through Federal Government finance a few years ago was taken to ensure their demolition when the new Yulara village was established .
After demolition, the motel leases were to be brought back as near as possible to their original bushland condition, as the Aboriginal people would have known it.

Despite considerable heartache at that time, the small tourist pioneers were compulsorily bought out by the Federal Government, and they saw their years of efforts being swept aside in the interests of the environment and the future face of the Rock.

Now Minister, despite these actions by Government authority, you suggest that the buildings be now retained, despite the past and despite the environmentalists who say they are an eyesore and have no part in the Aboriginal culture of the area.

The people of the Territory would be most interested to understand the rhyme and reason for your latest pronouncement, having in mind too that the Aboriginal people are being re-established at Yulara.
If you are again to impose your wishes on the people of the Territory despite it being a complete turnaround from a negotiated stance-we ask what next do you have in store?

The matter has to be resolved. Two Federal Ministers appear to be in conflict. I for one would like to have the matter resolved, particularly now that Yulara Village is in being. I believe it is a fine example of co-operation between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 May 1983, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I think this annual report is one of the most interesting and informative reports tabled last year and, as I understand it, nobody has had the opportunity to speak to it. In the light of the very recent fracas in this chamber about assets tests it seems some basic understanding of the facts and figures in social security would be well recorded in the Senate chamber. The annual report contains a remarkable record of the work done in this Department and gives figures and information about the number of people on pensions and benefits in this country, the changing nature of those figures and the changing population currently drawing those pensions and benefits.

Before I refer to them in more detail I will comment on the early parts of the report that referred to the so-called Stratplan, that is, the introduction of the new computer system throughout the Department of Social Security, first of all to replace an outdated system and, secondly, to deal with the enormous increase of work required to be done in the Department consequent to the considerable increase in the number of people drawing pensions and benefits in this country until certainly the date of this report, June 1983. The thing that interests me in the introduction of the whole Stratplan is first of all the thoroughness with which it is being done. Very much effort is being made to judge what is needed in various States and departments around the country. Very considerable effort has gone into the planning provisions for the introduction of this considerable computer system before it is implemented. As well as that there is the parallel training and information provided to staff who will necessarily be required to work on the new system.

The other lines that I find are highlighted in this report-and of which I certainly feel very supportive-are that the Stratplan requests for tender laid particular emphasis on the occupational, health and safety standards required as a consequence of the introduction of this new system. In particular the Department acknowledges that if it is going to put any number of word processors , computer terminals and so on throughout its Department it needs to be very aware of the occupational, health and safety problems that are well known; for instance, eyesight problems of people working on visual display units. I am delighted that these matters are being considered at the time of the introduction of such computers and are not being tacked on later.

In particular it is interesting to note the enormous increase in the number of people who are drawing pensions and the change that has taken place between 1981 -82 and 1982-83. There was, I recall, an enormous increase in the number of people drawing pensions over this time. The figures increased by some 12 per cent on those of the year before compared with some 4.5 per cent increase on the previous year. Until 1983 over one million people were drawing pensions or unemployment benefits in this country. That has, of course, been a major consideration and preoccupation of this Government since it came to office. It is not without interest that the assets test debate has been considered in the light of this Department's annual report.

It is well known to any of us who deal with people in the community that living on a pension is not an easy thing to do. The amount of money such people receive may mean that they are no longer starving but they are certainly not living with any freedom, elegance or extras. They are living very much a hand to mouth, very tight, existence. If they are faced with any increase in expenditure, for example, a stove that breaks down or a water service that goes wrong, they are in particular difficulty. One of the awful problems-it is a recurring problem-is what happens if a pensioner gets behind on his rent or any repayments. I have heard a number of reports of people who have been threatened with the cutting off of their gas supply or electricity because of their failure to pay bills. Those reports completely fail to understand the problems of people who are trying to live on the limited income of a pension. It is with those sorts of considerations in mind that this Government addressed the problem of redirecting income. It made some attempt at this through the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make one or two remarks on an item which was listed on yesterday's Notice Paper but which was inadvertently left off the list in today's Notice Paper. I think it is reasonable, from my point of view and the point of view of the Senate, that we look first at the background of the Burdekin Dam and then at the problems now existing in Queensland in relation to the development of the project itself. It is worth while noting that financial assistance was sought from the Commonwealth from as far back as 1949. Through a series of governments, including Labor governments and Liberal-National Party governments, some undertaking was given in relation to financing that project. It is also worth noting that the previous Labor Government provided a $3m grant in 1974 for the Clare Weir, regarded as the pilot scheme for any future large scale development. It also initiated a Commonwealth-State investigation of the Burdekin Basin potential which was completed in 1977 at a cost of about $1m. Specific projects were not analysed, but the conclusions indicated that without further water resource development the Burdekin delta region would stagnate. Following that investigation by the Federal Government and the allocation of certain amounts of money, it is worth while noting that the previous Government agreed to meet the full cost of the dam, $107m, at January 1983 prices. While the States would be responsible for the cost of the preliminary works amounting to $19m and the development of the irrigation area amounting to $142m, the Federal Government was going to meet its part of the bargain in relation to the amount of money that it would put forward. Not only did the Labor Government and the previous Federal Government indicate that they would support the scheme, but there was also an indication of support by the Queensland Government. In December 1978, the Queensland Government published a full economic, technical evaluation of the Burdekin Dam project. This has been accepted as the preferred scheme under which future development would take place. To extend a little further on the scheme that was put forward by the Queensland Government, the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organisation and the former Department of National Development and Energy undertook a further study of the Burdekin Dam project, the report of which was tabled in Parliament in September 1980.

One of the reasons why I raise these points on the Burdekin Dam today is that as late as yesterday a statement was made by Mr Goleby, a Minister in the Queensland Government. He is initiating a dispute about the concern of people in relation to the gathering together of land that will need to be resumed in relation to the development of the Burdekin Dam project. According to Mr Goleby, the State Government wants a buy back scheme which will allow the farmers, who are the large landholders in the area, to buy back the land acquired by the Government for the Burdekin Dam scheme. Some conflict is involved in this because both the Federal Minister and the State Opposition believe that any land acquired by the Government should be divided amongst the smaller landholders who could ballot to acquire the land around the Burdekin as opposed to setting up a buy back scheme whereby the large landholders would reap some benefit from the development of the Burdekin scheme paid for by taxpayers throughout the Commonwealth of Australia and also by taxpayers throughout Queensland by virtue of the Queensland Government's allocation of money to that scheme.

I hope that the bloody mindedness of the State Government through the Minister does not allow the situation to develop so that large landholders can buy back land and small landholders or people wishing to acquire land after the development of the scheme will not be able to acquire any land because the buy back scheme will prevent them from gaining land to develop the Burdekin River scheme. I hope that the dispute which is starting to develop is settled. Positive steps regarding the scheme have been taken by the present Federal Government and previous State and Federal governments for the benefit of the people in Townsville and north Queensland, in particular, to develop industry and farming in the area and, at a later date, a hydro-electric scheme.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 12.43 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, follows the answers he gave yesterday to questions relating to discussions he had had with the judge referred to in the Age tapes. Does the Attorney-General agree that legal professional privilege arises only in circumstances where the client and the solicitor are discussing a matter in which the solicitor is acting in a professional capacity for the client? Does he further agree that such a claim of privilege cannot be sustained relating to discussions of a more general nature between client and legal adviser and to social conversation, for example? Does this mean that in the case of the conversation about an attempt to denigrate a Sydney suburban alderman said to frequent gay bars, which was reported in the Age tapes, the solicitor was acting in some way for the judge? If he was not so acting for the judge, and the published reports of the conversation about the alderman do not suggest that there were legal proceedings contemplated or a situation in which advice would be sought, what justification has the Attorney- General for claiming, as he did yesterday, that privilege prevented him from disclosing further detail of his discussions with the judge on that matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, legal professional privilege is available in the context not only of actual proceedings on foot but also of putative proceedings or proceedings in contemplation. That was certainly the situation in the particular context to which I referred yesterday, and as to that matter I have no further comment to make.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the answers given yesterday and the rather over-heated response to them in some quarters, I should make the following points absolutely clear. First, in the two interviews to which I referred the judge made no admission that any conversation as recorded in the transcripts and published in the Age actually occurred. The second point is that in fact, as I said yesterday in answer to Senator Jessop, 'on every occasion and in relation to every matter doubts as to and, indeed, rejection of the authenticity of the reports . . . in question' were expressed by the judge. That was an absolutely general statement that I made yesterday in answer to Senator Jessop, and I repeat that for the record in case it was not noticed.

The third point is that what the judge did say as to certain matters which were given publicity in the Age was that conversations with the solicitor in question may have occurred. For example, with respect to the appointment of the senior public servant, which was the subject of the first question in the series from Senator Sir John Carrick, I have subsequently checked my departmental secretary' s aide-memoire of that meeting, and it said:
The judge said he may have spoken to the solicitor about the appointment.
That is what I meant to convey to the Senate yesterday when I said:
. . . the judge's answer was that he had had such a conversation to the extent he could recall it with the solicitor in question . . .

The form of expression I adopted yesterday, without the benefit of the aide- memoire directly in front of me, was, I believe in retrospect, somewhat less than fair to the judge's position, and I correct the record to the extent that it needs correction accordingly. The substance of what I conveyed yesterday was perfectly clear, but the terminology could have been expressed a little more accurately.

The final point I make to put this all clearly in context, I hope, is that what the judge further said was that, to the extent that any such conversations may have occurred-and I repeat my terminology of a moment ago-in relation to specific allegations arising from the reports of those conversations in transcripts and then in turn in the newspapers, as I said in my original statement, he either denied the factual accuracy of those specific allegations, specific propositions, or put them in a rather different context from that which was evident at first sight. Despite the guffaws emanating from the other side of the chamber, I believe that puts with precision and accuracy the substance of the exchanges I had with the judge. Beyond that, I have nothing further to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. There are many supplementary questions arising out of that answer, but I would like to read it carefully before asking them. There is one evident bit of confusion in the answer which the Attorney-General has given me and I would appreciate clarification on it. He referred to the fact that privilege could arise with respect to putative proceedings. Of course, I accept that if one were discussing possible proceedings privilege would arise. With respect to one of the matters on which the Attorney was questioned yesterday, namely, the proceedings to cause embarrassment to a leading Liberal, I accept that it would be possible to put up , or to argue anyway, a claim of professional privilege. But with respect to the smearing of a man for his homosexuality, or the possibility of his homosexuality , I ask the Attorney: Were there proceedings in contemplation in that case also? If not, on what basis could it be said that a discussion between a man and his solicitor on the sexual proclivities of an alderman could give rise to legal professional privilege? I think that has not been addressed by the Attorney, and I would appreciate his doing so.

—Senator Chaney manifestly has not been listening for the last five minutes. I made it absolutely clear that the judge is not to be taken as having admitted the content or for that matter the existence of any particular conversation. I was referring in the context of legal professional privilege to a conversation which the judge acknowledged he may have had and in which the identity of the particular alderman in question was in issue. The subject matter of that conversation in turn was such, he believed and I accept, as would have attracted legal professional privilege.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to a letter published in today's Sydney Morning Herald in which it was claimed that the report of the Water 2000 Study confirmed the wisdom of the Fraser Government's bicentennial water resources program? Can the Minister say whether the Water 2000 Study did in fact support this program? Does the Minister care to comment on the accuracy of any of the other claims in that letter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an extraordinary letter in today's Sydney Morning Herald, apparently written by Senator Sir John Carrick. It claims, among other things, the item to which Senator McIntosh referred-that the Water 2000 Study confirms the wisdom of the Fraser Government's program. Recommendation 4.1 of the Water 2000 Study says:

ANSWER.PARA: Priority in water resource development for irrigation to the year 2000 should be given to the completion of those projects already under construction.

What the Fraser Government actually did when it was approaching its death throes was to produce on 25 January 1983 a shopping list of projects which every cargo cultist had dropped into State departments in the last couple of decades. They varied from the Mitchell River dam which had already been scuttled by the Victorian Government to the supreme cargo cult scheme, the Bradfield scheme. Moreover, as Mr Howard subsequently revealed in an interview published in the Age on, I think, 15 August 1983, the Fraser Government, had it survived, would not have been committed even to the Burdekin scheme. Mr Howard said that he would put that in the hotchpotch with everything else and that there was no necessary commitment to the Burdekin scheme, which had already been commenced. So, far from the Water 2000 report being compatible with the cargo cult, the thrust of the election stunt pulled by Mr Fraser at the end of January last year was totally at variance with the major recommendations of the Water 2000 report: That priority should be given to the completion of schemes already commenced. If the Fraser Government set any store at all by the Water 2000 report it would have waited until it received the report before it announced a major new policy initiative. But of course that did not fit the electoral timetable which the then Prime Minister had in mind and which he subsequently implemented.

Senator Sir John Carrick also claims that the Fraser Government list was based on State priorities. He acknowledges that there was one exception to that, the Mitchell River dam, which the Fraser Government had included in its so-called bicentennial water resources program, a project which had already been scuttled by the Victorian Government. Senator Sir John Carrick thought that he avoided that by saying that that project was given high priority by the Hamer and Thompson governments, by governments which had been consigned to the dustbin of history. It is often concluded that conservative parties-or at least the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-have a firm conviction in their divine right to rule. But Senator Sir John Carrick has broken completely new ground in suggesting, as he does in this letter, that the relevant priority of a State government which should be taken into account by a Federal government is not the actual government of the State but a government which had been defeated in an election nearly 12 months previously. That is an extraordinary extension even of the widespread belief among those who populate the Opposition benches that they have some divine right to rule. They also apparently believe that defunct Liberal governments have the right to rule from the grave.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. Did the mass of material supplied by him to Mr Temby for the purposes of his opinion include, firstly, details of the judge's conversation with the Sydney solicitor's wife, during which he advised her husband to get someone to say in Parliament that the solicitor had 'come up smelling like a rose', and, secondly, the conversations between the judge and the solicitor concerning the launching of proceedings against a former Federal government figure? As there is no apparent reference to either of these matters in the opinion, will the Attorney-General explain why these matters were not dealt with by Mr Temby and will he seek a further opinion from Mr Temby in relation to them?

—The matters to which Senator Durack adverts were, I recall, the subject of some material that was handed to me by the Age. Whether it was in the form of detailed transcripts or just, as indeed was so often the case, one- sentence or two-sentence purported summaries of conversations, I am unable to recall. Certainly all the material handed to me by the Age was in turn given to Mr Temby. I believe that Mr Temby's opinion squarely addressed the matters in issue. He did not specifically necessarily address, nor was he asked to, every particular sentence or half sentence of scuttlebutt that was contained in this particular material. But what he did in relation to all the material in question was to satisfy himself quite clearly, as he says in his opinion, that certainly no criminal conduct occurred, nor was there anything that could be described as misbehaviour within the meaning of the Constitution. He certainly applied those tests to all of the material in his possession, as his opinion makes clear and as he subsequently orally confirmed to me. In the circumstances, I see no justification for any further reference to him.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that, in answer to a question yesterday, the Attorney-General said that he specifically raised with the judge the question of the discussion about launching proceedings -he said what the answer was, and the reaction-and in view of the widespread reporting of that particular matter, can the Attorney-General not now assure us that that was put to Mr Temby and that Mr Temby brought his mind to bear on that matter?

—I can assure the honourable senator that that particular matter was brought to Mr Temby's attention. I can assure him, equally, that Mr Temby put his mind to the matter. I can assure him also that there is, indeed, one quite specific passage in Mr Temby's opinion which deals with that particular subject matter. But I shall have to leave it to Sherlock and his troops over there to find that out for themselves.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that the United States Department of Commerce is investigating complaints by American steel producers that Australian steel was dumped on the United States market? Can the Minister inform the House whether, in the Government's opinion, Australia's steel exports to the United States, totalling 180,000 tonnes in the last year, constituted a breach of American trade laws in regard to dumping? Does Australia's action in this matter contravene the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade? Will the Government be negotiating with the United States Government on this matter or, alternatively, what assistance will the Government be offering John Lysaght Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in fighting this case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the anti-dumping and countervailing petitions which have been lodged with the United States Department of Commerce by the United States Steel Corporation. Those petitions allege that Australia is introducing exports at less than a fair price into the United States market. They also allege subsidisation by the Australian Government. Under the United States procedures the Department of Commerce has until 1 March-today-to determine whether the petitions are sufficient to establish a prima facie case. If it is found that the petitions establish a prima facie case the matter is referred to the International Trade Organisation for a preliminary determination on the question. The Government has been consulting very closely the Australian companies involved-the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and John Lysaght Ltd in particular. The companies intend to defend any dumping action if it arises as a litigious matter and the Government, on behalf of the Australian industry, will defend the case in respect of countervailing duties. Since this matter was drawn to our attention the Government, through its representatives in Washington, has also been making representations to the United States Government about both matters. We have been arguing there that insufficient grounds exist to proceed with the actions which are contemplated by the United States steel industry.

ANSWER.PARA: These proceedings have been brought by the United States steel industry against exports from other countries in a very similar manner. It is perhaps an uncharitable observation to make, but I remind Senator Richardson, who is very aware of these matters, that it is an election year in the United States and the United States steel industry is no doubt very conscious of that fact. Also, the quantities of steel involved from the Australian industry are really minuscule in the context of total United States steel consumption, and it looks very much as though Australia has been hooked into these procedures, as it were, largely as a result of the desire of the United States industry to take these proceedings against a number of other countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of an anomaly in the Income Tax Assessment Act recently noted in the report entitled 'A Maintenance Agency for Australia' prepared by the Family Law Branch of the Attorney-General's Department? The report states:

QUESTION.PARA: The ITAA now provides, by paragraph 23 (1), that income by periodic payments of alimony or maintenance received by a woman from her husband or former husband is exempt from income tax.

This is because the income is assessable in his hands and he is not allowed the payments as a deduction-which is fair enough. The problem arises because, as the report points out, in cases 'where alimony or maintenance is received by a man from his former wife, there is no exemption from tax for the payments in the husband's hands, while the paying wife is also taxed in respect of the same money as it is income in her hands'. Is this assessment of paragraph 23 (1) correct? If so, does the Minister agree that this failure to confer an apparent benefit upon a man in the same circumstances in which it is conferred upon a woman is one of the few cases of sexual discrimination against men in this country? If so, will he approach the Treasurer with a view to having that part of the ITAA duly amended so that both sexes are treated equally and maintenance is not taxed in the hands of the recipient, whether that person is male or female?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the Treasurer was aware of what I presume are the facts that Senator Haines has read out, but I certainly was not. I accept the accuracy of what she has set out. It is one example-it is not the only one; I can think of a couple of others off the top of my head-where, as she said, the law discriminates against males relative to its treatment of females. I will ask the Treasurer to check out the facts and whether he will consider amending the Act in order to remove, one way or other, the anomaly to which Senator Haines has drawn attention.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Health recall the points raised by the Opposition in the debate about Medicare, in particular its claims that a large number of jobs would be lost from private health funds with the establishment of Medicare, that there would be insufficient time to administer adequately the introduction of Medicare and that there would be a very long turnaround time for claims under the new arrangements? Can the Minister say whether there is any evidence from the first month of Medicare to substantiate any of the Opposition's arguments, that is, how many jobs have been lost, how many people have been enrolled and what is the turnaround time on claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The alarmist views of various people in the Opposition and some in the medical profession have not come to fruition. In fact, Medicare has been introduced successfully and with very few problems. The total number of Health Insurance Commission full time staff in June 1983 was 1,472 and in February 1984 it was 2,857. The number of part time staff totalled 382 in June last year and it now totals 1,382. Of these additional staff, I think about 1,050 are former private health fund employees. A further 28 former private health fund staff have accepted offers of employment but have not yet commenced. A further 250 positions will be advertised nationally and former private health fund employees will receive preference in filling those jobs, as in others.

ANSWER.PARA: As fas as enrolment in Medicare is concerned, on the latest available figures 94 per cent of the Australian population is now covered. As to the efficiency of the operation generally, as Senator Crowley knows, Medicare is working towards a goal of processing direct bill claims within five working days of receipt. In practice, when we allow for weekends and postage delays at both ends, this means that claimants can expect to receive their cheques approximately two weeks after lodging their claims. Initially, the processing time has been slightly longer than five days but this period should be reduced as additional transmission lines become available. The number of staff employed on direct billing is increasing and the productivity and experience of existing staff is improving.

It may be interesting to honourable senators to know the number of claims processed by Medicare during the period 1 February to 25 February. Of the total number of claims in New South Wales, for instance, there were 322,500 cash claims, 186,690 cheque claims and 257,742 direct billing claims. In South Australia, Senator Crowley's State, there were 40,000 cash claims, 78,171 cheque claims and 56,812 direct billing claims. The same pattern appears throughout all the States. In fact, out of 1,800,000-odd claims there was a total of 827,059 cash claims, 460,749 cheque claims and 560,786 direct bulk billing claims. I think this indicates two things: First of all, the system is working very well and, secondly, many more doctors than people would be led to believe are willing to use the bulk billing facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Attorney-General has said he visited the judge concerned in the Age tapes and received the opinion of judicial misbehaviour from Mr Ian Temby, QC, on the same day, that is, 15 February, will he now tell the Senate whether the visit preceded or followed receipt of the opinion? If he had the opinion when he saw the judge, did he communicate all or any of it to the judge? If so, what did he comunicate and at what stage of the conversation did he do so?

—The interview with the judge succeeded my receipt of the opinion, as I made perfectly clear in my statement two days ago, because I wanted to receive, as it were, a clearance from Mr Temby as well as from the Australian Federal Police as to the propriety of putting the material to the judge in order to ensure that there would be no question in anybody's mind of subsequent criminal investigations being prejudiced. As to making the copy of the information available to the judge, my re- collection is that I did so at that interview. If it was not at the interview it was certainly at some time shortly thereafter.

—Would the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs not agree that internal investigations into the Department of Foreign Affairs corruption allegations such as those made by me against Mr John Ryan and those recently made by Mrs Carmel Van Dartel against Mr Henderson and others are widely regarded as farcical in the extreme? Will the Minister provide the Senate with an unequivocal confirmation that Mrs Van Dartel's invalidity retirement was due to injuries sustained in a motor accident and for no other purpose?

—I do not accept that internal investigations of the kind to which Senator Primmer referred are farcical in the extreme. As to the latter part of his question, I will check that matter out and confirm it accordingly.

—I refer the Attorney-General to his interviews with the judge referred to in the Age tapes. Did the Attorney discuss with the judge the reported conversation between the judge and the wife of a Sydney solicitor, during which conversation the judge is said to have suggested that the solicitor should get someone in the New South Wales Parliament to say that an investigation had been made and the solicitor had 'come up smelling like a rose' ? If so, did the judge explain why he had suggested the need for a public clearance of the solicitor's name? Does the Attorney-General agree that the contact between a client and his solicitor's wife could not give rise to legal professional privilege? Does he believe that it was proper for the judge to give such advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly confirm to the extent that it is proper for me to give a legal opinion that a conversation between a client and his solicitor's wife would not attract legal professional privilege. Beyond that I have no further comment to make. As I said yesterday, I do not propose to go through a process of responding to every single line of this material, unauthenticated as it is, unaccepted as it is by the person in question, and indicating in any detail the nature of the judge's response. I simply repeat the general character of his response to this, that he made no admission that any matter alleged to have been the subject of his conversations did in fact occur. But to the extent that he acknowledged that some particular conversations may have occurred with the person in question and on the broad subject matter then, as to the particular contents of those conversations, he either denied outright their factual accuracy or put the circumstance in a rather different context than may be evident at first sight.

ANSWER.PARA: There is simply no basis on which it is either fair, reasonable or legitimate to pursue this in the kind of detail that is being pursued. Mr Temby was satisfied, the police were satisfied and I am satisfied-and I assume responsibility for expressing that satisfaction-that there was no question of criminal misconduct or any question of any other kind of conduct that could possibly give rise to a proceeding for misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constititution. Beyond that I do not think it is proper or legitimate for this Parliament to pursue, in the way that it seems minded to do through Opposition spokesmen and members, matters that, to the extent that they have any factual accuracy at all, represent, as I have repeated on innumerable occasions, a grotesque invasion of personal privacy; representing material, to the extent that it is authentic at all, that was obtained in circumstances of manifest illegality and, under those circumstances, I believe, make it quite inappropriate for this matter to be further pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to reports that contaminated water recently escaped from a site at the Mary Kathleen uranium mine? Are these reports correct? If so, can the Minister say what is the likely effect on the environment? What steps can his Department take to ensure that there can be no further incidents which are of grave concern to property owners in the area?

—I have been told of the incident to which Senator Reynolds referred. It has been reported to some extent in the Press. I am advised that approximately 1,000 cubic metres of liquid was accidently released from an evaporation pond. The accident occurred while the liquid was being siphoned into a lower pond to avoid possible overflow of the upper pond during heavy rain. I presume that the siphon hose broke, or something like that. Since it happened in a period of heavy rain the 1,000 cubic metres of contaminated liquid would have been heavily diluted in the creeks. But the company has tests under way to assess the water quality downstream from the point of release which will enable a determination of the appropriate clean-up procedure, if any, which will be required. The site of the Mary Kathleen mine is being rehabilitated in accordance with the program approved by the Queensland Government and for which the Queensland Government has responsibility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to his response to me earlier in Question Time in which he said: 'In the two interviews to which I referred the judge made no admission that any conversation as recorded in the transcripts and published in the Age actually occurred'. I remind him that, in the Senate two days ago he said:

QUESTION.PARA: In respect of specific matters raised by the published material he--

. . . either specifically denied the factual accuracy of the allegations concerning him, or gave explanations which put those allegations in a rather different context than that evident at first sight.
I further remind the Attorney that yesterday at Question Time he was asked three questions relating to specific conversations which were part of the tapes. He said in part answer to one:
As I recall it, the judge's answer was that he had had such a conversation to the extent that he could recall it with the solicitor in question . . .
With respect to the second question he said:
. . . he made the point that there had been a series of conversations with the solicitor relating to the initiation of possible litigation by himself and certain others.
I do not need to quote any more. He said further, in response to the third question:

In the context that there may have been a discussion, whether it was precisely a discussion of the kind alleged in the tapes in the report of the newspaper is very much another question but to the extent that there may have been a discussion it was very much in the context of a solicitor-client type discussion . . .

In light of the evident discrepancy between what he has said on Tuesday and Wednesday as against what he said today, will he tell us whether what he said on Tuesday and Wednesday is still to be regarded as the truth or whether, to use Mr Nixon's phrase, it is now 'inoperative'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Senator Georges, it is not necessary, really.

—I wish to take a point of order, no matter what the Attorney- General desires. My point of order is that we are now engaging in the trial of a person at Question Time. If the name of the person were known-and I think it is known-we would-

—That is the responsibility of others. We would be in breach of the Standing Orders. Let me go away from the Standing Orders. Let me put it to you, Mr President, that at Question time we are engaging in the trial of a person who has no access to any defence whatsoever. We engaged in the trial of a person by innuendo and allegation based on material that has not been properly tested. I think it diminishes the status of the Senate to continue in this fashion.
—I have been listening to the questions carefully, and there is no point of order.

—Senator Chaney's question, lengthy as it was, was erected on a false premise in the very first sentance. He quoted me as saying this morning: 'The judge made no admission that any conversation recorded in the transcript actually occurred'. I said nothing of the kind. What I said this morning was: 'The judge made no admission that any conversation as recorded in the transcripts and published in the Age occurred'.
—That is exactly what I said.

—Senator Chaney omitted the word 'as' and there is a very significant difference if he ponders it. Of course what I said yesterday and indeed what I said on Tuesday is consistent with a concession by the judge that at least some of the conversation in question with the persons in question on the general subject matter may have occurred. Of course that is the case. As such, there is no inconsistency in anything I have said subsequently.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am happy to give the Attorney- General what I quoted from, which is the exact words he used in response to me. In light of the evident discrepancy between what he has said today and what he has said over the last two days, will he table, I think his word is, a sanitised version of the aide memoire so that we can satisfy ourselves as to the accuracy of what he has told this Parliament?
—Since there is no such discrepancy the question of my tabling that document to prove the point that I make does not arise.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I refer to a report in the Adelaide Advertiser during the parliamentary recess concerning research done in Adelaide University on a newly discovered species of frog which has the ability to stop acid secretion in its stomach. In view of the medical possibilities of applying the substance, which prevents acid secretion, in the treatment of illnesses such as stomach ulcers, will the Government consider extra funding for this research as it has been claimed that the new species could justify the work of an extra six research staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, that matters in the Adelaide Advertiser during January concerning the new frog species-I believe it is called the platypus frog -and its application to human medical research have been drawn to his attention. He advised me that the Government recognises the significance of the research being carried out in Adelaide in connection with the inhibition of stomach acid secretion in certain rare kinds of frogs. The potential application to human illness such as stomach ulcers is important.

ANSWER.PARA: The researchers concerned, Professor Shearman, Dr Seamark and Mr Tyler from Adelaide University and Dr O'Brien from Flinders University were awarded grants from the Australian research grants scheme of $18,000, both in 1983 and 1984. Mr Jones advises me that he anticipates the researchers will shortly be making a further application to ARGS for the 1985 grant year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to the brochure that was distributed by the Institution of Engineers Australia, titled 'Engineering Education in Crisis, 1983' in which the Institution points to the damaging effect of continued funding restrictions on the quality of education of professional engineers in Australia? In fact, the Institution now says the situation is contrary to the national interest. In view of the seriousness of the present situation and the importance of a sufficient number of well trained engineers to the development of all aspects of this country, will the Minister have the Department examine the brochure and, if necessary, officers of the Department? Will he have them have discussions with the Institution of Engineers and then advise the Senate what action it is intended to take on the recommendations that are made by the Institution in the brochure that I mentioned.

—I am quite happy to undertake some investigation into the claims that are being made by the Institution of Engineers. The particular pamphlet referred to by Senator Townley has not been drawn to my attention.
