In response to Senator Townley I suggest that the most appropriate course of action would be for me to consult with the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission because the Commission has been asked to review manpower needs in a number of crucial areas in higher education. Clearly, if our needs for trained engineers are changing, that need should form part of its review and part of its advice to me. If Senator Townley would like to make the pamphlet available to me I will make sure the Tertiary Education Commission considers the matters raised.

—I refer the Minister for Industry and Commerce to recent allegations of transfer pricing in the motor vehicle industry. I ask: Has the Minister instituted a thorough audit of imported vehicle components in order to determine the extent of abuse of transfer pricing in the industry. If so, are any results available to date? If not, will he conduct the audit?

—I am asked whether I had an investigation made into the recent allegations of transfer pricing. I assure the honourable senator they are not recent allegations, they have been going on in one form or another for a long time. It is a very difficult issue because most component parts of vehicles are brought in in packs and it has not been an easy question for the Customs to resolve. These complaints were brought again in the middle of last year during the period in which I was Minister. I wrote in about July last year to each of the five planned manufacturers seeking information and co-operation from those manufacturers in respect of the import of component parts and the allegations of transfer pricing. I have received information in writing from most of the planned producers on this question and I am now seeking more information from them. As I said, it is a difficult question to resolve, but I am expecting to receive from my Department shortly a number of options on the basis of the material which we now have and on the basis of determining which is the best option. We will take what steps we can to deal with the matter as quickly as possible.

—I refer the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to that part of the Prime Minister's National Press Club speech last week in which he promised the fullest possible consultations with non-government schools on the new policy. He said: 'I give a guarantee that I will be fully involved in that process'. Because that part of the Prime Minister's promise has attracted the attention of non-government school authorities, I ask: Will the Minister advise the Senate exactly how and to what extent the Prime Minister will intervene within her portfolio to redeem the pledge he made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, at this particular stage I will not advise the Senate of the arrangements that the Prime Minister will be making in the future. I was very pleased that the Prime Minister made that announcement to the Press Club because I have been discussing these matters with him for some time and he has expressed a great interest in the whole process. I have discussed those matters with him again today, but at this stage we do not have the particular timetable.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me give the Senate some information about the consultations. As I recall, the Commonwealth Schools Commission is currently, and has been for the last three weeks, travelling around Australia consulting with not only representatives of non-government schools but also State Ministers, State education departments and representatives of government schools about the issues contained in the funding options paper. When the Commission has finished this process of consultation it will report to me on the results and make some proposals about how our needs based approach to funding might be expressed in terms of funding formulas for the future. It expects to be able to report to me at the end of March. At that stage, I have undertaken to consult with national government and non-government organisations about what the report has said. At that stage also I will be meeting with my State ministerial colleagues and discussing with my Federal colleagues our response to that report. At that stage it will be most suitable for the Prime Minister to become involved, but the Prime Minister's program is a matter for him to determine and I will be having further discussions with him at about that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The Department of Administrative Services is reported to be studying tenders for $9.4m worth of Commonwealth office space in Fremantle, most of which will house the Bureau of Customs. In view of the fine reputation of the Fremantle City Council for conserving and restoring its uniquely historical city, will the Minister give an assurance that the Council will be consulted before tenders are let?

—The Government is committed to improving the office stock for government operations in all the States of the Commonwealth, in particular in Fremantle where there are a number of unsatisfactory and inadequate features with our office accommodation. I have seen the reports that the Department of Administrative Services is studying tenders for office space in Fremantle and also that the City Council through its Mayor, Mr McKenzie, has expressed concern that this proposal of the Government might pose some threat to the future and the livelihood of the city's west end. To that extent the Government is committed to a policy of consultation with any group affected by government decision making and has undertaken to discuss the matter with the Fremantle City Council. I understand those discussions will take place over the next two weeks. I think I can give an assurance to Senator Giles that the Government is committed to an environmental protection policy and that also includes our concern for old buildings and for the environment, whether it be a natural or a man-made environment. To that extent the Minister for Administrative Services has assured me that he will be taking those matters into account when the discussions are held with the Fremantle City Council.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that some overseas students currently studying in Australia, and some other persons on a limited entry visa to Australia, are arranging for their names to be placed on Commonwealth electoral rolls and are using this enrolment as a reason for permanent residence. How widespread is this practice? What action has been taken against such offenders?
—Since the honourable senator was unkind enough not to give me notice of his question, I will have to refer it to the Special Minister of State.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Was the schedule fee until yesterday for a standard medical consultation in Queensland $11.60 and has it now been increased to $12? Does the Department of Health have any information on the fees charged by individual medical practitioners? If so, do most medical practitioners on he Sunshine Coast in Queensland charge at least $15 for a standard consultation? Are the views of medical practitioners taken into account when schedule fees for various types of medical services are determined? If they are, why do medical practitioners, such as those on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland, charge well beyond the schedule fee, thus financially disadvantaging those who need medical assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Colston said, there has been an increase in the medical benefits schedule fees from today. The increase is 4.3 per cent, which I believe takes the standard consultation fee in Queensland from $11.60 to $12. The 4.3 per cent increase which was given to doctors from today, of course, is the same increase as workers throughout Australia have received in recent months . The Medical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, under the chairmanship of the Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Mr McKenzie, is currently hearing arguments from the Government, the Australian Medical Association and other interested bodies about whether there is a need for a further schedule fee increase. Because a doctor's income is different from that of wage and salary earners due to staff, transport and other overhead costs associated with running a practice, it may be that a further increase is justified.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question, the Government does have information on the fees charged by individual doctors. The information was provided through the private health funds' statistics prior to the introduction of Medicare. The information is now available more accurately and efficiently through Medicare. However, I stress in relation to schedule fee compliance by practitioners that an overall figure for a State, rather than for individual areas, is analysed. Because the Medicare system has just commenced, statistics are not available on the level of compliance with the schedule fee. But from subjective evidence I have received, the Minister for Health has received and certainly some other senators have received, it would seem that there are numbers of doctors who are not charging the schedule fee. In fact, the numbers who are complying with the schedule fee may even be declining. This is of concern to the government and also to the community. It also should be of considerable concern to the medical profession. If doctors and other professional groups expect trade unionists to abide by arbitration procedures, I think they should do so themselves. But when the wage freeze came into operation many members of the profession unfortunately decided to grant themselves a catch up increase without waiting for the proper arbitral procedures to be undertaken.

I hope that when the fee tribunal hands down its decision-in handing down that decision, the views of the medical practitioners and their representatives will be taken into account-compliance with the schedule fees will return to its previous levels. This would be in the best interests of the community at large; it would certainly be in the best interests of Medicare and the private health funds, and it would be in the best interests of the profession. When independent interest groups act in this way against properly arbitrated decisions, there is great pressure on the Government to bring them into line. I hope this will not be necessary. But the responsibility in this case lies with the medical profession. There will undoubtedly be pressure if the medical profession, or significant sections of it, continue to avoid the arbitrated fees which are arbitrated in conjunction and in co-operation with their representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce who is responsible for small business. I refer to the proposal to shelve the Australian Capital Territory Leasing Ordinance. Is the Minister aware of the promise made by the Australian Labor Party to small business prior to the March election last year in its action program dated 13 February 1983, which stated that a model lease would be developed. Can the Minister advise why the Government has not been able to honour its commitment in this area after twelve months in office, while the Bjelke-Petersen Government yesterday met its electoral commitment for lease legislation after only two months of parliamentary sittings? Would a copy of the Queensland legislation help the Minister with this complex problem that the Government does not seem to be able to understand?

—As I recall, the Queensland Government has been in office for more than 20 years. That is the length of time that it has taken it to do anything about this topic which has been the subject of discussion in business areas for many years. It is in a similar category to the uniform building regulations with which the Queensland Government has had the same difficulty over the same period. So I do not believe I would get any help from the Queensland Government. The discussions that I have had with representatives of that Government on business matters have bordered on the inarticulate and I will not be seeking support from that source on those particular matters. With regard to the Australian Capital Territory Leasing Ordinance being shelved, I will make inquiries from the Minister for Territories and Local Government. It is within his area of responsibility. The question of a model lease being developed is still under consideration by the Department of Industry and Commerce.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, concerns the proposed redrafting of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. What stage have negotiations on the redrafting reached? Is the Minister satisfied with the response to date from State housing Ministers? Will the new Agreement result in an easing of public housing pressures in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Renegotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, together with new policies such as the community housing expansion program, the community amenities program and local government housing programs are part of the Australian Labor Party's policy. One of the first things that is being negotiated is the Commonwealth State-Housing Agreement. Preliminary discussions between Federal, State and Territory housing Ministers were held at the end of last year and on 24 February and probably 25 February last. The comments of the State Ministers on priorities for a new agreement were, in the view of the Commonwealth Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Hurford, most constructive. There is a general consensus for a new thrust in public housing policy which will have two approaches. The first approach is to make a greater effort to alleviate poverty related to high rental costs of housing, particularly those in private rental accommodation. The honourable senator will be aware that at the moment the subsidies available for those in public rental accommodation are much higher than for those in private rental accommodation. The second approach is to try to ensure that housing assistance is equitable among all forms of tenure.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of those discussions and discussions with local government and non- government organisations, I believe there will be a much better Commonwealth- State Housing Agreement because all of those people's views will have been taken into account. At the moment the Minister expects the Commonwealth offer about the new Housing Agreement to be available towards the end of April or in May. The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, of course, is central to this Government's housing policy. The whole intent of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is to assist the States, particularly the State housing commissions and housing trusts, to improve the volume of housing and the access of disadvantaged people in particular to that housing. In the case of an enlightened housing trust and an enlightened State with an enlightened housing policy such as South Australia we can expect the result of such an agreement to have a greater spread of accommodation and a better balance of accommodation in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Attorney-General and refer him to land formerly used by the Commonwealth for the use and detonation of explosives, such as former artillery ranges, particularly the former artillery range at Warnbro in Western Australia. Does the Commonwealth Government accept liability for any injury or damage which may be caused by on-site explosions from debris and UXBs left in the area? While I am sure it will make no difference to the ultimate legal judgment made by the Commonwealth, I remind the Attorney-General that it was the Commonwealth that caused the bombs to be placed there in the first place, that it failed to locate them and remove them. The Government quit possession with the bombs still in place. Perhaps it might be implied that the Commonwealth accepted liability in part by providing funds for the Western Australian Government to assist to remove that material down to three metres.

—I am advised that the Warnbro land was never owned by the Commonwealth, that it was used as a range under some form of licence by the Commonwealth, the United States of America and perhaps other forces during World War II. It is known to have been polluted by unexploded ammunition. I am informed that in 1978-79 the then Government agreed to meet the cost of a search for unexploded ammunition and to arrange for detonation of ammunition that was found. The Commonwealth has not accepted liability for any injury or damage caused by explosion in the area. Generally speaking the situation is, however, that the Commonwealth is liable at law for any wrongful actions or omissions on its part, as would be the case if it were a private citizen. That follows from sections 56 and 64 of the Judiciary Act. I am not aware of any proposal that would accept a greater measure of responsibility than this. It would seem to be sufficient from the point of view of putative plaintiffs in this respect.

—In answer to one of the questions asked about the Age tapes this morning-I think it was from Senator Kilgariff-I said that as I recalled it I had actually physically handed over to the judge in question the Temby opinion on the first of the interviews on 15 February. I was a little unsure whether that was so. I checked my recollection subsequently and the answer is no, I did convey orally the substance of that opinion as it related in particular to questions of criminality and misbehaviour but the actual physical text of it was not in fact forwarded by my Department until some days later. I would not wish in any way to be inaccurate in this matter.

—On 29 February Senator Hearn asked me a question about the present whereabouts of a plaque in honour of the Tolpuddle Martyrs, previously located at the old Hobart Trades Hall. The Minister for Administrative Services informed me that the plaque is now located at the new Trades Hall building at Newtown, Tasmania. The plaque was relocated following Commonwealth acquisition of the old Trades Hall on 1 October 1974. I am further informed that the Hobart Trades Hall trustees and management committee regards the plaque as its property and has stated that the plaque will remain at the new Trades Hall building.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Sibra asked me as Minister representing the Special Minister of State a question about scrutineering practices during the recent Richmond by-election. The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question: The Australian Electoral Commission has advised that the Divisional Returning Officer for Richmond did rule that each candidate was entitled to be represented by only two scrutineers at each counting centre. The Australian Electoral Commission has further advised that this ruling was quite consistent with the provisions of section 130 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act as it applied to the Richmond by-election. That section provides as a general rule that a candidate is not entitled to be represented at the scrutiny at a particular counting centre by more than one scrutineer. The section goes on to provide that the Divisional Returning Officer for the division may increase the number of candidates.

ANSWER.PARA: The Special Minister of State has advised that the problem Senator Sibraa brought under notice should not arise in the future. One of the many electoral reforms effected by the 1983 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act was an amendment to section 130 to ensure that a candidate was entitled to be represented at the scrutiny at a counting centre by as many scrutineers as there were officials engaged in the scrutiny or counting of ballot papers at that centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Question Time in response to the second question I asked the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) he suggested that I had misquoted something that he had said in reply to an earlier question. In asking him the question I read from a record of the answer he had given, prepared in my office. That appears to me to be exactly the same as the wording which the Attorney used in his response to me . I therefore believe that I in no way misrepresented the words which he used. I ask him to check the Hansard record and if he is wrong again I ask him, as he did a moment ago, to apologise and withdraw.

—by leave-Just for the record, I was not imputing any ill motives to Senator Chaney in saying what I thought he said in purporting to quote my words. There did seem to me to be a significant substantive difference between the two forms of expression which were in issue. We have had rows about language in the past and I thought it appropriate to get the record straight as soon as possible. I hasten to add that I do believe that, read properly, the language I used contains its own answer to Senator Chaney's question.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Kilgariff proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The political manoeuvrings of the Government to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 64, I raise the following as a matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The political manoeuvrings of the Government to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.

I will very briefly go over the history of the line. The provision of a rail link through the centre of Australia from the north to the south has been a vision for 100 years or more. Indeed it played its part in the agreement reached between the Federal Parliament and South Australia. Of course, this was after Federation when the Territory, which was a part of South Australia, became Federal property. Somewhat painfully, a narrow gauge line was laid across South Australia and by degrees to Alice Springs, which it reached in 1929. During this time a line was laid from Darwin to Birdum, which eventually was closed down.

In the same era Western Australia was brought into regular communication with the east by rail link. During the period of the McMahon coalition Government firm plans were made and finance committed for the continuity of a standard gauge line from Tarcoola, on the east-west line in South Australia, to Alice Springs. The project was picked up by the Whitlam Government and was completed by the Fraser Government in 1980. The completion of this project constituted a mere link in the chain of providing an all-weather standard gauge rail link to our northern coast, at Darwin.

Planning continued for the next stage-that is, Alice Springs to Darwin-and a considerable amount of funds was expended in preparation, prior to initial construction contracts being signed. Thanks to the efforts of the national railway project team, headed by the engineer Des Smith who, I suggest, is the modern pioneer of railway construction, construction of the line is almost ready to start. The track has been surveyed and is being protected. Aboriginal consent has been given for where the line would cross Aboriginal land. The Northern Territory Government is prepared to protect the track. Work by surveyors and other men, numbering some hundreds, has now reached the point where it is possible to see from the air the graded outlines of the proposed rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin. It is almost ready to go; it awaits contracts for construction.

Come the 1983 election the question of the future of that all important railway link became an important election issue, particularly in the Northern Territory. I think to no small degree the success in the election of the Australian Labor Party candidate, John Reeves, rested on ALP promises. Leaflets depicting the now Prime Minister Bob Hawke were put out captioned: 'Bringing Australia together. Boost Territory development. Build Alice Springs to Darwin railway'. A series of statements and promises followed. For instance, as late as 22 April 1983 the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, said that the Hawke Government promised to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. On that day Senator Gietzelt told the Senate that no steps would be taken to curtail that election commitment. On 15 March 1983 the Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, said that it was a project of national and international significance which the Labor Party would honour.

On 10 May 1983 John Reeves, the member for the Northern Territory-I have no doubt that he regrets the report that has been tabled-said that the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link was the linchpin for future development in the Northern Territory and those who claimed the cost of the railway was unjustified would have said the same about the Snowy River project when it was first mooted. Then the thunder clouds of big government spending started to gather. Despite the improvement in the international and Australian recession the decrease in Australia's inflation rate and the end of the drought, which meant that the financial situation of the country was improving immeasurably, the Labor Government's deficit grew and it is still growing alarmingly. The effect of this appears to have brought about a remarkable twist for without precedent in Australian rail history the Northern Territory was called on by the Prime Minister to finance 40 per cent of the proposed national rail project. The overall cost of the railway in October 1982 was $541m. It was demanded that the Northern Territory contribute $216m, a most unusual demand considering that the Northern Territory gets its annual allocation of tax sharing funds through the memorandum of understanding which was agreed to by the Federal and Northern Territory governments and which the Commonwealth Grants Commission oversighted. No money was available for such a demand.

This promoted a most bitter public debate, particularly as it could be seen that the Government appeared to be reneging on a firm election promise. This was followed by the Minister for Transport deciding to hold an inquiry. The inquiror was Mr David Hill, the Executive Director of the New South Wales Rail Authority. He is a close friend of Mr Wran and Mr Hawke. I see nothing wrong with that but in hindsight the appointment was lacking to quite a degree.

There has been considerable interest, particularly from South Australia and the Northern Territory, in the report on the Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, which has now been tabled. South Australia and the Northern Territory could see from the way things were going that the completion of this national rail project was being wiped out or, at least, placed in considerable jeopardy. To say the least, it was an incomplete inquiry. One of the most significant aspects of the rail case-defence-was not considered by the inquirer. A decision on the defence aspects of the construction of such a rail link still rests in the hands of the Federal Government. It is most peculiar that defence, which is one of the main considerations in the north, has been left out of the report.

Many substantial authoritative submissions which were costly in time and money, were made by the South Australian and Northern Territory governments. I do not have the South Australian submissions with me in the chamber but I have the submissions from the Northern Territory. They have been prepared at the cost of much time and money. It was also promised that there would be consultation on the many aspects of the rail, including the upgrading of the Stuart Highway which was part of the inquiry. As I have said the report is now with us. It has been rushed through without any discussion on the numerous papers submitted. It was tabled without complying with the promises that were given, one of which was that there would be consultation with the South Australian and Northern Territory governments before the report was tabled. This has not taken place. In effect it is a partial report which-it is obvious now-is based on poor and false premises. I have before me an evaluation of the Hill report by officers of the Northern Territory Government and I will quote from it to indicate to the Senate the many concerns that I have in regard to the report. I intend to table the evaluation-I will not have it incorporated in Hansard-so that interested people can at least see how the Northern Territory feels towards the report. I will refer to one or two parts of the evaluation.
It states:
The Hill Report, in large part, is an attempted rebuttal of the case presented by the Northern Territory Government to the Inquiry.
The whole tenor of the report and the manner in which the Northern Territory submission is constantly referred to, belies the even-handed manner in which an Inquiry should address its task.

The NT Government provided a comprehensive and professional assessment of the economic resultants and social effects of the construction of the railway in which all estimates and assumptions of future effects were clearly spelt out.
By comparison, the reasoning behind many of the fundamental assumptions made by the Hill Inquiry are inadequately documented, making independent analysis difficult.

The first major area where this occurs is in its approach to forecasting freight demand. Forecasts of freight demand is a fundamental issue in assessing the transport requirements of the Northern Territory, and must necessarily be made in order to make judgments about the future.
The evaluation goes on to indicate where there is disagreement with figures and costings, and states:

However, as the Northern Territory submission has made clear, the economic development of many of the potential mineral areas is dependent upon either the decision to build the railway or on its actual construction.

The approach adopted by the Northern Territory Government is similar to that adopted in other developing regions or countries where appropriate transport infrastructure is seen to be a prerequisite to the development of economic potential.

In the absence of quantifiable reasons for the reduction of the freight forecasts by the Inquiry, the NT's forecasts of transport demand in northern Australia must remain the most acceptable estimate.
Towards the end of the document, it states:
There are a number of other issues referred to in the Technical Assessment which have resulted in a less than equitable evaluation being made of the case.
A summary tabulation of the rerun results of the Hill inquiry and the NT base figures on our computer model is appended-
That is of interest to many, no doubt-

It indicates the specific areas of disagreement which are taken up in the Technical Assessment. In summary we consider that our approach has been professional and rigorous and that the conclusions are justifiable-that on economic grounds alone the project provides substantial benefit to Australia and should be undertaken.

When considering the overall situation and the Federal Government's attitude to the rail project I say that, given the way the inquiry was initiated and the apparent skimming and the speed with which the inquiry was made and the report printed, one can surmise only that it is but fuel for the action of destroying the project. At this time we can only complain about this action because the Federal Government has the ability to force the findings and decisions of this report down our throats. I suggest that in time they will be regurgitated and the construction of the line will continue.

Submissions to the inquiry indicate that the findings are false. There are very many grounds for this finding. It is most interesting that when one looks back with hindsight at this inquiry one finds that it was chaired by a person from the New South Wales State Rail Authority which loses $2m a day. Over a year more than $700m of the taxpayers' money is lost. Yet that person is supposed to be able to reach a reasoned decision regarding the line from Alice Springs to Darwin. How can such a situation exist? Why do we look in this gloomy area, as I think I called it, of financial rail disaster for a person with experience to make such a decision? Given the criticisms I made, which I think are justifiable , I think it is reasonable that the case for this very national project be reviewed. In doing so, the criticisms which I have made should be heeded, because quite obviously facts point to the possibility that this railway line could be viable.

Much money is being spent on the Darwin port now. A huge crane is being erected . Millions of dollars are being spent to upgrade the Darwin port. I see Darwin port developing into a strong trading link with other nations, particularly in South East Asia, with cargo containers overlanding to southern centres. By ' overlanding' I mean by a rail link that will go from Darwin through Alice Springs to Adelaide and then to Sydney, Melbourne or wherever the standard rail gauge operates. The development of the mining industry, in particular, the pastoral industry and the travel industry, will assist the railway immensely. Not to be forgotten too is the immense demand such a line would make on Australian industries. The defence of the north, which I have mentioned, is also not to be forgotten. This has not been permitted to influence the case for the line in this inquiry.

Summing up, I quite honestly believe that the review of this proposed national project has not been given a fair go. In the first place, the Prime Minister and others were quite obviously in favour of the project, without qualification. Times have changed. Now the Government has introduced various matters which qualify its opinion. It has conducted an inquiry which I say is incomplete and whose findings are not substantiated because the Government did not consult. It did not comply with its promises. The promise was clearly given that the inquirer was to consult with the people who made submissions to it, particularly the Governments of South Australia and the Northern Territory. This was not done , despite the fact that the authorities in South Australia and the Northern Territory were extremely able in presenting to the inquirer a substantial submission which indicated that in some circumstances the line would be viable. Construction of the line would develop industries which would ultimately make the line viable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At long last, on the third day after the resumption of the sittings, we are beginning to discuss something substantive and not engaging in the muck-raking which has been part of the strategy of the Opposition in the first three days of the Parliament , both in Question Time and in debating matters of public importance. However, I think it has to be conceded, without in any way being derogatory about the needs of the Northern Territory, that the issue that Senator Kilgariff and the Opposition have chosen to debate today would hardly excite the imagination of the great majority of Australian people, given the problems that beset them.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, the Government accepts that in the Northern Territory there is concern about transport problems and the railway link. However, I make it very clear from the outset that when in opposition the Australian Labor Party made the promise to construct the railway it did so in absolutely good faith and without knowledge of the disastrous state of the economy brought about by the Treasurer and Prime Minister of Australia in the latter part of 1982 and the deficit of something like $10 billion. That was the state of the Treasury when we inherited government a year ago. Of course we recall that it was part of the conventional wisdom of both the Opposition and the Government that each pledged to construct the railway.

However, I make it very clear that the posturing of Senator Kilgariff has no substance because the Government has not, in fact, repudiated its election commitment. It has sought only to indicate to the Northern Territory Government that there needs to be a financial arrangement which is satisfactory from the point of view of the Commonwealth. Having inherited such a disastrous budgetary situation, it would be incompetent as well as immoral for a government to continue the spending program that was obviously set in train by the Fraser Administration. Of course this Government has set about creating a political, economic and consumer climate that will enable it to fulfil its election promises. Obviously it cannot do that in the first few months in which it is obliged to bring down a budget, bearing in mind that the Parliament began to meet only in the latter part of autumn of last year, and that the Government was confronted with a deficit of a magnitude of which it was not aware and the knowledge of which the previous Government withheld even from its own Cabinet. The information about the extent of the deficit was known only by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. They deliberately kept it from the Australian people, from their Government and from the Opposition. Yet Senator Kilgariff suggests that the Labor Government is dishonouring an election promise. Heavens above, if we are to talk about governments dishonouring election promises, one characteristic of the Fraser Administration was that the average Australian knew that it was blessed with broken promises and failed to honour its election commitments.

Let us remember what it was like in 1980 when Mr Fraser went to the polls and received substantial support from the Australian people. He said that we were on the verge of $25 billion-worth of development, that there was to be an end of inflation, that interest rates were to be reduced, that there was to be a reduction in unemployment and that we were on the eve of a great new wave of development that would set Australia on the path of progress. Of course, we know that that was all hogwash and that the Australian people were being deceived by the Fraser-Anthony Government. If we really look at the substance of this matter of public importance we see that it should read:

The political manoeuvrings of the Opposition to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.

What a shabby record the previous Government had with respect to this project for which Senator Kilgariff suggests this Government is capable of being censured and criticised. The Liberal-National Party has been in office for 30 post-war years. Where was the progress in respect of this railway? Not one sleeper was laid and not one mile of railway network was constructed. In the brief months of the Whitlam Labor Government the Alice Springs-Tarcoola railway was begun and has now been completed-the link in the chain that made the Alice Springs-Darwin rail link a possibility. That is what was achieved by the last Labor Government.

What did the Fraser Government do when it came to office in 1976? Instead of building a railway line in the Northern Territory it closed down the only line there from Darwin to Larrimah, some 500 kilometres, throwing 200 employees out of work. Yet the Opposition Whip from the Northern Territory has the audacity to suggest that this Government, barely a year in office, should be criticised in respect of its obligation to improve the transport situation in the Northern Territory. Of course, the line which was closed by the Fraser Government could have been the first stage of a link south to Alice Springs. Senator Kilgariff should have been aware that in 1980 the Fraser Government promised $10m for survey and design work on the Alice Springs-Darwin connection. Yet by the time the election came around in 1983 that amount was underspent by half. What did the Hawke Government do? With the support of the Minister for Transport, the Hon . Peter Morris, Labor in its first year of office has appropriated for the connection of this line as much as the Fraser Government spent in the previous seven years, that is, $5m to be spent in 1983-84 to complete the preliminary planning and design of the project. That is proceeding while we have this time- wasting exercise by the Opposition Whip.

The Labor Government has released for public comment the draft environmental impact statement on the project and has finalised the environmental impact statement, proving again that we have not repudiated our election promise but have in fact set in train a proper inquiry, an essential prerequisite to a responsible and competent way in which to carry out this election commitment. We did all this in spite of the dramatic $10 billion deficit we were confronted with when we came to office. That hidden deficit would have necessitated any government of any standard and of any competency in this country or in the world to re-examine its financial commitments. We did that. Of course, as you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, we also set in train in the last Budget legislation designed to overcome the difficulties in the welfare areas to get rid of those who were abusing the system and collecting large sums of money, something like $400m per annum, out of the Commonwealth Treasury, as a result of which we introduced the assets test. So a government began, for the first time in the last decade, to put into place a responsible attitude to public sector expenditure.

In view of the large amount of capital cost involved in the railway, we had to modify our commitment in the interests of responsible economic management. We offered to proceed on the basis of shared funding with the Northern Territory. That has been the way in which all governments prior to and since Federation have acted with respect to the construction of railway systems throughout Australia. What did we say to the Northern Territory Government? Despite the deficit of great magnitude that we inherited, we told the Northern Territory Government that we would still contribute 60 per cent but that the Northern Territory Government would have to provide the other 40 per cent of the construction costs. We made alternative offers to the Northern Territory Government, including offers to upgrade the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin and to upgrade the Alice Springs railway facilities to give a high standard road-rail link between Adelaide and Darwin by 1987. But the Northern Territory Government, being in a position to be difficult, rejected those alternatives.

We make no apologies to the Australian and Northern Territory people. We have acted responsibly in the light of that unprecedented $10 billion deficit. No doubt the Fraser Government, confronted with exactly the same economic criteria that the Hawke Government was confronted with, would have had to recast its public works commitments. It would have had to delay, repudiate or in some way seek other means to finance this railway. It ill behoves a senator of the standing of Senator Kilgariff to suggest that the Government was being irresponsible when it put forward alternative propositions for the way in which the railway should be financed.

Or course, Mr Everingham can claim, and has claimed, that it would be unreasonable for the Northern Territory Government to contribute towards the Alice Springs-Darwin railway as State/Territory contributions have not been required for major capital works programs, but many precedents for State government contributions to major national construction projects already exist. South Australia was required to pay 30 per cent of the cost of the railway standardisation works within that State. Western Australia constructed the Western Australian section of the trans-Australia railway and later contributed hundreds of millions of dollars towards upgrading and standardisation work on the line. Between 1963-64 and 1979-80 under Liberal-Country Party governments, the Commonwealth Government joined with State governments to construct some 17 dams and irrigation projects, all partly funded by State contributions. So there is ample precedent for the Commonwealth to seek a Northern Territory contribution to the railway. In fact there is no railway system network in this country run by State governments which States do not have to heavily subsidise.

Mr Everingham's criticism falls flat on its face. It has no basis and no substance. As a government which claims the right to represent the Northern Territory and wants to be recognised as an independent State government, the Northern Territory Government should be prepared to get in the queue like any other State instrumentality. The Federal Government was left with no option but to proceed to conduct an independent economic inquiry to settle once and for all the issues of the economic and social merits of the project-only because of the extent of the deficit-and to examine the most cost-effective means of providing high-standard all-weather transport services in and to the Northern Territory. It established the inquiry. I remind Senator Kilgariff that it did so with the endorsement of the Northern Territory Chief Minister, who agreed to the terms of reference, agreed to the appointment of Mr David Hill, agreed to the report being the basis for decision on the future of the project, insisted on the exclusion of shipping services from the terms of reference, and insisted that the Stuart Highway should not be upgraded. Yet Senator Kilgariff has the audacity to suggest that Mr Hill has acted somewhat improperly. He is a man who has held high office in the State Rail Authority of New South Wales for only a short duration, having regard to the railway system itself operating for more than 150 years, and he has a record that can be compared with any other public administrator in Australia, in that he has substantially reduced the losses incurred in that particular instrumentality. The Government rejects completely the attacks upon Mr Hill, who had the endorsement of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on both his selection and the terms of reference that he carried out on behalf of the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Governments .

The Hill report, as later speakers will elaborate, has clearly demonstrated that there is no economic justification for the railway. That has not led to the Government withdrawing its offer. The Government is still in the field with its offer. But it has pointed out the economic difficulties that both the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory would face, on the basis of the Hill report. What did the report say? It said that 130 trucks and 20 buses could perform the proposed rail link's transport tasks into the next century. That is what was found as a result of the inquiry. I say to Senator Kilgariff that the Northern Territory and the South Australian governments were consulted; make no bones about that. There is no criticism about the inquiry that was carried on, the scope of it and the fundamental way in which the Commissioner carried out his task. Using the best, but questionable, economic projections provided to the inquiry by the Northern Territory Government, he came to that conclusion. That Government provided him with the criteria on which he made his objective judgment. It showed that the projected cost of the railway would represent a unit cost of $5m for each truck and bus used. The Hill report shows a cost to the Australian taxpayer of $1 billion by the year 2000, so that for that capital outlay we would get 1,000 jobs. That is a unit cost of $1m per job, and that is very expensive job creation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $1 billion figure is wrong.

—Well, 20 times fewer jobs than alternative expenditure on roads, which is the way in which any responsible government would deal with this matter. I would have been interested to hear what Opposition senators would have had to say as to how their government, if it had, disastrously, won the election in 1983, would have handled the problem of the deficit which was hidden from the Australian people and how it would have been able to finance this project. One has only a certain sum of money that comes in from taxation and other charges, and one cannot spend it in any other way than that for which we have provided in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Northern Territory Government is serious about building the railway, and if it is not using this matter, as Senator Kilgariff is, for cheap political point-scoring, why is it not progressing the Queensland offer to build the Mount Isa-Alice-Darwin link? When I was in Queensland I heard a great deal about the offer that was made by the Queensland Premier. On 14 July last, in the run-up to the Queensland and Northern Territory elections, the Chief Minister and the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, announced a joint feasibility study to build a rail link between Mt Isa, Tennant Creek, Darwin and Alice. That Press conference was also attended by the South Australian Opposition leader, Mr Olsen. Mr Everingham said that the Queensland Government had indicated that it would pay for the 1, 600 kilometre line and that that would cost $600m to $700m. The Queensland Premier said that the project could be funded by long term loans serviced by freight revenue between Queensland and the Northern Territory. Of course, the Press conference, like so many of the things that happen in politics with the conservative forces in Australia, was just another political stunt, the same sort of political stunt that was pulled by Mr Fraser in 1980, and a blatant political manoeuvre by Mr Everingham and Mr Bjelke-Petersen which, unfortunately , had the effect of influencing the voters in those two States to give them another mandate.

Where is that study, Senator Kilgariff? Where is that railway, Senator Kilgariff? Why is it that the Chief Minister is not chasing the Premier of Queensland to honour that particular joint agreement, which occurred before the Budget of the first year of the Labor Government? Perhaps the previous commitment is as inviolate as his promise of $1 billion worth of rail electrification projects in central Queensland. So we see the fraud and the political manoeuvering of the Chief Minister, and the detrimental impact of his machinations on the people of the Territory is exemplified by his stand on the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Mr Everingham tells the Federal Government that the road does not need upgrading. Is that Senator Kilgariff's view? We hear nothing about that from the honourable senator, but he tells the Territorians that the Federal Government is not spending enought money in the Territory.

We reject the inane and mischievous meanderings of Senator Kilgariff. They are clearly just an attempt, on behalf of the Opposition, to suggest that somehow or other the Opposition is interested in the needs of the people of the Territory or the needs of Australia. Opposition members have been shown up by the bankruptcies since they have lost one after another of their leaders-the Frasers , the Sneddens, the Killens, the Lynches and the Streets, and all of the others who were responsible for the state of the economy in the period 1976-1983. They have departed from the Australian Parliament and left the Hawke Government to rebuild from the failures and decay of that Administration led by the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that we are discussing today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The political manoeuverings of the Government to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.

Contrary to something said by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), I do not believe that discussing this matter is a waste of time. Without wishing to set any sort of precedent, I should like to congratulate Senator Kilgariff, whose persistence on this matter, if on no other matter, has been legend in this place through all governments from all political parties.

The Australian Democrats have always supported the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. There is no doubt that its completion is long overdue and that the failure to link the Northern Territory by rail fully with the rest of Australia under all sorts of weather conditions is of considerable disadvantage to the country as a whole but, of course, to the Northern Territory in particular. The detriment to Australia because of the lack of this section of railway being completed is evident in a number of areas-social, economic, defence, and so on. Our access to remote areas is considerably less than it would have been if that access had been made available to us through the completion of that rail link. Fuel costs, employment opportunities and so on should be taken into account when we look at the value to the country generally and the Northern Territory in particular of the completion of this section of Australia's national railway lines.

The construction of the link has been discussed for so long that it would appear as though some sections of Australian National Railways and the public actually believe that it is finished. This came to my attention a week or so ago in an inquiry which came into my office regarding an elderly lady who lives in Sydney who went to the Australian National office there, or an Australian National office-I do not know how many offices it has there-and asked for a ticket from Sydney to Darwin by rail. She was furnished with a ticket that stated 'Sydney to Darwin', and she found out only when she got to Alice Springs that she was not able to proceed any further by rail or for the cost of the ticket with which she was issued. After some carry on, she was placed on a bus, and I gather that she finished up in Darwin but certainly not by the mode of travel for which she had asked or which the ticket had indicated that she would get. I find this a rather extraordinary situation. I could have understood it if the lady had said--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit like the 1,400 staff who were employed for the assets test.

—Indeed, yes. It was a bit of a bungle, as they say. I could have understood it if she had asked for a ticket from Sydney to Darwin and the ticket had been printed Sydney to Alice Springs. But as I understand it the ticket was actually printed Sydney to Darwin, so somebody in Australian National in Sydney believes that that rail link has been completed. This lady was just one of the many people who wanted to be able to take a train trip from one capital city in this country to Darwin without having to leap on and off trains or buses, in and out of cars or on and off aeroplanes or anything else. I think it is a scandal that she and others are not able to do this. The scandal, of course, rests as much in the pocket of the previous Liberal government as it rests in the pocket of the current Australian Labor Party Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that rail travel in Australia has many advantages as far as tourism is concerned. It offers high density group travel, although that seems to be something that Australian National is discouraging, if the complaints that come into my office from people who have booked from Adelaide to Alice Springs are any indication. I am frequently informed that people are told that the train is booked and then find out at a later date, too late to do anything about it, that in fact it was not booked. I rather suspect that this is some kind of cunning lurk by Australian National to cut down the number of staff and therefore cut back its costs, because I understand that it is running rather close to the financial bone. Notwithstanding that, train travel, theoretically at least, offers the opportunity for high density group travel. It also, of course, offers flexibility for multi-mode travel, which is taken full advantage of overseas and should be taken full advantage of here. I refer to the fly-rail or the car-on-rail type of trip. It would certainly make full value of Darwin as an entrance point for overseas tourists if we had not only air and bus access but also direct rail access to other parts of Australia.

As far as the tourist dollar alone is concerned, the completion of the railway, notwithstanding comments made in the report of the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, could be of substantial economic benefit to both the Northern Territory and Australia as a whole. Other economic advantages would accrue simply from the building of the line via the employment prospects, use of resources and ancilliary or secondary business benefits in local areas. For example, I understand that since the completion of the Tarcoola-Alice Springs rail line freight trade has doubled. Furthermore, it is estimated that something like 150,000 tonnes of steel would be required. That, would be of considerable interest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, since you, like me, are South Australian and very much concerned with the problems that South Australia is facing through unemployment, particularly in some of its northern cities. That 150,000 tonnes of steel would represent approximately 20 per cent of Whyalla's plant production during the life of the project. That would provide no small boost to South Australia's economy. Had the scheme been initiated already the Iron Triangle lay-offs could very well have been avoided.

Another important consideration, to which I alluded briefly when I mentioned Darwin being better used as an entrance point for overseas tourists, is its potential for the development of Australia's trade links-not just its tourist links-with South-East Asia, not only the Northern Territory's mineral and pastoral industries but also for the major industries in the southern and south- eastern States of Australia. Certainly, long term viability of Northern Territory industry, especially its agricultural and horticultural industries, would be more likely.

Furthermore, I believe that the isolation of the Top End of Australia calls for the provision of a secure transport link that is not subject to the vicissitudes of petrol or fuel supplies or the weather, as is road access. Flash floods and so on have a quite drastic effect on the Northern Territory's economy and on ease of transport and so on between the Territory and other parts of Australia. Certainly, railways are not as affected by that sort of thing as roads are. Darwin needs and deserves a reliable social, economic and defence link with the rest of Australia, as well as with Katherine, Tennant Creek and Alice Springs. This acknowledgment of the need for social objectives to be taken into account when designing transport services and systems is, as I understand it, part of Australian Labor Party policy. Certainly it is part of the Australian Democrats' policy, as is a commitment to provide full services to people in isolated areas. These people suffer enough from increased costs and so on because they choose to live in those sorts of areas, and they do not need another problem that could readily be rectified if governments of all political pursuasions were prepared to put their money where their electoral mouths are. Furthermore, again despite the Hill report, a South Australian report indicates that something like $20m per annum could be saved in fuel costs alone at current fuel prices if only the rail link were completed.

I mentioned a moment ago the need for defence connections and security for the Northern Territory. It is not just in recent years that the defence of north- western Australia has been seen as vitally important to the defence of the rest of this country. We have, however, created a reserve unit of battalion size and another reserve unit is being raised in the Pilbara region. In order to shift and maintain a viable force in the north-west, as anywhere else, we will need to use all transport systems available. For instance, the maintenance of a division under battle conditions requires some 400 to 500 tonnes of material per day by the way of fuel, food, ammunition and spare parts. A railway would be of invaluable assistance both in shifting a viable force quickly into the area and in subsequently maintaining a substantial and fully equipped force. I understand that defence experts have said on-land railways are the only really effective way of transporting large numbers of men and material.

Notwithstanding the fact that previous Liberal Governments have done nothing whatsoever to honour their promises to fund and complete the Darwin-Alice Springs railway-members of the Liberal Party are, of course, past masters of the art of political manoeuvring to get out of fulfilling their promises-this Government stands condemned not only for not fulfilling its promises but also for using a not terribly objective report to justify its inaction. That report, by the way, did not have defence services and requirements as part of its terms of reference. It further stands condemned for using that report to justify the fact that it continues to disadvantage not only the people of the Northern Territory but also steel works employees in Whyalla, tourists across the country and the population of Australia as a whole. Contrary to the Hill Inquiry's findings, the Australian Democrats believe that the construction of the rail line is economically justifiable and is a matter of considerable urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today debating the following matter of considerable importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The political manoeuvrings of the Government to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.

I stress the critical words 'political manoeuvrings'-that is what the Government has engaged in and will show that-and 'consequent denial to Australia of the advantages' that would follow from the construction of the railway. I do not often quote Australian Labor Party politicans but I shall commence my remarks on this occasion by quoting the Deputy Premier of South Australia, the Honourable Jack Wright who, at a meeting in Adelaide in August last year, said:

There is no doubt in my mind, and in the minds of the State Government that the completion of a rail line connecting the northern and southern borders of Australia will be of enormous benefit to our State, and to the nation as a whole .
For the benefit of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who is in the chamber, I repeat:
. . . will be of enormous benefit to our State, and to the nation as a whole.
Those are the words of the Labor Deputy Premier of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure he believes them.

—As Senator Teague has said, I am sure he believes them. He is a very genuine old school, no promises broken, Labor politician. In pointing to the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government in ensuring the completion of the project the Deputy Premier noted further:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The Federal Government has an historical and legislative responsibility to the project, and its funding. Federal financing of national assets is in the interests of all Australians, for reasons that cannot be put into economic arguments.

Since 1911 the unfulfilled promise to provide a rail link from the north to the south of this continent has perpetuated the isolation of northern Australia. The neglected promise was to be finally honoured when, in 1981, the Fraser Government announced a $545m program for the construction of a 1,470 kilometre rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin. The completion of this project by the end of this decade, together with the completion of the Stuart Highway, would have meant that Australia finally had a rail and highway network linking the major population and development centres of this nation. Although obviously little pride can be attached to a 70-year delay in fulfilling a national commitment, it was not surprising that the Fraser Government's decision to proceed with the construction of the rail link was applauded for its vision. Moreover, in the early months of this Government's tenure and, following the promises that it made at the election, to which Senator Kilgariff referred earlier, it appeared that the rhetoric of 'bringing Australia together' was to have a worthwhile, practical application. As I said, in both the election campaign and following the election, the Government assured Australians that the construction of the rail link would proceed. No provisos were attached to these assurances.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—I will quote what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, representing the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) said. I remind the Senate that on 22 April last year the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is the Government's intention to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway as part of its long-standing commitment to the completion of an all- weather standard gauge connection between Adelaide and Darwin.

That appears to me to be quite unambiguous and quite clear. It was the Government's intention to construct a railway. I remind the Senate that the Minister made this statement on 22 April. The defence that we have heard from the Minister today-I thought it was a disappointingly negative speech from a disappointingly negative government-was that the Government found that, because of the size of the deficit, it would not be able to proceed. But we heard about the size of the deficit as soon as this Government came to office. Some time later, towards the end of April, the Minister gave an unequivocal undertaking that the project would proceed. Since then we have seen a steady retreat by the Government from its promise to complete the line. Unfortunately, the national vision has now been dissipated and expediency has displaced statesmanship. All Australia will suffer. The construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway is a national responsibility as was the Snowy Mountains scheme and as is the national highways system.

Honourable senators will recall that, in the May economic statement last year, this Government, in abdicating its national responsibilities, demanded from the Northern Territory a contribution of 40 per cent or $200m for the completion of the railway link-an amount patently beyond the financial capabilities of the Territory. I remind the Senate that Western Australia was not required to provide a specific financial contribution to the building of the transcontinental. It was misleading of the Minister today, when he referred to the maintenance and upkeep of the railway line, to indicate a position different from a national responsibility in relation to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line. We would all concede that maintenance upkeep is an entirely different matter.

It would now appear that the Government has found for itself the final nails to place in the Alice Springs to Darwin railway coffin-the report of the Independent Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory by the Chief Executive of the New South Wales Rail Authority, Mr David Hill. Although the Government claims to be awaiting a defence assessment I am sure that my colleagues have little doubt that this is simply going through the motions. The Government made its decision back in May when it set terms upon the Northern Territory Government that it knew the Northern Territory Government would be unable to meet. I do not wish to dwell on the Hill report because economically it is another assessment; one of the many fors and againsts which have been made over the years. But I remind the Senate of one paragraph in the report which states:

A major factor that could alter this assessment of the railway in the future would be the emergence of significantly higher tonnages of bulk minerals than is currently evident. The mineral prospects would need to be definite before the economic assessment of the railway would be altered.

That shows the limited value of such inquiries. It shows that the responsibility of government can never be abdicated to inquiries. The Northern Territory Government made clear in its submission that the economic development of many of the potential mineral areas is dependent upon the decision to build the railway or its actual completion. That is why there is a need for a national government to have national vision. It should see the transport infrastructure as a prerequisite to the development of economic potential.

But the Hill report is just what this Government wanted. It will now say that it cannot possibly proceed when Hill says that the present project cannot be justified. Will this Government recognise that Hill differs notably from the Northern Territory and South Australian Government conclusions and attempt to analyse the differences? Of course not! The Government now has exactly what it wants. Rather the Government will accept the report and, therefore, abandon a vital infrastructure project at a cost to all Australians, in particular, at a cost to employment and investment opportunities within South Australia and the Northern Territory.

In the limited time available to me, I want to look further at the cost to the nation of abandoning this project. Let us reflect upon the direct employment in the construction and establishment of the link. The Northern Territory Department of Transport has estimated that 1,200 jobs would be involved in the construction project. Let us reflect upon the employment generated from associated development-the downstream supply of material for the construction, tourism, freight, et cetera. Let us reflect also upon the employment necessary to operate and maintain the railway. Let us look, for example, at the effect upon South Australia's Iron Triangle which no one would doubt has been experiencing depressed economic activity in recent times. The project would require 150,000 tonnes of rail over five years. For the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd in Whyalla the contracts for the provision of this material would be worth $124m , employing 50 people per year. Port Pirie, with the largest lead smelting plant in the world, would be the logical destination for 130,000 tonnes of Macarthur River lead by the year 2000. Three proposed mining operations in the Northern Territory will produce lead-silver concentrates which would find their way to Port Pirie for processing. Port Augusta, with its existing rail shunting yards would be where the north-south and the east-west traffic met with consequent capital spending and through traffic spending.

Perhaps even more important is the incalculable number of jobs created by the further economic expansion which might be made possible by the existence of the railway; factors such as the effects of a significant reduction in transport costs from South Australia. For example, Adelaide Brighton Cement Ltd estimates that the railway would allow it to supply the Northern Territory with 60,000 tonnes of quick lime and limestone which is currently imported. That raises the land-bridge concept, the argument that the railway will allow the replacement of goods currently imported into the Northern Territory with goods produced in southern Australia-that interests me-and will facilitate exports to South East Asia. It has been estimated that it could cut 14 days off the transport of some goods. The South Australian citrus fruit growers have indicated that over 20,000 tonnes of additional citrus products could be exported to the Northern Territory and overseas if the rail link were to be completed.

Let us consider also the new opportunities for pastoral and mining developments along the transport route prohibited now because of the lack of suitable transport. About 55,000 live cattle are transported to South Australia from the Northern Territory each year. It is estimated that that volume could double if the line were completed. On mining, a major report of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy refers to a possible 12 new mineral projects that will be developed in the next five to 15 years, at least four of which are almost entirely dependent on the existence and completion of the Alice Springs- Darwin railway. In the other direction is the possibility of coal being railed from South Australia to Darwin for power production. I remind the Senate that 66 per cent of the imports into the Territory are in the form of mineral fuels.

Let us look at tourism very briefly. The estimates of passengers that would travel on the new line have ranged up to 60,000 per year. It is a railway link that could become part of the great train journeys of the world. It is worth remembering that on the Ghan, after the completion of the standard gauge line in November 1980, patronage increased by 176 per cent. For those honourable senators interested in employment, it is estimated that the staff would increase by one for every nine passengers on each trip. The list of opportunities is practically endless.

Let me end on the national perspective. This Government promised the construction of a valuable national asset. To us it seems obvious that it is in the best interest of Australia's national development that there is an adequate transport infrastructure. The growth of the Northern Territory and the benefits to South Australian industry translate directly to benefits which Australia, as a whole, shares. Let us not forget the national advantages of fuel efficiency of rail as compared with road transport. Even so, let us not fall into the trap of trying to assess national infrastructure provision on the same strict criteria of commercial projects. As stated in the South Australian paper to the Hill Inquiry, many economic and social benefits are, at times, intangible but include items such as economic development, community and business confidence, defence and the opportunity for trade that are all dependent on the provision of a complete transport system in Australia. It is time this Government showed the vision of its predecessor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making my contribution to the debate I would like to make a couple of comments about some of the arguments raised by the three previous speakers. Senator Kilgariff complained about the lack of consultation between South Australia, the Northern Territory and the Federal Government. Let me remind Senator Kilgariff that the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory has presented its report the Government. The final part of the review will be completed when the defence review is completed, which will be done shortly. At that time, as indicated quite clearly by the statement, the South Australian and Northern Territory governments will be consulted and the final decision will then be made .

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make the point here that the three previous speakers have suggested that a decision has been made in this matter. There might be some clear indications but no decision has yet been made. Senator Kilgariff commented on freight estimates. Let me remind Senator Kilgariff that the Northern Territory Government's submission showed a projection of these high growth rates for freight would reflect continuous and uninterrupted boom conditions in the Territory for the next 50 years. The Australian National Railways Commission believes, and I believe any normal person would believe, these figures would be too high. We are not likely to have continuous and uninterrupted boom conditions for the next 50 years.

Senator Haines suggested that the link was desirable between north and south. Of course, we agree with this. It is a commitment of this Government that an all -weather connection will be made. She talked about Australian National ticketing and moving somebody from Sydney to Darwin. I remind her that in this area former Senator McLaren and I were very anxious, when he was a member of this place, to make sure that Australian National did try to fill up its trains and not use the device of saying that all tickets had been sold to avoid putting on extra staff. Steel production in South Australia has been taken into account in the report. Let me remind the Senate that 2.5 per cent of the total annual output of South Australia would be involved; in other words, about 35 jobs. The Australian Democrats believe that the line should proceed regardless of what the inquiry has said. I think that that indicates the depth to which the Democrats have subjected the inquiry and the whole proposition.

I agree with Senator Hill entirely that it is a great pity that Mr Fraser did not go ahead with his proposition to build the railway. We agree with this. It is a great pity, but given the record of the previous Government it is not at all surprising. Again, Senator Hill talks about steel production in South Australia. I remind him that 35 jobs are involved. We would like to see those filled, but the high cost of creating those jobs is the relevant point in the debate. Senator Hill also talked about the incalculable number of jobs that would be created. With the greatest of respect, as our friend Senator Chipp would say, what a ridiculous statement to make. The jobs can be calculated, they have been calculated and they have been costed. So it is not a matter of incalculable jobs at all. I suggest that the honourable senator read the report and have a good look at it.

Moving to my comments on the report, there are three elements to this matter of public importance which have been put forward by Senator Kilgariff. They seem to be, firstly, political manoeuvrings of the Government; secondly, an election undertaking; and, thirdly, a consequent denial of advantages. These are the three elements in the propositions which have been raised by the Opposition today. I am assuming that Senator Kilgariff is speaking for his Northern Territory colleagues and the Northern Territory Government. There is a good relationship between the worthy senator and his colleagues in the Northern Territory-this is to be expected-and a good deal of material flows back and forth between the Chief Minister and Senator Kilgariff, as indicated by the presentation today.

I remind honourable senators that we are referring here to the Northern Territory Government, the government led by Mr Everingham, the leader of the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory. This is the man who called an election in December of last year.
