He went to the people and said that he wanted to govern the Northern Territory for the next four years and put forward a great proposition that he would bring forth and that he was the man for the job. He announced in February 1984 that he would be the candidate for pre-selection and would come down to the House of Representatives. Mind you, that was not the first proposition. Some two weeks before he had indicated on a talk back program that he was going to come down to the Senate. Because of his great standing in the community, the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party would win two Senate seats and when the candidates came here they would take control of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about telling us about the railway?

—I am as close to it as the honourable senator was, even in what I am saying. Let us look at the three aspects of this matter of public importance. Firstly, political manoeuvring. I am surprised that the honourable senator who proposed the matter of public importance used this term in a derogatory way because members of the Northern Territory Government are past masters at political manoeuvring. Ministers swap portfolios so that deals can be done. I can give an example of this with the purchase of some Crown land by one of the Northern Territory Ministers. I will not go into that matter. The Chief Minister manoeuvred the last election which was held last year on phony issues. He suggested that we must have an election because we are not being consulted. Then he shamefully exploited the Northern Territory electorate by calling on them to stand up for the Territory; by that he meant the Country Liberal Party. Nevertheless, because there was a short lead up to the election he closed the rolls early by political manoeuvring and that went through. People were swayed because they did not have the opportunity to see what was really behind his proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We might talk about the manoeuvrings on the extension of the town boundaries to thwart land claims. This is a matter of court action at present. We might talk about political manoeuvring on the politicisation of the Public Services contrary to all the principles of Public Service in Australia. I will not go into those matters. There are many more examples.

What do members of the Opposition mean by political manoeuvring? Do they mean that we should not have set up an inquiry, that we should have gone ahead to build the railway without looking at the cost and the implications? I do not think that would be the case. The Chief Minister in a letter to me recently when he rejected my plea that the Darwin primary school remain open for very good reasons said:
. . . You apparently advocate . . . the waste of scarce public money.

The suggestion is that he would not advocate this. He is saying, in a derogatory way, that what I am suggesting will cost money and he is not prepared to do it. Is the proposer of the matter of public importance suggesting that the Northern Territory contribute part of the cost? Is this the political manoeuvring that went on? Is this the action which he has called unprecedented? Yet, quite clearly it is not unprecedented, since Western Australia constructed the Western Australian section of the trans-Australian railway and later contributed hundreds of millions of dollars towards upgrading of standardisation works on the line. Again, in 1963-64 and in 1978-79 the Commonwealth Government joined State governments in constructing 17 dams and irrigation projects, all partly funded by State contributions. Certainly, the action is not unprecedented. It is a reasonable proposition.

The second part of the proposition put forward is that an election undertaking was given. I notice that the Opposition did not use the word promise. I suppose that anyone who sits on the other side of the House and remembers Fraser's record would be very careful about using the word promise. So the word ' understanding' was used. I remember the promises made by Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon. No doubt Senator Kilgariff also remembers those promises because they were made in Alice Springs. They said: 'We will build the railway'. I understand that one of the shadow Ministers also says that he will build the railway.

What undertaking was given? Early in the campaign, clearly following a request from the Northern Territory candidates, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he would build the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. It is part of our Northern Territory platform and it was based on our economic understanding of the situation. In the last week of the campaign-this is the point that I raised with Senator Hill by way of interjection earlier-there were rumours of a blowout in the deficit which the present Opposition knew about, which the discredited former Treasurer knew about, which the former Prime Minister knew about, but which we did not know about. In the final week of the campaign when rumours were circulating in the newspapers, Mr Hawke said that he would build the railway if the money were available. That statement was made on the Wednesday of the last week of the campaign. He introduced the qualification that Senator Hill denies. When we found out that the deficit was $4,000 billion more than we expected-I do not have to repeat the figure-the undertaking was given still to look at the project. That is why the Hill inquiry was set up. The decision was to be based on the result of the Hill inquiry and the defence aspect. We know the Opposition 's view about defence. As recently as 29 February this year in the other place the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) said:

It is always difficult to counter emotive arguments such as that, but it is interesting that nowhere else in any of the policy-making that goes on in this country has the likelihood of World War III been evoked as a serious reason for determining economic policy . . .

In other words the suggestion, as far as the Opposition is concerned, is that defence will not be a great consideration in this matter. Nevertheless, it was said that this aspect would be looked at. The third aspect of the proposition concerns the consequent denial of advantages to Australia. What are the advantages to Australia? The report of the Hill inquiry states:
For the projected traffic levels the total cost of transporting freight and passengers by rail exceeds the cost of accomplishing the same transport task by road by a large margin.

The implication is clearly that the traffic levels are not within the accepted margins that operate in New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria and other places where railways lose money. This point has been raised by Senator Kilgariff. Does the Opposition really want to see allocation of scarce resources to this project? The activity of the previous Government-represented by the honourable senators who sit opposite-during its 30 years in office clearly supplies the answer. Those honourable senators certainly do not want to see it done, they would not have done it themselves and if the decision is made not to proceed, they will not do it. It is clearly, as indicated by my colleague Senator Gietzelt, a cheap political exercise. This is the sort of exercise that is much favoured by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.

Let us look at the record in this area. Mr Everingham claimed that the railway was vital. He had funny little badges, flags and material printed-at taxpayers' expense, of course-to say that we should go ahead with this project and that the only way to do it was to re-elect the Country Liberal Party Government. He had a petition circulated which many people signed in very good faith because both parties in the Northern Territory wanted to see the railway constructed. It has been our policy for as long as I can remember. Mr Everingham agreed to the setting up of the Hill inquiry. He agreed that Mr Hill should be the person to conduct the inquiry. He did not like the findings, so he abused the umpire, apparently in the same way as did Senator Kilgariff today when he told only part of the story. He suggested that Mr Hill was a friend of the Wran Government. Another speaker said that the Hill inquiry brought down the sort of report that the Government wanted-suggesting in some way that there was some sort of collusion. With regard to shipping in the same area, we might recall that the Northern Territory was given a one-off payment by Fraser to subsidise the Australian National Line. It was then given another one-off payment by the Fraser Government. It was then given $2m by the present Government as a one-off final payment. That is three one-off final payments. Yet the Government of the Northern Territory still created more political mischief by creating a strike on the waterfront, by suggesting that more money ought to be coming from the Federal Government.

I turn to the proposal last year from the Queensland Government. Honourable senators will recall that concurrently with the run-up to the Queensland State election the Premier of Queensland and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory announced a joint feasibility study on a link between Mount Isa and Darwin. The Chief Minister said that Queensland would pay the full amount. What has happened? Where is the inquiry? Where is the railway? Why is the Chief Minister not castigating the Premier of Queensland for not building the railway from Mount Isa to Darwin, which he promised he would do, and which the Chief Minister said would go ahead? Perhaps the Premier's commitment to that project is about the same as his promise of $1 billion worth of rail electrification projects in central Queensland.

I regard the sorts of things that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has done as falling within the lines of being called fraud. They are certainly political manipulations. There is a detrimental impact of his machinations on the people of the Northern Territory. This is exemplified quite clearly by his stand on the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Honourable senators will recall that Mr Everingham told the Federal Government that the road did not need upgrading. After he said that, he returned to the Northern Territory and told Territorians that the Federal Government was withholding money for construction work on the Stuart Highway. All the time that he is doing this double dealing, he has $7m of road money sitting in the Territory piggy- bank, which he is using-or misusing-to build an unnecessary bypass road for one of his little projects.

I sum up by saying that, of course, we wanted to see the railway built. We worked hard to try to get it. But, unfortunately, rhetoric is not enough. What we must see in this country and what we have not seen for some years is responsible government, and that is what we are looking for. The reviews and the reports have indicated that the railway should not be built. The Government may make a decision not to do so. If it makes that decision, I am sure it will be with sincere regret on my part, on the part of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) and on the part of the rest of the Government. But let us make sure that we make the point that if the railway is not built it will be because it is not viable, economical, or the best use of the resources of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has been raised by the Opposition today in the Senate is set out as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The political manoeuvrings of the Government to avoid its election undertaking to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and the consequent denial to Australia of the advantages of the railway.

In the present stage of the Australian Labor Party Government's manoeuvrings on this matter, to recant from its election undertaking, we had presented before us only this week in the Senate the report of the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory. In this first week of sitting , South Australian and Northern Territory representatives are raising a matter which has unified that State and the Territory more than any other issue in recent times. I believe it is the key issue which led to the overwhelming success of the Northern Territory Government. Of course, positive virtues and policies were put by Mr Everingham and the Northern Territory Government in that election. But the people of the Northern Territory were alerted to Mr Everingham and the Country Liberal Party taking up this key development issue for their part of Australia. They overwhelmingly rejected the action of the Hawke Labor Government in its political manoeuvrings to deny its election commitment. In South Australia I do not know of one politician-let them stand up now if they want to deny it-whether from the Liberal Party, the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats or the National Party, who is not in favour of the Government presently committing itself to this project. The Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, is on record all through last year and again following the Hill inquiry as saying that this project must proceed. He is leading the Labor Party in lobbying for it. Not one Labor member of the South Australian Government is opposed to what Mr Bannon is doing.

Let any member of the Labor Party in the House of Representatives or the Senate deny that they support what Mr Bannon is doing. Even more vocally and, I believe with more credibility, the politicians representing the Liberal Party are outspoken in calling for this project to go ahead. It has unified all sides of politics in South Australia and the Northern Territory. That is perhaps with the exception only of Senator Robertson, though he did say at the beginning of his speech that the decision had yet to be made by the Hawke Government and there was still yet some hope that the Hawke Government-despite the findings of the inquiry it set up and the terms of reference given it-might decide to go ahead with the rail link. Even with the withdrawing, recanting, half-hearted series of excuses by Senator Robertson in his speech he still, in his heart of hearts, wants to see that railway go ahead. Why he does not more forthrightly represent the view of the people of the Northern Territory I do not know. I would be quite happy if the speeches today of Senator Robertson and Senator Kilgariff concerning this issue were circulated to every voter in the Northern Territory so they could make a clear comparison between who is best representing them.

I will now note something of the recent history of this matter. The Tarcoola to Alice Springs railway which excited so many people in South Australia and the Northern Territory was begun in 1975 and completed in 1980. At that time the inquiry into the viability of continuing the rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin was also completed and those recommendations were put before the Fraser Government. In 1980 the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, committed the Government to building the Alice Springs to Darwin link by 1990. On 14 January 1983 the same Prime Minister-again typifying the initiatives of the Liberal and National Country Parties-firmly announced that that program would go ahead and that the railway would be completed two years earlier in 1988 at a cost of $545m. It was not a vague promise. It was specific as to scope, timing and cost. In fact, it was so specific that during the election campaign of the next month Mr Morris the then shadow Minister for Transport and now the Minister for Transport said:
. . . at the 1980 election, Labor supported the construction of the remaining leg from Alice Springs to Darwin and that support continues.

But Senator Robertson said that lo and behold in arriving in office after the election these Ministers found there was a financial problem facing the country. That was despite the fact that on 15 March-after all the facts were known-Mr Morris told the Northern Territory Opposition leader, Bob Collins, that Labor's commitment to the railway was not simply a parochial one for the Territory but a project of national and international significance which the Labor Party would honour. Indeed in April 1983 Mr Morris again assured the Northern Territory Labor leader that preparations for the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin rail link were proceeding on schedule and that necessary legislation was being drafted and a Budget submission prepared for Cabinet. On 8 April 1983 Mr Morris announced that public meetings would be held at various places in the Northern Territory over the next week at which details of the rail link would be explained. However, around the middle of April we saw the political manoeuvrings of Hawke himself when he interfered with his Minister for Transport in the same way he had interfered with numerous other Ministers of his Government. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, took the initiative that led to the Keating Treasurer statement on 19 May, a month or so later.

The first whispers that the project was starting to be in doubt and that it was time for the ALP in the Northern Territory to try to rescue what was looking like going down the chute were heard on 26 April. By 3 May those whispers even reached in a very direct and tangible way the Leader of the Government in the Northern Territory. He saw that everything was up for grabs and immediately a telegram and writing campaign was instituted by the Northern Territory Government. Nevertheless on 19 May in the economic package announced by the Treasurer, Hawke's decision was announced to Australia. Of course that was that this very valuable project would be proceeded with but only on the basis that 60 per cent of the funds would come from the Federal government and 40 per cent from the Northern Territory. That 40 per cent of funds amounted to $216m. That $ 216m is equivalent to an extra tax on every resident in the Northern Territory of $20 a week for 50 years. Does the Government expect the Northern Territory Government to raise $20 from every resident every week for 50 years?

Moreover a fraud was involved in the 60 per cent national-40 per cent Territory so-called funding division. Not only was it impossible but also it did not take account of the $200m fiscal claw-back that followed in the economics of the project. The total cost, then estimated at $540m, would have resulted in $220m being paid by the Territory and $320m by the national government. In a number of items in terms of indirect tax on materials, income tax on the 2,000 jobs to be generated every year of the building of the project and through savings in various costs-these items have been carefully analysed by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry South Australia, Inc., and acknowledged by the South Australian Government-it was estimated that there would have been a $200m claw- back to the Federal Government during the expenditure of that $540m.

The inquirer, Mr Hill, fundamentally does not question that $540m construction cost. I know that the Northern Territory response to the Hill finding, which is in detail, finds all sorts of anomalies, lack of definition and imprecise methodology exhibited in the Hill report. But those criticisms will stand. Fundamentally Mr Hill in his inquiry did not disagree with an approximate $540m construction cost for the railway. However, he dismissed that claw-back of $200m by saying that although 2,000 jobs each year for every year of construction would be created of course they could be located in some other national project if the railway project did not go ahead. He said that that claw-back would therefore have come in some other way. Let it be taken in either mode, I do not mind. Let us understand the impact upon the Australian economy if such a commitment to this project was made and the claw-back resulted from the Northern Territory railway project. As I said, this was a fraud and the project would have meant that there was a net outlay of only $120m from the Federal Government compared with the $220m being demanded of the Northern Territory by the Hawke Government. It was impossible from the start and the Government knew it. That is what we mean by manoeuvrings. Instead of making a clear-cut decision that that railway would not be proceeded with and an honest answer being given to the people of Australia, there is this manoeuvring. But it did not work.

Mr Reeves, the House of Representatives member for the Northern Territory, said in his maiden speech in May 1983 that the rail link was the linchpin for the whole of the Territory's development. It was the most important project for the Territory. He still believes it and so do the great majority of people involved in the Northern Territory and South Australia, as would, I suspect, the majority of Australians generally if they studied the matter. Mr Reeves was not convinced and he continued to make loud noises. South Australian industry, immediately after the Keating statement, said that it would lose $200m in contracts if construction of the line was halted. The breakdown of that amount is clearly set out. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd immediately retrenched 1,400 steel workers. It knew that the project was under question, abandoned, and that there was no way it could retain that work force. However in late May the Opposition said that it would confirm its original commitment. Mr Peacock, the then Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Anthony, and our spokesman on transport, Mr Lusher, all made clear commitments that a future Liberal-National Party government would honour a commitment to fund the railway. A like commitment was made after the Hill report was brought down.

I turn to the South Australian Government. Mr Bannon's response was headlined in the newspapers: 'Now is time to start rail link-Bannon'. There is unanimity on all sides of the Parliament in South Australia. Jack Wright, the Deputy Premier, was the principal speaker at a conference of all parliamentarians convened in mid-August last year. There was not a whisper from any side of politics or from any side of industry in opposition to what I am saying. Even after the Hill report was presented Bannon and Everingham, as recently as the last fortnight, have been working together to overturn the Hawke Government's decision, to stop these political manoeuvrings and to maximise the advantages for Australia that are in the project. The advantages are clear. This side of the Parliament, which has the ability to summon a majority in the Senate, can embarrass this Government any time. I appeal to Ministers to act upon the speeches that have been made here today and, despite the pessimism of the Hill finding, go back to the evidence that was put by the South Australian and Northern Territory governments and Opposition spokesmen, and ensure that this vital national project goes ahead to the advantage of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was once said that history was a great teacher. If one listens to Opposition senators speak about railways one realises that they have learnt nothing from history, especially the history of this country. Our railways have never been organised and thought out economically. We have the worst transportation system in the world. For years we have had to put up with what was called politician lines-lines that went anywhere in this country. Never mind whether they were viable; they were put there to please certain constituents. That is no way to organise a transportation system. It is no wonder that our transportation is the dearest in the world. That is what we should be looking at. Is that any wonder when for many years this country was governed by the most inefficient of economic managers? We should reflect on that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that I and many other senators, and many people in this Parliament, want to see a railway line to the Northern Territory. But at times such as this, when we have to have economic restraint, we have to look at whether a project is economically viable. It would be irresponsible of any government not to do this. It would be madness at this time to build a line which has been proved by a thorough investigation by the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory to be uneconomic. It will be built in the future; we are not saying that it will never be built. However, at the moment we must look at where we can best spend that dollar. We must increase the number of people in the work force and get the economy moving. It would be totally irresponsible at this time to go ahead and spend the amount necessary for this project, which would be $1,000m to the year 2000. I do not think that expenditure is necessary.

If we were seriously looking at improving the transportation system in this country we would be building new lines in places other than where they are now. We would look at the economics and at where to build the lines. We should have feeder services into railway lines. We should upgrade and strengthen roads so that road transportation can feed into those areas. At this time we cannot spend huge amounts on uneconomical lines. If construction of an Alice Springs to Darwin railway line has been proved uneconomical it should be deferred. We have to be hard headed about it. As we know, the States built their railway lines on different gauges. Lines were built all over the country to suit political purposes. If we are responsible politicians who have learnt from the past we should be looking seriously at the possibility of building lines which will improve our transportation system, at reducing the cost of transportation. If we do not reduce the cost of transportation in this country we will not be able to compete economically with world trading markets. Building the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link is not the way to do it. It has been estimated by the Hill inquiry that by 1993 only 940,000 tonnes of freight will be carried on that line . It is estimated that to make the line viable it must carry three million tonnes. That is absolutely hopeless.

All Australians are paying too much taxation because of ill-conceived projects that have been uneconomical. I am sick and tired of putting up with those sorts of conditions. The Australian people have to foot the bills, but the attitude has been: Do not worry about that. We cannot get money from anyone but the Australian taxpayer. An upgrading of the Stuart Highway is justified. If a railway line would be uneconomical we have to upgrade the Stuart Highway and use road transport. That is the logical thing to do. If in future business in the Northern Territory increases-I hope it does; this Government will do everything within its power to see that it does-I will be the first person here to press for a rail line.

It cannot be said that the Fraser Government did a great job. When it built the line from Tarcoola to Alice Springs it used a second-grade, light line. It is a new railway, large sections of which have been built with light line. Trains have to reduce their speed to a little under 70 kilometres an hour. We should be building in this country lines that are capable of carrying trains travelling at over 100 kilometres an hour. That is where we fall down. The Fraser Government saved a little more than $1m on that line by putting in a second-hand light line . It spent $1m on parties, and that is the tragedy of what has been going on. Do not talk to me about economic management; I have seen too much of it.

Senator Kilgariff mentioned something about the Snowy Mountains scheme. He never mentioned who brought about the Snowy Mountains scheme. It was Ben Chifley . He said that there was criticism of that, but he did not say that it was Menzies who criticised it. He did not tell this Parliament that Menzies said it was the white elephant scheme. That is what was said. Let it not be said that the Australian Labor Party has not created schemes that have been of great benefit to this nation. We have. The Liberal Party has been very critical of us for doing that at times. The truth is that any scheme has to be economically viable. If it is not it cannot proceed.

Alternatives are available to us. We cannot build a railway at the moment, as I see it, because of the Hill report. We have to take notice of professional people. That is what has not happened in the past. I think it is outrageous. We have wasted billions of dollars in this country. We still have a poor transportation system. It is no good operating that way. It is no use State governments saying to Federal governments: 'We want this and we want that'. It is no use isolated towns saying: 'We want a railway to come to our town. Do not worry about the viability of it. Do not worry about the costing of it. Do not worry about what the taxpayers pay'. That is just no good. Yet that is how Federal and State governments have operated in the past. It is just not correct.

The Government offered the Northern Territory alternatives, yet no one has said anything about those. The Federal Government offered the Northern Territory Government a choice of 60:40 shared funding of the railway line or an accelerated upgrading of the Stuart Highway together with improved rail facilities in the Alice Springs area. The Northern Territory Government did not take up either of these options. As the situation now stands there will be discussions between the Federal Government, the South Australian Government and the Northern Territory Government. When the defence assessment becomes available -and it is not yet-the Federal Government will resolve its position on future funding for the railway. I think that is a sensible way to go about it.

During the war I saw the necessity for a railway from Adelaide to Darwin. I know that it is still necessary. We should be looking at it. It will be looked at. I hope that when the defence assessment is available the result will be beneficial. But the line has to be built on the basis of either economy or the defence needs of this nation. I think that our decision can be justified, at least to the Australian people who have to foot the bill. Governments have to be responsible. It is no use wasting money and carrying on as we have done in the past. The Queensland Government's submission, relative to the construction of a rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin concludes that:

. . . the development of the Barkly Highway, together with a rail link between Tennant Creek and Mt Isa, would give benefits to many more Australians. And these benefits could be acquired more economically and efficiently.

Development of the Central Corridor will severely disadvantage Queensland unless development of the Eastern Corridor is undertaken at the same time. Without the concurrent development of the Eastern Corridor, Queensland would need to seek compensation for the loss of trade and for the social and economic inequality generated by the preferential treatment given to the Northern Territory by the Commonwealth Government.
That has to be taken into consideration. It is no use people saying that a line can be built here and there and not doing their sums correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done them.

—The honourable senator should read and study correctly the Hill report. I assure him that to say what he has indicates that he has not read the report. That is the truth of it. It is no use attacking the Hill inquiry.
—You are attacking the South Australian Government.
—I am not attacking the South Australian Government or the Northern Territory Government. That is not my desire.
—But they have done their sums on this too.

—I assure the honourable senator that the 3m tonnes of freight which are necessary to make this line viable are simply not there. They will not be there by the year 2000. It is no use constructing a line that will forever be a drag on the Australian taxpayer, which is what it would be. There are other efficient ways of going about it. I think that we have to be efficient. We have played politics on it too much. That is the worst aspect of trying to create a reasonable transportation system in this country, which I think should be done. I think that we should be spending money on building railways, but perhaps not in that area if it is not required for defence purposes. We should be spending money on upgrading the whole transportation system. But there are several ways that we can go about doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is no use attacking the Hill inquiry. These attacks are totally unwarranted. The inquiry was carried out in a competent and very impartial manner. It was broadly based.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no it was not.
—Yes it was. It optimistically estimated all possible benefits to ensure that its results were beyond reproach.
—Only one man did it; not a committee.

—The inquiry received 110 written submissions. Members of the inquiry travelled the entire route of the proposed railway to ensure that they were thoroughly familiar with the project. It is all in the report. The inquiry was not just a one person thing. It received submissions from all governments. It received 110 submissions. If I remember correctly it took evidence from 19 of those who presented submissions. So a big study was done on this matter. It was not haphazardly done. Mr Hill has made great improvements to the New South Wales rail system. He has improved its viability. That is what we must look at. Politicians do not have the time. I also doubt whether we have the expertise. What else can we do but go to people such as Mr Hill and others to get that understanding and advice? That is what has not been done in the past. That is where we have gone wrong in regard to the railway system in this country. It would have been a great thing if Australia in its very early days had not relied on the six States all going their own way, building their own lines and not thinking of what was good for the nation. I am a South Australian and very proud of it. But I am also a member of Federal Parliament.
—You do not care about Queensland.

—Yes, I do; it is very important to me. I am an Australian but I have a great responsibility to my State. I will press for that line to go all the way. But as a Federal politician I have an overall responsibility to consider what is best for the whole of this nation. I think that is what we should be thinking about. One should be proud to be a South Australian but also proud to be an Australian. That is what we would be better off doing.

I draw attention to the importance of this chamber taking notice of steps taken to relocate anything, even something as small and perhaps unobtrusive as a guard box at the rear of Parliament House. I think we ought to show, if something is being done within the parliamentary zone, that we are taking notice of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about child minding facilities? Can we have a few child minding facilities?

—Child minding facilities come within provisions different from section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 which, for those who do not remember, is a memorial to former Senator Sir Reginald Wright who battled for quite some years to get that legislation passed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I read with interest the resolutions of the thirteenth meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council on 23 September. It was a most progressive meeting. I was aware of most of what had taken place prior to reading the report, but it was good to see the proceedings consolidated and to see how good a meeting it was. It also gives us the opportunity to realise that the fishing industry is not as healthy as it should be and that now, and only now, are we really finding the industry trying to do something about it. It is now better organised and is directing its decisions better towards effecting the changes necessary to rectify some of the problems. Regrettably, the fishing industry has been historically fragmented, not very well represented and seldom listened to. It now seems to be changed, and its attitude to the northern prawn fishery in particular is excellent. What has been done there and what is being endeavoured there are examples not only to other sections of the fishing industry but also to other industries. The industry's attitudes to the southern blue fin tuna fishery are improving. The fishermen and the industry generally have come to realise that unless they are prepared to do somthing about the situation themselves, and unless the various members of the industry agree to what is going on, it will not improve.

I turn to the south-eastern trawl fishery. Here again it is my opinion that the fishermen themselves are the people to decide what will be for the best. Regrettably, the south-eastern trawl fishermen, particularly those based in such ports as Eden and Ulladulla, have suffered from the industry's philosophy that, provided they are kept poor and barefoot, there will be no trouble with them. The situation has now gone beyond that and the costs of operating in these areas are now very high. The fishermen there have to work on the fact that they will now require, if they are to survive as a profitable industry, greater professionalism, a greater concentration on quality, improved merchandising and a reduction in the cost of effort.

One factor in particular in which I was disappointed was that out of the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account $120,000 was expended for the deficit in the publication of Australian Fisheries. This had previously been a charge against the normal running costs of the Department of Primary Industry and now it is taken out of the fishermen's own account. I draw attention to this particularly because the report states that the Council noted that this had to be done because:
(b) without the financial support of FIRTA the continuation of 'Australian Fisheries' was at grave risk as circulation had fallen drastically and advertising revenue was also declining.

All that demonstrates is that it was not being read or sufficiently used and was a loss operation; it was not competing with other publications on the open market. It is my opinion that this $120,000 would have done a lot more had it been used for the purpose for which it was originally intended, that is, research. Space might have been bought in one of the alternative publications which had better advertising, better circulation and was privately operated so that this expenditure would not become a drain on the fishermen's account. Had space been bought in other journals, at least $100,000 of this money would have gone to a better purpose. I am very disappointed at what has happened. There have been several discussions about the publication at Estimates committee meetings over the last few years. I have never received satisfactory answers to the questions I have raised. I am very disappointed that this publication is being bunged up with $120,000 of fishermen's money.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING AGREEMENTS BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF AUSTRALIA AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA AND VARIOUS COMMERCIAL ORGANISATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is important that we consider our responsibilities under the international law of the sea. It is equally important to look to our responsibilities to the livelihood of Australian fishermen, to conservation and to the reasonable management and exploitation of the resources in the seas around Australia. The various countries with whom we have, or have recently had, agreements are Japan, the Republic of China, the Republic of Korea and Thailand. It is important that these agreements are looked after and carried through in the spirit in which they were originally set up. Governments present and past have seen the Australianisation of the 200-mile zone as the most important thing to do, and I am very pleased that this is proceeding. There have been great benefits from these international relationships, and we have been able to get much better knowledge of what actually exists in those waters than we would ever have been able to obtain for ourselves. But having got that information, I must say that I am disappointed that not more Australian fishermen are out there taking advantage of it and assisting in the Australianisation.

None of the countries involved-Japan, the Republic of China, the Republic of Korea and Thailand-have any objection to seeing this become an Australianised fishery again, but it is difficult to get Australian fishermen to participate in these areas. We need Australian fishermen to take over more of the trawl fishing , the squid fishing and the tuna fishing. In this regard, as it is not happening as well as we would like and appreciating the benefits that would come to us and our current difficulties in some of the other fisheries around Australia, I believe it is imperative that we produce some encouragement and/or inducement that will help the surplus fishermen in other areas to take on a part of the fisheries that have been developed by fishermen of other countries. Fishing is still in quite a mess, and we need to redirect many of the fishermen into these new developing areas.

I have made it my business to be familiar with all of these foreign fishing ventures. Regrettably, there is a general lack of understanding of the very fundamental needs of the industry, especially the bi-national industry, with gum -ups that seem to happen too often in the bureaucratic process. I just do not think that enough people in the offices of the Department really have any understanding of the size of the industry with which they are involved, its nature, the money involved, the employment-whether ours or other people's-and the logistics of moving vessels about from the Northern Hemisphere to the Southern Hemisphere. There are times when I wonder what they are trying to achieve. The whole point of having agreements is that we ought to be trying to make them work. But some officers seem to get an enormous delight out of trying to make them difficult. A few weeks at sea in one of these small boats, working long hours in difficult conditions, would probably help some of these officers to gain a much more practical approach to an industry of which they do not seem to demonstrate a great understanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Archer, particularly in relation to the facilitation of the negotiation of agreements with foreign countries on the development and exploitation of our various marine resources where we do not have at the moment either the expertise or the equipment necessary for that. I have the feeling that whilst at times there have been officers who have gone out of their way to be helpful and to expedite matters as far as they could, there have been other instances in which there has seemed to be an enormous amount of bureaucratic inertia to be overcome before things got moving to the degree that they should have moved.

SPEECH.PARA: The fishing industry is an extremely important part of Australia's future. It is a very underdeveloped part of Australia's future. It is one which will require much goodwill on the part of all those involved to develop, using, as Senator Archer said, the information which can be gained for us by other nations under these agreements and made available to Australians who, I hope, will make a reality of the Australianisation of the exploitation of the 200-mile economic zone. That is not happening at present to the degree that one would have hoped. Obviously, one of the areas of activity will have to be the development of a system whereby, not only through opportunities such as the Australian Maritime College at Launceston but also through the opportunities presented by some of the bigger conglomerates that have now started operating in the fishing industry , there will be highly qualified people able to operate efficiently the much larger and much more expensive equipment which will be necessary for the full utilisation of the economic zone. We are starting to move. I support what has been said about the importance of continuing that movement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT SERVICES TO THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We have just been through a two-hour debate on this matter. I wish to have attached to this report a brief comment. I have had a chance to review Mr Hill's report in some detail. It appears to me and to the Northern Territory Government that the report is an attempt to rebut the case presented by the Northern Territory Government for the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin rail link. The Northern Territory Government forwarded to the inquiry a very comprehensive submission. It was one which gave a professional assessment of the economic and social effects of the railway and it should be viewed as an authoritative report on the project.

It is important to point out that all of the Northern Territory Government's forecasts for the railway were clearly stated and the methodology used to reach these forecasts was also clearly explained. By comparison, the many fundamental assumptions used by Mr Hill in reaching his recommendations are inadequately documented, making it difficult for an independent review of his findings to be undertaken. There are some obvious flaws in his report. In particular, the economic benefits of the rail link have been underestimated, while the economic costs have been overestimated. The report also fails to evaluate properly the social benefits that the rail link would bring to people throughout the Northern Territory. Also underestimated by Mr Hill were the substantial benefits that the link would bring to the railway network throughout Australia. Northern Territory Government studies have found that many traders prefer to use only one mode of freighting goods. Senator Haines, I think, mentioned this point earlier. If they can use rail from the loading point to the final destination, they will do so; if not, they are more likely to use another form of transport. If the rail link were constructed to complete a national rail system, use of rail for freight transport would increase throughout Australia.

It seems that the Hill inquiry has been used to free the Government from its election promises. If it had been a serious exercise, there would surely have been-I have said this previously-some form of consultation between the Federal Government, the South Australian Government and the Northern Territory Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a debate on the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, but I want directly to address the report that is before the Senate, the so-called 'Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory'. Senator Elstob placed a great deal upon the word ' independent' and on the fact that the Hawke Government had set up terms of reference for Mr Hill-one man; not a committee-to independently, so-called, evaluate the cases put by the South Australian Government, the Northern Territory Government and business interests in those areas and nationally, with the exclusion of defence matters. The Northern Territory Government and, for that matter, the South Australian Chamber of Commerce in the preparation of their cases, independently sought an economic analysis from the Department of Economics at the University of Queensland. That analysis found, for instance, that 2,000 jobs per year over six years would be generated by the construction phase of the project. However, Mr Hill, another independent inquirer, estimates that 1,000 jobs would be determined. It is scandalous if we receive just the newspaper headlines from such a massive report. We need carefully to compare like with like and to understand the restrictions that this inquirer had from his terms of reference and his methodology.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not taking to task the particular methodology of Mr Hill. I am saying that for members of this Senate, and especially for Ministers, to evaluate the findings of this inquiry, they need to understand its methodology, its terms of reference, and the scope that Mr Hill chose. He may well be independent; I do not know whether, as my colleague Senator Kilgariff said, he is a friend of Mr Wran and Mr Hawke and was the Chief Executive of the New South Wales State railway system. I am not questioning his independence; I am saying that if we regard this inquiry as the only possible independent inquiry, we are wrong. If we just say that because he is so-called independent and we have to take the bottom line, as did the headlines, we are wrong.

Let me give one example. The Hill report gives the direct contruction costs as $450m and estimates, with rolling stock, spare parts and plant and equipment costs, a total of $515m. However, Mr Hill also finds that direct benefits would result from freight line haul savings, passenger cost savings and reduced road maintenance costs, all totalling $142m. So the net capital costs involved would be $373m. That is what Mr Hill found. I am glad that Senator Maguire, a South Australian economist, is listening. Mr Hill found in his report that the net cost for the construction stage would be $373m, not the $1 billion that the newspaper headlines estimated to be the cost between now and the end of the century. We can see further reductions. I ask the Minister to inquire into the proposed $200m fiscal drawback, the reduced unemployment benefits that would be paid out and other items such as those given in the analysis by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry South Australia Inc. If we take that into account, will the net cost of $373m given in the Hill report come back to $173m? It is almost a profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you keep going along these lines of argument, it will not cost us anything.

—As with many investments in Australia today, Senator Grimes, one can outlay money and, because it is a good investment, receive that money back in the profits generated from the activity. I raise these questions and ask the Minister to respond in due course only to enable us to understand the terms on which the Hill report is formulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Foreign Investment Review Board report of 1983 is a significant paper. I have certainly spoken on all other reports before this chamber since I have been here. I believe that one of the basic principles of the Australian Labor Party in the age of foreign investment is the maintenance and support for a competitive, non-monopolistic private sector, including small business and farming, controlled and owned by Australians operating with clear social guidelines and objectives. The words 'controlled and owned by Australians' are fundamental to Labor's position on the private sector. Indeed, I feel there is wide support throughout the community for the retention of Australian control and ownership of the Australian economy.

I am greatly concerned at the extent to which our industry is foreign controlled and the likelihood that this foreign control will increase further unless preventive action is taken. This report has to be considered against the background of the vastly increasing foreign control that has occurred in the last few years. That increasing foreign domination of the Australian economy by the foreign-based transnational corporations endangers our foreign sovereignty and places our resources, technology and the leading role in determining the future pattern of development under the control of corporations whose interests are not in accord with the best interests of our nation. Furthermore, the international scale and enormous economic power impinge upon the effectiveness of the traditional tools of government and economic management. Indeed, they reduce the authority of the elected government over the national economy.

One matter of concern to me is the continuing tendency for foreign investors to acquire existing businesses rather than establishing new businesses. The 1982-83 report shows that out of 944 foreign investment proposals only 43 involve the establishment of new businesses. The other 901 proposals related to acquisitions of existing Australian businesses. I am also disturbed to see that of the 43 new businesses almost half-21-were proposed for the finance and insurance sector. This disturbs me because the finance sector is a strategic sector of our economy . I believe that we should restrict foreign entry into the strategic sectors of the economy. Yet even before the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System has been published it seems as though foreign interests are making a major push into the finance sector of our economy.

Another matter of some concern revealed in the report before us relates to the manufacturing sector. Of a total of 187 foreign investment programs in the manufacturing sector, only three involve the establishment of new businesses. At a time when Australia desperately needs new growth in our manufacturing sector only three foreign investment proposals out of an overall total of 944 related to new manufacturing business. I feel that this emphasises the Labor Party platform which is a vital platform when referring to overseas control. We do not object to overseas investment in Australia, but the reference in the Labor Party platform points out that we want that investment only when it introduces beneficial new technology and expertise, increases employment, expands taxable capacity, and otherwise shows itself to be in Australia's national interest. Unfortunately a table in the last report showing foreign investment as a proportion of net private investment expenditure has not been reproduced in this report. Time does not allow me to refer to this any further except to say that I think the figures in the last three reports showed a very significant and alarming situation concerning foreign investment as a proportion of net private investment expenditure. I hope that in the next report we will get a proper detailed analysis of what has happened in this area in the period under review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Childs for his contribution to the debate because it enables my contribution to contrast with his and to show where some of the differences of opinion lie. I believe that Australia's future lies very clearly and very strongly in the Western Pacific and in trading with countries in what is the major growth area of the world and likely to be the major growth area of the world for the next decade, two decades or longer. We need to ensure that we can interrelate, but not integrate, our economy with the economies of those countries to the maximum extent to our advantage. I believe that one of the fears is that if an organisation such as the Foreign Investment Review Board adopts an attitude which is restrictive towards the inflow of capital, other countries will follow up with attitudes which are restrictive to the development of trade generally with Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is no reason why we should be concerned, as Senator Childs suggests we should, about the fact that only a very small percentage of the total number of applications in 1982-83 related to manufacturing. I hope that that percentage will increase. As a matter of fact, as we come out of the recession, if we stop decrying manufacturing industry in Australia, if we stop the continual practice of accusing manufacturing industry of having priced itself out of the market and of being totally incompetent, if we start recognising that there are areas where manufacturing in Australia can be world competitive, others will have more interest in coming and investing and perhaps bringing with them technology and other benefits. I have believed for many years that Australia has the opportunity-I think this is increasing almost daily-to be the finance centre, or at least a major finance centre, for the Western Pacific. But to do that we will need to deregulate. I congratulate the Government on the steps it has taken so far to facilitate that.

As time is so limited I can say only briefly that the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial system has made recommendations. The Martin Review of the Australian Financial System has made some further recommendations which are perhaps more in accord with the present Government's policies. I hope that we will be getting some responses to those recommendations in the very near future because the FIRB is very important to the whole question of Australia's prospects of being a finance centre.

Finally, I repeat the suggestion I made by letter to the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House, dealing with the future use of this Parliament House when the permanent Parliament House has been constructed; that is, that Australia's great contribution to the Western Pacific could be to make this chamber, in fact the whole of this building, available for the Western Pacific Council, the Pacific Basin Economic Council, the South West Pacific Forum and other bodies, all of which have been developing in recent years and tend to bring together the island nations of the South Pacific, the South West Pacific and a number of other countries from Japan right through the Western Pacific. If this could be done this Parliament House could become the equivalent of the Palace of Europe in Strasbourg as a meeting place, a centre at which people from the various countries involved could meet to produce a more cohesive approach to the development of their region. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make those brief remarks.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present a report on the parliamentary zone draft development plan. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement relating to the report and to make some further remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The report I have just tabled concerns a draft development plan for the parliamentary zone. Last October, the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory along with the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House received a briefing from the National Capital Development Commission on proposals for the future development of the parliamentary zone.

Until recently the major planning priority has concentrated on the location, design and servicing of the site of the new Parliament House. This included the road access to the new House, which the Committee has previously reported on. With the finalisation of major planning decisions concerning the Capital Hill area, attention then focused on the remainder of the parliamentary zone.

During the briefing by the Commission it was pointed out that the quality of landscaping in the central northern part of the zone was poor. The landscaping had always been a temporary measure until the site for the permanent Parliament House was decided. Consequently it was minimal and poorly defined.

The NCDC put before the Committee plans for correcting the deficiencies by creating a more coherent plan for the northern part of the zone-that is, for the area between the present House and the Lake. The design:
Reinforces the Burley Griffin land and water axes;
provides a framework within which future public buildings can be located; and
encourages increased tourist and pedestrian use of the lake edge.

The Parliamentary zone is the focal point of the national capital and it should now be developed as such. The completion of the new House and the major design elements of the remainder of the parliamentary zone by 1988 will be a fitting way to mark the bicentenary in the national capital. The designs presented to the Committee are still evolving and the final designs may differ in some aspects. However, to work within a tight timetable and in keeping with good planning practice of allowing comment on planning at an early stage, the Commission has sought an early in-principle approval of the plan. Several elements will require gazettal action and detailed scrutiny at a later date. A major concern of the Committee was the lack of provision in the proposal for consultation with all senators and members or for that matter with the community . Parliament's role in the planning of the parliamentary zone was made clear in the Parliament Act 1974. The Act establishes Parliament's control over major works in the parliamentary zone. Therefore the Committee believes that all members and senators should have an opportunity to examine the proposals in detail and comment on them before final decisions are made. We have requested the NCDC to follow this procedure. Despite its concern about the lack of consultation the Committee believes the development plan to be a good one because:
It provides an overall framework within which road proposals, landscape proposals and long-term development can be resolved in a way that will complement the new Parliament House;
The plan will complete Griffin's land axis between the new Parliament House and the lake; and

The plan is sufficiently in keeping with Burley Griffin's plans given the structure and location of existing buildings and the need for the zone to cope with modern day traffic problems, including tourist and commuter traffic. The 1983 plan provides a much clearer road system and an improved pedestrian environment in the Parliamentary Triangle. In general, the layout is now more suitable for tourists.
I strongly recommend that all members and senators read the report and, more importantly, examine the proposals for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also table the minutes of the proceedings of the Committee. The part of the report to which I refer specifically is made more apt by the remarks Senator Peter Rae made just a short time ago, when he moved that the Senate take note of the paper dealing with a small variation of buildings in the parliamentary zone. Whilst the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory is empowered to scrutinise national capital matters on behalf of the Parliament, we believe that we cannot speak for all honourable members and honourable senators on a matter such as this. We believe that the proposals are of such significance that all honourable members and senators ought to have been advised of them and given the opportunity to comment. We have said that in the report. I recommend the report to honourable senators and honourable members . As I said, I welcome the remarks made earlier by Senator Peter Rae endorsing this concept.

The Curriculum Development Centre annual report 1981-82, together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), outlines the reasons for the delay in tabling the Curriculum Development Centre annual report for 1982-83. The report was considerably late. Concern has been expressed many times in this chamber in relation to reports which are late. I think it is to be welcomed that there is, along with the late tabling, an explanation by the Minister for the reasons for the late tabling of the report. This has meant that honourable senators are not just confronted with something which is out of date but that there is no explanation as to the reasons for the delay.

I will talk a little about the Curriculum Development Centre, its future role in Australia, whether it has served a useful purpose, and if it has, which way it might go in the future. In Australia we have a very wide ranging debate amongst people who view the problem of curriculum in the various State education systems as a matter of real concern. They wonder whether we should have a much greater degree of standardisation or whether we should simply have a curriculum development centre which can develop various aspects for study and make the information available to the State and private education systems which can take it up or not take it up as they choose. To many people that is really what the debate has been about. Others believe that this country needs to have far more work done, particularly for its brighter students, those who have the greatest opportunity at school, to develop, within the curriculum, the types of studies which will put Australians at the forefront of technology and technological thought.

This brings me to repeat a suggestion which I have made previously. I believe that one of the areas in which we fail badly as communities, not just in Australia but throughout the world, is in relation to what might be called technological economics. It is called this at Stirling University where Professor Bradbury is in charge of the faculty of technological economics. It can be called that as long as one does not get the idea that the subject is simply technology or economics. It is about how the technologist communicates with the economist. How does one bring together the various concepts? How does one develop the newspeak to enable the increasingly complex concepts which are developing in this rapidly changing world to be understood by a person who is in the board room having come up, say, through the accountancy section or the technical section or having never worked in either section of an industry? How does one bring together people who have to try to understand and to assist in the decision making, such as members of parliament, if they cannot understand the terminology and are turned off, as people often tend to be, by jargon? How often have we heard in this chamber criticism of lawyers for being too prone to use jargon whenever they have the opportunity? How often have we heard criticism of medicos and others? These days the economist is probably mentioned more frequently than any other. I think we need to give a lot more thought, at a school level as well as at a tertiary level, to the concept of some intercommunication, some understanding between the various disciplines. It is all very well to stream kids into an arts type humanity stream, science stream, or whatever it may be. One of the main things they need to know is what is the difference and how they communicate between the two. That is one of the areas where the Curriculum Development Centre could perhaps do more than has been done in the past. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak on this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The certificate issued by the Electoral Commissioner on 27 February this year is the first step in the process of redistributing the electorates for the House of Representatives. The new Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, has determined the population of the several States of Australia and has made his determination of the number of electorates to be created for the House of Representatives. He makes it clear that on his calculations eight extra seats will be created in New South Wales, six in Victoria, five in Queensland, two in Western Australia and two in South Australia. That determination follows the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to increase the size of the House of Representatives. The general effect of that determination is to make the enrolments of the electorates between the various States and Territories more uniform. A redistribution of the House of Representatives is long overdue and should occur anyway, irrespective of any increase in the size of Parliament. For example, in at least one recent Federal election there was a clear lack of correspondence between the number of votes obtained and the number of seats obtained in the House of Representatives by the various parties. For example, in the 1980 elections the conservative coalition parties received 0.2 per cent more than half of the votes but ended up with a majority of 23 seats. That is one example of why a redistribution is necessary.

Under the previous set of electoral laws in Australia it was possible to have non-mandatory redistributions of electorates. However, the Fraser Government chose to have no non-mandatory redistributions. There has not been a redistribution of the House of Representatives boundaries since 1977. Consequently, a huge disparity in the enrolments in the various electorates has arisen. The latest figures made available to honourable senators this week for the month of January indicate that the disparity is worst in the Federal divisions in Queensland. The division of Fadden, an outer metropolitan seat, has 106,800 electors, which is 35 per cent above the State average. The rural electorate of Kennedy has 66,000 electors, or 40,000 fewer than the number in the electorate of Fadden and 16 per cent below the State average. So it is clear that in Queensland the Federal boundaries under no circumstances can be construed to indicate that one vote one value applies. We should be fighting for the very important principle in electing our parliament that electors, wherever they live, should have votes of equal value. I hope and believe that that principles will be a central part of further redistributions.

The new criteria for redistributions include a provision that over the seven- year maximum interval between redistributions, electorates should have approximately equal numbers of electors; that is, after three years and six months it should be possible to forecast the approximately equal number of voters. That means that the growing areas of Australia which, since the post-war period have been the outer metropolitan areas, should tend to have their initial enrolments set below the averages for their respective States. That is a very important step forward. In the past redistributions have not taken sufficient account of the growth of certain parts of our capital cities. Consequently, within a year or two very large enrolments have resulted in those areas. I mention for example the seats of Kingston and Bonython in South Australia.

The redistribution is to be carried out by the Australian Electoral Commission which is reconstituted as an independent body. The determinations of the Commission in respect of redistributions are to be final. There will be no role for parliament in determining the nature or content of redistributions. I think that aspect of independence is a very important step forward at the national level in the drawing of our electoral boundaries. It follows the model set in South Australia, and more recently followed in Victoria, where electoral boundaries have been taken out of the hands of the parliament and put in the hands of independent commissions. Certainly, in South Australia the independent model has worked very well. Both major political parties have been able to win elections under the boundaries drawn by the Electoral Commission in that State.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.
