One of the most important reports to come before the Senate for a long time is the Honey Research Committee annual report for 1982-1983. I say that with great sincerity and I also urge honourable senators to read this report because it is typical of this type of report. We must acknowledge that the honey industry, although in itself quite small, is both an industry in itself and an adjunct to many other industries. There is no way that we can do without a very bright and prosperous honey industry. I am impressed by the work carried out by the beekeepers of Australia. I am impressed that the Honey Research Committee works very hard and produces programs year after year on how to improve the industry and the product.

I noticed in its 1982-83 program it supported 13 projects for the year and spent $89,668. During 1983-84 it will spend $128,499. I notice in that year its priorities, in order, were: Bee breeding; bee diseases; pollination as a service to horticulture and agriculture; pesticide hazards; bee nutrition; production of honey and hive products; and honey quality. All of those are very important items and demonstrate that it is a grass roots organisation. It considers the things that are fundamental to the industry and fundamental to the way that it fits in with the other areas which are so important, particularly in regard to pollination of seed crops. It is also important that we maintain and support an export industry. It needs to have access to international markets. I find it quite incongruous that on the one hand the Government provides money to support the Research Committee and on the other has produced a Bill to slug the industry for enormous export inspection charges which will more than take back that money . I think it is absolutely crazy. I have had the pleasure of assisting the Tasmanian exporters to form themselves into a Tasmanian honey exporters association. I hope to assist them and their interstate colleagues further in trying to get more help and consideration from the Government in this regard.

I commend the industry and the Research Committee. I urge the Government at this stage, before we deal with the legislation, to consider what it is doing to this little industry which is so important to a host of other industries. The apple and pear industry, the small fruits industry, the rape seed industry and the sunflower industry all depend entirely on having an active, enterprising, beekeeping industry. To confront it now with the schedule of charges that is laid down on export honey is quite unreasonable, if we expect it to do so much of what it does more or less for nothing. In many cases the beekeepers cart bees from one end of the country to another to provide a service to other industries for which they get no re- compense. I believe that because of its size and what it does, it deserves a little extra consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: 6.00)-I well recall the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations looking into the proposals for the honey industry export charges. What we found as a result of the inquiry was that in fact the countries which used to require some certification for which an export inspection was made and a certificate issued no longer required such certificates. We were informed by the exporters that they did not need the certificates but that what was happening was that an inspection-which cost money -was being made and a charge made to recover some of that cost, all of which appeared unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: One finds a tendency on the part of the Department of Primary Industry to whisper: 'Oh, well, we will sneak it through another time, sometime when the senators are not watching we will be able to get through some of the things that got knocked back this time'. The matter concerns not just honey but a number of other products. All I say is that if ever I have the chance to be here I wish the Department of Primary Industry to know that I shall endeavour to keep a very good eye on what is proposed and to make sure that some of those that have been put back once will not be slipped through by other methods.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have followed the activities of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation since its inception in 1966 and I have had quite a lot to do with it. I repeat what I have said before in this chamber: No one single item in the time that I have been concerned with housing, has had such a beneficial effect for people seeking housing in Australia as has the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. I am interested to see that the Corporation has now insured 571,000 loans for total amounts of $13 billion. That makes the Corporation a fairly big business by any standards. It is a great service and it runs alongside some very worthy free enterprise operators with whom I would like to see the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation operating on a fully competitive basis.

Of course 1983-84 will be a big year as will 1984-85, largely due to the massive injection of government grants for new home buyers. Make no error, I welcome the stimulus that this is giving to the housing industry and to the people seeking housing in Australia generally. I make a couple of comments however. Firstly, the effect of this injection of funds has been universally, Australia-wide, to increase the price of houses generally by at least the amount of the grant or more. In many places the increases in housing prices as a result of this extra liquidity has meant an increase greater than the amount of the grant. I regret to say it has also encouraged the sale of considerable numbers of houses previously let to people in the lower end of the rental market. Owners of those houses have seen an opportunity to get an artificially high price and have taken the opportunity to cash them in. Regrettably many people who have been tenants most of their lives have had to find alternative accommodation.

Also, interest rates have been artificially reduced at present and loans are the highest they have ever been in the history of Australia. The HLIC would confirm that. What will happen when interest rates return to normal and when there is some tightening up in the amount of finance available? How long will the grants scheme last? I am still trying to determine roughly what the backlog in housing is likely to be. I want to know how long it will take to fill it and what will happen when it is filled. Normally when demand is satisfied prices could be expected to come down. I do not want to see or be a party to a monstrous wind-down while we are enjoying what is going on at the moment. I do not think this has yet been mentioned or taken into account by any of the people I have heard discussing the benefits we are currently getting.

Also I wonder, with the rise in housing prices that the grants have created, whether we are not going to have to keep the level of inflation high enough to cover any contraction in price that may otherwise occur. I would like to see the Government consider the matters that I have raised. I would like to see the Government put down a paper demonstrating how long it sees the current scheme lasting and how it proposes to bring the scheme back to a level of what will be the run-on figure in the years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address some remarks to the 1982-83 annual report of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The function of the Corporation is to insure the repayment of loans made by lending institutions. The Corporation insures them against default on loans made for owner-occupied housing. It must be made clear that the insurance is not in respect of the asset itself but rather the loan in respect of the asset. By making that insurance possible the Corporation assists home ownership in Australia because it gives lending institutions more confidence in the repayment ability of those receiving loans. It effectively lifts the security of the loans .

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically the Corporation helps home ownership by boosting loans in relation to property valuations. That is a very important matter. Lenders can then provide more of the actual value of the property as a loan cutting the so-called deposit gap which in recent years in Australia has been a key obstacle to home ownership. Indeed the deposit gap is very much addressed by the present Government's first home buyer's scheme which involves making the grants to couples to purchase homes. In that way it removes the cash down payment or the deposit gap required.

At the moment the Corporation has under insurance some 18,600 loans-a large number of loans. It is interesting to note that most of those loans have in fact been made available by building societies rather than by other lending institutions such as savings banks and finance companies. It is very important to note that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is a self-financing statutory authority. It operates on a full commercial basis. In servicing its capital it pays a greater return on that capital to the Government as well as paying all State and Commonwealth taxes to which it is subject. Since the Corporation was established in 1965 it has made a profit in every year. The Commonwealth's only role in respect of the Corporation in recent years has been to guarantee its funds. It is striking that since 1978 there have been no increases in the premiums charged by the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. This is a tremendous achievement given the rate of inflation and the increase in price levels in this country since 1978.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is the largest insurer of residential loans in Australia. It now accounts for some 60 per cent of the resident loans market. It is very pleasing indeed to see a statutory corporation as the market leader in a particular industry. That is a very welcome development. The Corporation itself makes a very big impact on the housing market. In 1982-83 a record operating profit of $8.2m was earned. The Corporation paid income tax into the Commonwealth Budget totalling $3.5m and paid a dividend to the Government in November 1983 of $2.3m. The Corporation is a commercially viable organisation paying a rate of return on its capital and paying taxes to Commonwealth and State governments.

I found that one of the disturbing features of this report was the sharp increase in the number of housing loans arrears cases of housing loans in Australia in 1982-83. For example, in Queensland there were 30 per cent more arrears cases than there were the previous year. New South Wales had a 36 per cent increase, and the number of properties in the possession of mortgagees doubled in that one year indicating some of the problems in the economy at the moment-depressed property values, higher unemployment, people's fear of unemployment and their concern about their ability to repay housing loans.

I am very pleased that the present Government has repudiated the so-called razor gang re- commendations of April 1981 that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation be sold. I am also very pleased that in addition during 1983 the Government conferred increased functions on the Corporation to allow it to now insure some loans for commercial properties. That is a great step forward. It is a profitable, public authority and it should be supported by all members of Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

One must congratulate the Aboriginal Development Commission on the contents of its 1982-83 annual report and the way in which it has outlined the organisation' s land acquisition, housing grants and a number of activities that the Commission has engaged in during that period. In the short time available to me the points that I wish to make are in relation to land acquisition by the Commission. It is worth while noting that on page 16 of the report, under the heading 'Consideration of land proposals', details of those proposals, as outlined by the Commission, are set out. While time does not allow me to read into the Hansard record all of the details outlined by the Commission I think it is important that one or two of the items listed on land proposals be read out. Some of the important points outlined by the Commission are:

. . . the needs of the community or group concerned and the importance of land in relation to its long-term development; the economic and social viability of the proposed land acquisition; the number of people who will benefit directly and indirectly . . .

by any acquisition of land. It goes without saying that it is very important to the Aboriginal people that they acquire land. It certainly gives them some base on which to build their community and to get recognition from the rest of the community in relation to the role that they will play in the community where they hold that land. I find it very interesting to look through the report at the number of properties that have been acquired by the Commission on behalf of the Aboriginal people. Without dealing with the Northern Territory, Western Australia and some of the other States, I believe it is fairly important that I should make some comment in relation to the Commission gaining Delta Downs pastoral lease at Normanton in north Queensland. That is a fairly significant acquisition of land because this is the first time that the Aboriginal Commission has been able to acquire a pastoral leasehold in Queensland. This has allowed the Aboriginal Land Commission to acquire a pastoral lease that will allow the Aboriginal people to demonstrate to the rest of the community firstly that they can produce a viable proposition in relation to the breeding of cattle and, secondly, that they are able to produce from that property revenue for the Aboriginal people who will be able to use that property as a base for settlement . This will demonstrate that they have some belonging in the area. Not only will the acquiring of the lease and the development of the cattle property give them that sense of belonging but it will also give them a base which will allow them to acquire a number of sacred sites that are contained within the lease. The report states:

In December 1982, the Commission acquired all shares in Delta Downs Pastoral Company and thereby the pastoral lease. The acquisition finally provides the Kurtjar people of Normanton with a land base which is enabling them to maintain protection of sacred sites and to operate a viable cattle enterprise. The pastoral lease is well developed and could generate substantial income. It has nine dams, a number of additional waterholes and a herd of between 16,000 and 22 ,000 cattle.

This allows the Kurtjar people to demonstrate to the people of Queensland that they have the ability to manage and run this property and that they can give to the Aboriginal people a reasonable financial return during the time they run it. The other interesting point I would like to make is that it is unique that the Aboriginal people gained this pastoral lease in Queensland because for years the Queensland Government has frustrated any attempts by the Aboriginal people to transfer leases to their Commission or to themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the discussion on the Aboriginal Development Commission annual report 1982-83 I want to raise a couple of matters which relate to my State of Western Australia. Perhaps the most significant of the purchases that have been made by the Aboriginal Development Commission this year is the Carson River Station which honourable senators might recall was next to the Kalumburu mission which was controlled by the Benedictine Order about which I have spoken on a number of occasions in the Parliament. There was, of course, great reluctance on the part of some members of the Benedictine Order to enter into any discussions with regard to the Carson River pastoral lease. It is interesting to note that it has now been acquired for the Kalumburu community under a leasehold which is jointly held by the Western Australian Aboriginal Lands Trust and the ADC.

SPEECH.PARA: The original intention was that the Western Australian Aboriginal Lands Trust should be the sole leaseholder. That was a stipulation by the former Government of Western Australia and I believe that that would not have been in the best interests of the Kalumburu community. The property has the potential to carry 20 ,000 cattle and given the enthusiasm of members of the Kalumburu community I am sure that they will make a success of it. It is part and parcel of the self- sufficiency syndrome that is being developed in the Aboriginal community and I think that is of great benefit to the majority of them. I read, I think in Tuesday's West Australian, that yet another property has been acquired by the ADC, the Aboriginal Lands Trust and one other organisation in Western Australia for the Bow River pastoral lease which will also be of great benefit.

It is not possible to discuss Aboriginal affairs in Western Australia without raising the situation which obtained at Noonkanbah some years ago. I am sure that I do not need to remind honourable senators of the dramatic effect that decisions of the former State government had on the community at Noonkanbah. I briefly remind honourable senators that this was a station where the State Government determined that a mining company would be allowed to go ahead. After great confrontation with both black and white communities a drilling rig was eventually put through to Noonkanbah. A great deal of distress was caused and the community found itself in an extremely fragile situation. In fact I did not visit Noonkanbah for some 12 months after that because I knew that the people there were quite shattered by the whole experience. It is interesting to note that now drilling at Noonkanbah is going ahead with the agreement of the Noonkanbah community. It is going ahead where the Noonkanbah community first determined that it should so that its sacred sites were protected and so that there was no need for the members of the organisation who were to do the drilling to have any access to the community if that was the community's decision.

I always think that it is interesting that that could have happened before. If there had been more co-operation and perhaps conciliation-'conciliation' being one of the in words at the moment-the situation that developed at Noonkanbah during 1979-80 may never have been necessary and perhaps should never have taken place. But it is interesting that the people there do, in fact, now control that land by virtue of its purchase by the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Western Australian Aboriginal Lands Trust. I think it is incumbent on me- especially as I was the one who raised the matter originally in the Senate-to say to the people at Noonkanbah and at Cooanana station on the Carson River that there is a genuine feeling in the Senate chamber that this is perhaps the greatest opportunity for Aboriginal people to establish that they are quite capable of accepting pastoral leases and making their own communities very secure and eventually self-sufficient. They will require the assistance of both State and Federal governments. I would like to think that that will be forthcoming in the foreseeable future but will not be necessary for eternity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 6.24 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Messner, and at his request, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes that-
(a) the introduction of Medicare will cause an artificial reduction in the Consumer Price Index; and
(b) this will adversely affect the millions of pensioners and beneficiaries whose income is linked to the Consumer Price Index;
and condemns the Government for its failure to recognise this fact and to take remedial action.

In considering this matter we should look at what was promised to the pensioners during the last election campaign. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said unequivocally at the time that he would not be touching the pensioners' pay packets. You will remember, Mr President, that there was considerable debate about this aspect of the election campaign because the previous Prime Minister, as has been proved right, said that pensioners would be better off with their savings under their beds. Let us look at what Mr Hawke promised. We were told not only by Mr Hawke but also by Dr Blewett that pensioners would not be any worse off under Medicare, that they would still have their health cards and would be in exactly the same position as they were under the previous Government . However, that is far from the fact. Because of Medicare this Government has said to the people of Australia: 'You no longer have the right to insure yourself. Therefore, we will stop you taking money out of one pocket to pay your contributions to your private health fund but we will take it from you in tax. We will still be taking the money from you but it will be out of the other pocket so that it will not add to the consumer price index'. Indeed, it will lower the CPI. It will not stop payment of money by the general public; it will just be paid in a different fashion. As a result, the consumer price index will go down by 2.6 per cent.

We know that the consumer price index takes into account money paid by individuals for health insurance along with many other costs but it does not take into account taxation. Because of that, the consumer price index will go down by 2.6 per cent even though the cost of goods and services will rise with inflation. How does this affect the pensioners? It is very obvious. When we were in government we brought in automatic rises in pensions in line with the rises in the consumer price index. Twice a year the consumer price index rises and pensions went up as a result. Now they will not go up by the full amount of the inflation rate, the rate by which the price of normal goods rises. The consumer price index will be reduced artificially by 2.6 per cent. I do not think anybody on the Government benches will claim that it is anything but an artificial reduction in the consumer price index. But the pensioners will still pay the increases in their food prices, in their rents and in everything else on which the consumer price index relies. They will not get relief from the costs of Medicare. They don't have to pay for that but as a result of the lowering of the CPI a married couple will be denied $3.90.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—When the consumer price index no longer takes account of that 2 .6 per cent. Mr Hawke assured the Tasmanian people on a talk-back program recently in Hobart that the pensioners would not get this 2.6 per cent pension increase. He tried to convince the population of Hobart that that really would not matter because the reduction in the consumer price index would eventually flow through and result in cheaper goods. What do the pensioners do in the meantime? I do not think even Senator Grimes would suggest that the 2.6 per cent reduction in the consumer price index is not an artificial reduction.
—I am not suggesting that it is.

—Senator Grimes said no. It is admitted. But a pensioner married couple losing out on $3.90 will still have to pay higher prices for their goods. Mr Hawke promised that he would not disadvantage pensioners and the beneficiaries who also get that automatic increase. Indeed, unemployed people and low income earners will also be disadvantaged by that artificial reduction in the consumer price index because they will lose out on the increase in their benefits or wages. I wonder what the unions will say about that. I wonder whether Norm Gallagher will let the Government get away with it. I wonder whether, when the time comes, Norm Gallagher will say: 'It is an artificial 2.6 per cent reduction but we builders labourers will take the cut'. I will be very interested to see what happens. I wonder what the other unions will say and what the Australian Council of Trade Unions will say. Indeed, I wonder what the pensioners will be saying. I also wonder whether Mr Hawke will say: 'Oh dear, I am sorry. We have made another mistake. But then we did say to the country that we would make mistakes. But I am big enough to stand up and tell you that I have made a dreadful mistake, or at least my Minister has made a dreadful mistake'-as he did on the assets test.
—He didn't say that at all.
—He did say 'We have made a mistake'.
—No.

—Senator Grimes said no. He said at the National Press Club luncheon: 'We made a mistake. I told you of course that we would make mistakes and we have done so, but to err is human'. It is no use Senator Grimes saying that was not said because it floated across the airwaves of every station in Australia. People know that Mr Hawke said that it was a mistake. The people know that he bared his soul and said: 'We are human. I told you we would make a mistake and we have. The assets test was a mistake'.
—That is the only promise he has kept.

—That and the dam are the only two promises he has kept, but I had better not mention the dam in the presence of Senator Missen. Let us look at the other promises that Mr Hawke made to pensioners and those that he has already broken. He said very clearly in March that he would not be touching the pensioners' cheques. What happened as soon as he got into power? He immediately said: 'We will enforce a strict means test on the over-70 pensioners.' As you will be aware, Mr President, pensioners who are over 70 have worked very hard to make Australia what it is today. All those over-70s who were getting a paltry $ 51 because they were over the income test limit had worked very hard. When they were younger and were saving, their motto was: 'We will put away for a rainy day ; we will look after ourselves'. Indeed there was nothing for which they could put out their hand. They were forced to look after themselves. As you, Mr President, would know, because you are roughly the same age as I am, the idea in those days was to put money away for a rainy day. That was the general philosophy of those who are now over 70. These people had looked after themselves, so when we were in government we said: 'We will abolish the means test for those people over 70' and give a small amount, $51, to those whose income is over the means test.
—Who abolished the means test?
—It was originally Mr Whitlam who abolished it, and it was continued by our Government.
—Who introduced the new one? I thought that it was your Government.
—It was abolished by the present Government.
—I thought that your Government introduced the means test.

—I went around campaigning shortly after the Government abolished it. As I went around, the general consensus amongst this group of pensioners was: 'But why would they do it to us at this age?' It seemed to them that a rather sensible thing to do would be to have said: 'Any pensioner turning 70 from now on will be fully means tested, but we will allow those pensioners who have already organised their finances, to keep that $51. From now on anyone turning 70 will no longer get the $51'. But, no, that was not to be. Many of the pensioners to whom I spoke said: 'But my son has organised my finances. I am in the sort of accommodation that I can now afford, but with that money taken from me by the Government it means that I shall have to change my accommodation'. At their time of life, that is a cruel way of going about matters. As I have said, we have Mr Hawke's promises being broken many times.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of the pensioners promises broken category is the superannuation promise. That affects many pensioners. Many pensioners relying on superannuation and on getting lump sums believed Mr Hawke when he said that he would not touch them. They believed, a week before the election and immediately after it, that he would not be touching the lump sum payments. Because that man promised it, many of them voted for him. They have learnt to their sorrow that a promise by Mr Hawke really does not mean anything. Not only did they find that their lump sums were taxed, but those who were over 70 also found that their money was taken from them. I just wonder what those pensioners are now thinking. I often wonder what Mr Hawke thinks of himself as he lies in his bed at night as regards these elderly people, because there is tremendous concern in the community.

Many elderly people have no idea where the Labor Government will hit them next. They have worried since August about the assets test that was introduced. Indeed , Senator Grimes had assured them, in terms of one syllable, that it would definitely be introduced. Many of them have altered their finances in anticipation of that. One pensioner came to me about this matter. Her only assets had been some shares. She did not even own a house. Before she came to see me she had sold the shares and decided to buy furniture because she had heard that Senator Grimes had said: 'You can have furniture'. She invested in furniture so that she could leave something to her children. I told her that that action was a bit premature, but she had already done that on the say-so of Senator Grimes. She had already said to herself 'Senator Grimes said that I cannot have that sort of money in shares but I can invest it in furniture', and she had sold her shares.

What will the Government do about re-compensing such elderly people? They are people who, as I am sure everyone in this chamber will admit, are very concerned about their finances when they are in their 70s and 80s. For them to be misled by the Government into the sort of shenanigans that the assets test involved was an absolute crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I realise that there may be some relationship between the consumer price index, Medicare and the assets test, but Senator Walters is going on at great length about an issue that is not related to the motion.
—Why don't you give her a fair go.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank Senator Chipp for his great concern in protecting me. Many other honourable senators want to talk on the motion. Senator Haines is anxious to speak. I believe that I have made the points of particular concern to pensioners. I am sure that we shall find that Mr Hawke will admit another dreadful mistake. I hope that he gives the extra $3.90 to the pensioners, to the unemployed, to the low incomes earners. I am not so worried about Norm Gallagher , but if Mr Hawke gives it to the groups who are not able to pressure him as Norm Gallagher is pressuring him, I shall be very pleased. I shall be interested to see whether Mr Hawke succumbs to the pressure that the pensioners are and will be applying to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this debate is allegedly on the effect on pensioners of the relationship between the introduction of Medicare and the consumer price index, I shall do my utmost to keep my comments to that issue. On 24 May 1983, I asked a question of the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a fact that the cost of basic health insurance is at present a component of the consumer price index? Is it correct that, in the event of Medicare coming into operation, this component will be removed, thereby reducing the CPI by several percentage points? If this is the case, can the Minister say what effect this is likely to have on increases in pensions since they are adjusted twice a year according to the CPI?
The Minister responded as follows:

Yes, it is my understanding that, with the way the CPI is at present calculated , the introduction of the Medicare scheme or a universal health insurance scheme will in fact result in a reduction in the level of the CPI as it is calculated now.

This, of course, will affect increases in pensions as they are calculated now under the automatic indexation scheme. But as the honourable senator would know, the present Government takes as its parameter for the level of pensions a percentage of average weekly earnings. We intend, over the whole period of this Government if economic conditions allow as I am sure they will, to increase pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings. If by increasing pensions in line with CPI increases we do not reach that parameter, we will adjust pensions so that the situation is dealt with in that way.

It took Senator Messner and the Liberal Party something like 7 1/2 months to work out that there would be a problem for pensioners because of the odd, and not to say shonky, way in which the consumer price index is calculated. That is, money expended on health insurance straight from one's pocket or cheque book to a private health insurance fund is incorporated as part of the CPI. When the Government takes the health insurance contribution out of the taxpayer by a tax levy, it is not incorporated as part of the CPI. Nevertheless, that information slowly seeped through to Senator Messner and at some time in December last year or January of this year he must have put out a Press release because that prompted the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to issue a news release on 4 January 1984 stating:
Dr Blewett acknowledged that Medicare will have a substantial downward effect on the CPI in the March 1984 quarter, but said pensioners should not be alarmed.
'The Government is well aware of the potential implications of this for the November 1984 pension increase and will be looking at ways of addressing this in the Budget context.

'I am confident that appropriate measures will be taken. There is certainly no alteration to this Government's promise to improve pensioners' living standards through its commitment to raise the basic rate of pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings over a three year period.
I just wonder when we will see the first stage of that. Senator Grimes's answer to my question went on at some length and finished with this statement:

I believe and I always have believed it to be wrong to fix pensions just by CPI increases because CPI increases vary with the state of the economy and the level of productivity in the community. I think we have to fix a parameter, be it average weekly earnings or some other parameter, so that the true level of pensions relates to some recognisable and true value of the wages of other people in the community. For that reason we will watch the situation.

That is all very commendable, but one is forced to ask, some eight months later: 'What have you done about it?'. It is almost a year now since this Government took office. Presumably, although it is by no means certain, it knew what its policy plans were, what its timetable was, what sort of legislation it was planning to introduce, what effect it would have on the community and what the interconnection was between those pieces of legislation. Assuming the Government knew this and assuming that some unilateral decision was not made by a Prime Minister who specialises in unilateral decisions to upset all of that, one is forced to wonder why this area about which the Minister for Social Security was talking on 24 May last year has not been covered. Why is it that the only legislative action directed at pensioners by this Government has been a proposal regarding a punitive assets and income test Bill? I have no intention of speaking about that Bill at the moment.

The Medicare levy was introduced on 1 February 1984. As was indicated in Dr Blewett's news release, it will not affect pensions in the first half of this year. It will not-although Senator Walters seemed to imply that it would; I am not sure that she did it deliberately-affect the indexed social security increases in May because they are based on price movements from June last year to December last year. It will, however, affect the November social security increases, as Dr Blewett said, since this will be based on the CPI increases from December 1983 to June 1984. These, of course, are the ones that have been artificially deflated by the effect on the CPI of the introduction of Medicare. The estimated underlying rate of inflation for the period from January this year to June this year is estimated to be in the vicinity of 4.125 per cent. I pause to ponder on the fact that a figure taken to three decimal places can be an estimate. The introduction of Medicare will deflate this figure by 2.7 percentage points. Hence the CPI increase over this period will be 1.4 per cent despite an underlying rate of inflation of over 2.5 per cent higher and pensions , therefore, will increase by 4.1 per cent. Without the Medicare effect on the CPI the basic pension rate in November 1984 is estimated to be $93.13. Using the actual CPI figure this amount will be reduced to $90.71, so anyone on a full pension will lose, through the impact of Medicare on the CPI over that last half of the year, in the vicinity of $2.42.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless compensating action is taken by the Government.

—Indeed, unless compensating action is taken, but we have not had any hint of that yet and therefore we are forced simply to look at the situation as it appears it will be in the latter half of this year. What is worse is that by creating an artificially lower base for future CPI adjustments, unless some other action is taken, the effect of the shortcoming will be continued in the future as a sort of punitive cumulative effect as the lower CPI percentage continues to operate at a lowered amount from the previous quarter. Nobody will be able to catch up at all. Dr Blewett and Senator Grimes maintain that the problem will be solved by moving pensions towards 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. I made the point earlier that I do not deny that this is a commendable aim. In fact, I hope the Government fulfils its promise. However, we may well be faced with an early election this year at around the time when the pension is first affected by the CPI level. We will simply go into an election with yet another promise from this Government that it will increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is a wonderful timetable.
—We will have a Budget this year. That is when pensions go up.

—I see. Well, I will not hold my breath waiting, but will be delighted if there is something in the Budget to indicate that at least this election promise has not been unilaterally rejected by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in order to push up his ratings from 73 per cent to 75 per cent or some other astromonical figure. Even if that happens, though, it will not be an immediate solution to the problem. I think the Government is aware of this. Whereas Senator Grimes and Dr Blewett talk as if they want to increase the incomes of social security recipients, the effect of Medicare on the CPI must be the opposite. There is no question about it. Social security recipients represent a large proportion of low income units in Australia. As a result of the action of the Government slightly fewer than 2,500,000 people will be worse off. Those low income people will be asked to pay prices in accordance with the real rate of inflation whereas their income will be understated by the application of a bogus rate of inflation to their pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: One point outside the motion put by Senator Walters, either on behalf of or in disguise as Senator Messner, which will affect pensions and will come as a result of the introduction of Medicare is the real problem facing pensioners and other traditional users of the public hospital system such as the unemployed and other social security beneficiaries, with the Government's insistence on the use of public hospitals in preference to the use of any private hospital care under the basic system. Contrary to every other piece of social security legislation or policy proposal put forward by the Australian Labor Party, the use of public hospitals is allowed and indeed encouraged with no reference to the means of the patient to pay. Dr Blewett put out a Press release at some stage last year giving an estimate of the shift from private beds in public hospitals to public beds in public hospitals. The release states in part:

Estimate of shift is based on figures provided by the States. The estimated shift is equal to 16 per cent of private bed days in 1982-83 or 6.6 per cent of all public hospital days. The resulting proportion of 'hospital' patient days is estimated at 66 per cent on average, which is 5.2 percentage points higher than in 1975-76 and 11.0 percentage points higher than in 1980-81, the last year in which free treatment was available without restriction. On past evidence, the allowance for shift is considered to be the maximum likely change.

In other words, something like 6 1/2 per cent of pensioners are likely to be deprived of getting a public hospital bed when they want one because there is neither a means test nor any other incentive for non-pensioners to use other than public hospital facilities.

A number of pensioner groups wrote to me early last year urging the Australian Democrats not to do anything to upset the Medicare apple cart. When I wrote back pointing out to them that it was not the solution to all their problems and that it would have one or two adverse effects on pensioners, this did not seem in any way to deter their enthusiasm for the scheme. Notwithstanding the fact that they could not see all this, it will seriously disadvantage the elderly, the unemployed, those on the supporting parents benefit and others with low incomes. I believe it is a pity that the Minister for Health's paranoia regarding private practice, both medical and hospital, should lead him to so blatantly sacrifice an already disadvantaged sector of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the motion moved by Senator Messner in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes that-
(a) the introduction of Medicare will cause and artifical reduction in the Consumer Price Index; and
(b) this will adversely effect the millions of pensioners and beneficiaries whose income is linked to the Consumer Price Index;
and condemns the Government for its failure to recognise this fact and to take remedial action.

The facts are as stated in the motion. The Fraser Government made arrangements for the regular half-yearly indexation of pensions. That arrangement was to reflect the upwards movement of prices to accommodate pensioners' incomes. It was never envisaged that, by some device that altered the market basket of ingredients in the consumer price index, inflation would go up but the consumer price index would not fully register it. The CPI is an index established by an independent body with an arbitary set of ingredients. It has a quaint ingredient that I have always felt is wrong; it takes account of indirect taxes but does not take account of direct taxes. Although direct taxes cost the taxpayer or the pensioner just as much as indirect taxes, nevertheless, the indirect tax is measured in the CPI and the direct tax is not.

What has happened is that the partial cost of medical care has been transferred from indirect taxation, that is, payment from the pocket of the taxpayer, into a direct tax levy. The cost to the ordinary Medicare patient-I do not mean pensioners as they do not pay those costs and never have-is the same. The cost, in terms of the direct levy, is not registered in the CPI. We have a situation in which although costs have gone up there is an artificial deflation and freezing of the CPI. There will be a partial wage and pension freeze; that is the simple situation. Although all wage earners will pay more in terms of inflation, as if it had in it the 2.6 per cent or 2.7 per cent, nevertheless, their incomes will be deflated to the extent of the reduction in the CPI. It is not good enough for us to learn that, sometime in November, there may be some kind of device that may lift things up. I listened with interest to the suggestion that, over three years, the Government will move pensions to some 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government did not say in its policy speech that it would deflate average weekly earnings. But that is what it will do. In order to get over this jam that it is in there will be some kind of increase in November which the Government will suggest is a movement of the pension towards 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. It will be nothing of the sort! The average weekly wage will be lower than if the full CPI operated. What we are seeing is a confidence trick. There will be some lift all right.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is AWE connected with CPI?

—The Minister has asked me a question. I will explain the matter to him as he needs elucidation. As I understand it, the Government said in its policy speech that, over three years, it will increase the pension to represent 25 per cent of the average weekly wage. Wages in this country move upwards in terms of the CPI. If the CPI deflates the wage the average weekly wage is deflated.
—I used to hear you say you wanted wages down all the time.

—For the last year the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) has been a born loser in these things. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that he has made a mistake in the policies he has brought forward-make no mistake about that. What the Prime Minister said is not what the Minister said today. The Prime Minister said that it was not a reaction by him to the obstruction by the Senate. It was the Prime Minister's realisation that there were inherent defects in the policy. That is in the transcripts of what the Prime Minister has said, not what the Minister has said. We are seeing another confidence trick; we see it quite clearly. The Government is moving towards saying: 'It is true that you did not get your full increase according to the CPI but we will move you closer to the average weekly wage'. There is a chance for the Government to do that. The Government said that it would make this move over three years. That means that each year there would be a lift. A year has come and gone and there has been no such lift. One presumes that we will have a March supplementary mini-Budget in which the Government will introduce pension increases. I take it that the Government's policy speech means what it says. After all, the policy speech stated that there would not be any changes in the structure of pensions, there would be no assets test, there would be no attack on the 70 years of age limit. It said those things. The policy speech also stated that, over the three years, pensions would be moved steadily to reach 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Nothing has happened. The simple fact of the matter is that pensioners will receive less money than they should have to meet the rise in costs. Nothing that anyone says can gainsay that . If a sweetener is put into the Budget to apply from November, mark my words, that sweetener will be represented to be something that closes the gap with the average weekly wage. It will not be true.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Hawke Government has said that it opposes wage freezes and partial wage freezes, before the last election it fervently opposed any kind of wage freeze, six months or otherwise. With the introduction of Medicare we will have a partial wage and pension freeze. What is stated in the motion is true. The introduction of Medicare will cause an artificial reduction in the CPI. That is beyond doubt. Clearly this will adversely affect the millions of pensioners and beneficiaries whose incomes are linked to the consumer price index. This idea that the Prime Minister is pedalling that somehow or other if he can pull out a CPI figure that is lower than the reality of prices outside it will, in the long run, reduce inflation in Australia must be one of the rushes of blood to the head. If that is so, if we can cure inflation by artifically deflating the CPI, why not fix it at 4 per cent tomorrow and be in common with the Organisations for Economic Co-operation and Development countries? After all, here is a simple formula. How can this be?

The fact of the matter is that the world can observe at this moment the pressure on the prices and incomes accord. The only thing that has been going for the prices and incomes accord this year has been the wages freeze brought in by the Fraser Government. Nothing else has been going for it. Indeed, as the year goes by we will see rising unemployment, we will see that reflected in the coming figures, we will see higher interest rates later this year. They will all press the M3, which was to have been 11 per cent or 12 per cent and has been admitted to be at 14 per cent. Pressures on costs are everywhere. Industrialist after industrialist is saying that the recovery that has been foreshadowed will not happen. Investment in manufacturing is declining and the pressures that are there of a further recession will cram upon those who can least afford it.

I commend the motion. It is true that Medicare will cause an artificial reduction in the CPI. It is true this will adversely affect millions of pensions and beneficiaries. Therefore, this Senate should, and will I am sure, condemn the Government for its failure to recognise the fact and to take remedial action .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President-

—I think the situation is that the motion was to be moved by Senator Messner and was moved by Senator Walters on his behalf. I would have thought that if Senator Messner speaks he is closing the debate.
—I am excluded from speaking? The Minister will not allow the shadow Minister to speak on the matter?
—The honourable senator can close the debate. The Opposition has had three speakers on that side of the House. Is it not about time we had someone on this side?
—Order! The Minister is entitled to the call. He is not closing the debate.
—I am not closing the debate; Senator Messner will close the debate.
—I call the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Social Security) (8.45)-I do not wish to keep the Senate long. The motion we are debating tonight reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the introduction of Medicare will cause an artificial reduction in the Consumer Price Index . . .
Of course that is right and it is right as it affects pensioners. Every honourable senator here knows that and has said that. The motion continues:
(b) this will adversely affect the millions of pensions and beneficiaries whose income is linked to the Consumer Price Index, . . .

Of course that is right, if nothing is done about it. Of course I accept that. For Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Walters to suggest that I will not accept that is nonsense. What I do not accept is the next line, which states:
and condemns the Government for its failure to recognise this fact . . .

I thank Senator Haines for at least doing some research on this matter and for pointing out that, in answer to a question to her in May 1983-May last year-I clearly recognised this fact and I clearly answered that question in the recognition that that was so. That Dr Blewett has done so several times since is also perfectly obvious. To suggest that the Government does not recognise this fact is nonsense. I suggest that to condemn the Government for failing to take remedial action at this stage of the game, having shown that the Government has already recognised the fact, is nonsense.

Senator Sir John Carrick is right: If a levy for health insurance is introduced and, therefore, there is a direct taxation situation in which there is an artificial reduction in the consumer price index, of course it affects pensioners if their pensions are linked to the CPI and nothing is done to change that. It has affected them before. It affected them in 1977 when the previous Government introduced a levy and no remedial action was taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The full CPI was adjusted; you are wrong.

—The honourable senator should get his facts out and have a look at them. No remedial action was taken. The second thing to point out-I think it needs to be pointed out to Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Walters, although Senator Haines realised the situation-is that the present system of indexation of pensions to the CPI is exactly the same as the indexation system which has existed since it was introduced in 1976, except, of course for people such as the single unemployed who, until recently, had no indexation because that indexation was taken away from them by the previous Government. That indexation means that the May increases in pensions will be paid on the September quarter and December quarter CPI increases last year. Medicare had no effect on the CPI increases on which the pension increase which is due in May will be based. But of course there will be an effect on the pension increase due in November. The time to take account of that and to do something about it will be in the next Budget. To suggest that the Government is not aware of that fact, when I have been talking about it for a year, is absolute nonsense. Senator Sir John Carrick clearly did not recognise that. Senator Sir John Carrick said the previous Government introduced the consumer price indexation of pensions to protect their value. When Senator Sir John Carrick, who was a Minister in the previous Government, came into office the pensions represented 24 per cent of average weekly earnings; when he went out they represented 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. If that is protection of the value of pensions, the pensioners do not believe it, I do not believe it and no one else here believes it.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen to think that we should have a serious debate on retirement policy in this country. I think we should do it without some of the wild suggestions that Senator Walters made here tonight. Senator Walters said tonight that certainly she would return to the situation for pensioners aged over 70 years which existed when the previous Government went out of power. That was not a means test free pension, as Senator Walters knows, but to do that would cost $170m in a full year. Of course, she did not say that during her speech. She repeatedly said: 'We want a means test free pension for pensioners aged over 70'. That would cost $460m in a full year.

Senator Walters would revoke the taxation changes on lump sum superannuation. Senator Walters cannot stand there and condemn the present Government for introducing taxation on lump sum superannuation without suggesting that she would do what her Leader says she would do and revoke those changes. In the first year of introduction, because they will hardly affect anyone, they will cost only $10m. But in a full year that will get up to $360m. So we are up to over $800m in increased expenditure already. If we add to that the Opposition's refusal to pass the legislation aimed at collecting tax evaded in this country we are up to over $1,000m in expenditure for the sorts of things the honourable senator has said she will do or has done already. The inevitable result of that is that, with an aging population, either taxes have to be increased or the level of pensions has to be kept at an artificially low level. We cannot help those who are reliant on just the base rate pension, we cannot get that base rate pension up, without increasing taxes in some way. That was an aside which was introduced by Senator Walters in her contribution to the debate.

The fact of the matter-there is no need to go into any great detail about this motion-is simply this: The crux of the motion is that the Government fails to recognise that the introduction of Medicare and the levy result in an artificial lowering of the indexation factor, which affects pensions. Senator Haines has demonstrated that I was talking about it last May. I have talked about it since and Dr Blewett put out Press statements at least once when he represented me as Acting Minister for Social Security and, from memory, once or twice before that in his capacity as Minister for Health. So we did recognise it and of course we do recognise it. The person who recognised it latest was Senator Messner because , as Senator Haines pointed out, he took from the time we came into government until 17 November to put down this motion. Senator Haines was talking about it last April and May, and so were we.

The second part of the motion-the crux of the motion-condemns the Government for its failure to take remedial action. The time to take remedial action is not in a March mini-Budget. It is not affecting anybody. In case any honourable senator looks stunned, Senator Sir John Carrick suggested that we take such action in a March mini-Budget. That does not give us much time, because we have not yet had any Budget Cabinet meetings. I say that the time to take such action is in the budgetary situation. That is when that sort of change was made by the previous Government, and that is when that sort of change will be made by this Government. That is the simple fact of the matter. The Opposition should not condemn the Government for not now introducing some strange legislation outside the Budget context which will affect pension increases next November. Senator Sir John Carrick has been a member of Budget Cabinets. He knows they do not introduce things--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about the 25 per cent over three years.
—I will come to the 25 per cent. We have said clearly that we will increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings during our first three year term.
—The first year has gone.

—I say to the honourable senator that the previous Government said that it would index pensions to maintain their value, and they dropped from 24 per cent of average weekly earnings to 22 per cent. Our first year in government has ended. In our first year in government we have increased the unemployment benefit to single unemployment beneficiaries by $10. The previous Government failed to index them and failed to give beneficiaries an increase. We have indexed the fringe benefit levels for pensioner beneficiaries, something which should have been done years ago. We have ample time to increase the standard rate of pensions to that level. We certainly must do so, because they have been dropped to the present level by the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us talk about the motion. The motion claims that we do not recognise that factor. Of course we recognise that factor. I accept that that factor exists. I have been talking about it for far longer than has Senator Messner. We recognise, of course, that that factor will adversely affect pensioners and beneficiaries if nothing is done about it. But to suggest that we are now condemned for not taking remedial action for something which will not happen until the end of the year is politics of the worst kind. I repeat what I said before: We should have serious debate in this country about social security expenditure in this area, and about the development of a sensible policy. Some honourable senators say: 'Let us do this for $460m; let us do that for $320m'. If we are fiscally and financially irresponsible in our debating in that way, we will never reach a reasonable situation.

The first two premises in the motion are correct. I have said all along that of course Medicare will cause an artificial reduction in the CPI, and of course it will adversely affect people. But the crunch part of the motion aimed at this side of the House, that we did not recognise that fact, is patently and demonstrably wrong, as demonstrated by Senator Haines. To condemn us for not taking remedial action at this stage of the game, when such action should be appropriately taken in the next Budget is, I suggest, absolute nonsense and it should be recognised as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague Senator Walters for moving the motion on my behalf tonight. Unfortunately I was unavoidably detained. I will answer a few of the comments made by Senator Grimes in the course of his remarks which were quite remarkable. First and foremost, he accused the former Fraser Government of making no adjustment in respect of Medibank adjustments for the consumer price index in 1977. That is patently untrue. In fact, in all the circumstances in 1976, 1977 and at all other relevant times appropriate decisions were made to ensure that the consumer price index took full account of the true cost to pensions and was not adjusted artificially for the effect of health insurance. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a document prepared by the Education and Welfare Group of the Parliamentay Library Legislative Research Service which sets out that information.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

1. The effect of the original medibank showed in the Consumer Price Index for September Quarter 1975. The 1975 percentage increases over the previous quarter' s CPI were:
June-3.5
September-0.8 (Medibank)
December-5.6 (indirect tax rises)
(by way of comparison the respective figures for 1974 were 2.4, 4.1, 5.1 ( September) and 3.8).
Overall the relevant component of the CPI, 'Health and Personal Care' showed significant changes related to medibank. The percentage changes over the previous year were:
The changes in the overall CPI, 'All Groups', were:
2. During this period pensions were adjusted by Parliamentary Act rather than automatic indexation. Pension rates were adjusted twice in 1975-76 effective on 13 November 1975 and 13 May 1976.
Whitlam:

In the 1975-76 Budget (Mr Hayden) it was announced pensions would rise in Spring 1975 (November) in line with the CPI (December quarter 1974 to June quarter 1975) with the intention of a further rise in Autumn 1976 (May) in line with the CPI rise June to December quarter 1975.

Note: Up until the 1975-76 Budget the Labor Government had used as its target in pension rises an ultimate objective of 25 per cent of average weekly (male) earnings.
