TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Grimes, a little earlier in his remarks, made clear to us that he had recognised this problem. He may well have recognised it but he has certainly taken no action, and he has certainly given no assurance to the Senate, nor to the people who are most concerned, such as the combined pensioner associations in New South Wales who came to this city in November specifically to make this point at the head of their demands about the assets test and were given no undertaking that it would be corrected.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the reason for my raising the matter in the course of debate in the Budget session, subsequent to the introduction of the assets test, was to make the point that clearly this Government did not know what it was doing because already at that stage more than six months had passed since its election and no promises were made to pensioners, except that a capital gains tax would be levied in the form of an assets test against pensions in a most inequitable and discriminatory manner. For that reason I put down this motion in November. It evoked no immediate action on the part of the Government. But subsequently, by virtue of Press releases over the Christmas period, we flushed out the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) when he was the Acting Minister for Social Security, who gave us a statement, apparently in the early part of January, which indicated that the Government had realised the potential effect of this particular adjustment. Certainly, he did that. But he did not then give us any further assurance that there would be any adjustment to the pension in the way that the Fraser Government had given that undertaking and had carried it out in 1976 and 1977. Following all the complaints that have arisen with regard to the Minister' s handling of pension matters, and, in particular, the assets test in recent times-even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was forced to override his Minister in these circumstances-it has become clear that the pensioner community has little faith in what the Minister has to say on this matter. Clearly, while he is prepared to say that he recognises the problem, he is not prepared to give any undertakings. For that reason this motion is highly relevant.

I have one other point to make; that is, notwithstanding the Minister's present recognition of the importance of the issue-he claims that he recognised it last May-it was left to the Prime Minister in his recent telephone interview in Hobart to indicate to us that the reduction in the CPI will in some way favourably affect pensioners by virtue of the fact that it will reduce the rate of inflation and consequently, it will somehow help them in the way in which they live. The Minister has not indicated that that is so. It was the Prime Minister who gave that kind of assurance to the pensioners of Australia. We all know in this country who is the most powerful person when it comes to making decisions in regard to pensioners. It is not the Minister; the Prime Minister makes a decision and announces it over the head of his Minister whenever he feels so inclined. This is another case of such action occurring. For that reason I am afraid the pensioner community of Australia has little faith in the Minister's undertakings on this matter. Pensioners will not be fobbed off by the kind of statement he has given us tonight which says that the matter will be considered in a Budget context. What the pensioner community wants is a clear indication that in fact this will be corrected. It was only in the last week that I had this very matter raised with me by pensioner groups in Ballarat as a very significant issue which is worrying pensioner groups at present.

I make that final point on the understanding that the Minister does in fact recognise the problem and is prepared to do something about it. Having re- emphasised his commitment to a rise in the pension to 25 per cent of the average weekly earnings I believe that we will all be very justifiably looking for some results in that area in the months ahead. I am reminded of Senator Sir John Carrick's analysis of the problem when it is disclosed to us that this adjustment, artificially made by virtue of the Medicare payments, will relate not only to the question of health insurance and the way it affects pensioners but also the way it very significantly affects wage levels in the community generally. As such there will be a double-barrelled effect on the pensioner community. That creates a significant problem. I hope that the Government will pay attention to the motion which in effect is only another way of bringing to the attention of the Government the detrimental effects on pensioners of the particular adjustments which the Government intends to promote in the economy in the course of the next few months.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) deplores the decision of the Victorian Government to close (and sell) 4 hostels which were used for the accommodation of more than 200 country students in the Melbourne metropolitan area;

(b) condemns the failure of the Australian and Victorian Governments to accede to widespread complaints made by rural councils, student organisations and concerned parents against this decision which is a clear breach of ALP education policy; and

(c) urges the Australian Government to reach early agreement with the Victorian Government providing for the continued financing of the hostels so that essential facilities exist for country students seeking to acquire tertiary education.

This motion relates to action which the Victorian Government took and is taking this month to auction some four former hostels which last year housed around 200 country students. Three of those hostels are in St Kilda Road and Queens Road. They are central positions in Melbourne and very convenient for students at colleges. The fourth hostel is at Clayton near Monash University. The closure has caused a great deal of alarm and concern by very many organisations of students, country shires and towns and their representatives, church organisations and other people who are concerned at the displacement of hundreds of students.

I mention four hostels, but there is some suggestion that the number of hostels may be as much as eight. I think some unserviced hostels were closed at the end of 1982 thereby reducing the numbers. As I understand there are remaining some six hostels altogether that have some 450 students on the waiting list. I trust that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) will let us know the precise number of hostels that are closing this month and those to be closed later so we will know exactly how far the matter is going. I have taken the minimum figure of four hostels and more than 200 students in my motion. Neither the State nor the Federal Government is prepared to accept responsibility now for the resulting accommodation crisis facing Victoria's tertiary students. That is a matter of concern and this motion is an endeavour to ensure that that responsibility is faced at an early date by both governments .

As I said complaints have come from all kinds of areas in Victoria since about August 1983. At that time Mr John Radford the Liberal Member of the Legislative Council for Bendigo raised these matters with the State Minister of Education. Since that time Mr Radford, with other people has conducted a very strong campaign. Many people have written to him. Indeed I have with me a very thick file of correspondence which he has supplied to me. These are complaints from student organisations one of which is called HEAT, Hostel Emergency Action Team, consisting of students parents and others led by Murray Bickerdike. This group is working strongly to avoid what is happening now; namely, that students will not have the opportunity this year of taking part in tertiary education because there is no accommodation for them. In addition and since Mr Radford's campaign started the matter has also been raised in this Parliament. My colleague Senator Austin Lewis asked a question in this place on 6 October 1983. He will no doubt be saying more about this. In passing and in dealing with the historical nature of this dispute I quote from a supplementary question when he pressed the matter and used these significant words:
. . . does that mean that there will certainly be nothing done for these students during 1984 but that she will be bringing down something for them in the 1984 Budget, possibly to apply in 1985?
The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, replied:
No, it does not mean that. It means that I will address the problem of these particular hostels when it is presented to me in detail.
Whatever her intention that answer has unfortunately turned out to be false. It is clear that the effect in 1984 will be calamitous and that no arrangements have been made for students at all.

What is the role played by these government hostels in Victoria? They have existed for some years now. In the first place they were designed mainly for student teachers. Thousands of students came mainly from country areas of Victoria to study at universities and tertiary colleges in Melbourne. They needed to do this because there was not the accommodation in the country towns. Of course, accommodation for other people was freely available perhaps in university residential colleges and halls, but this was not so for students at Melbourne's various other tertiary colleges. The position in the last year was that some one-third of tertiary students came from the country. Unfortunately figures indicate that while I think one-third applied for positions and were offered positions in tertiary institutions only about one-quarter were able to proceed to enrol. So only 25 per cent instead of 33 per cent actually enrolled, partly because of difficulties in accommodation and other cost factors. These matters have been drawn to the attention of the Government by many experts who have studied this area.

The position is that over recent years the numbers of student teachers have declined and the emphasis has moved rather to other tertiary students undertaking full time study. I think a majority of people in the hostels are still studying teaching. The dependence has been very much for accommodation primarily for first year students coming in from the country because of the difficulties which they have in settling into a new environment in the city. Generally they are young students who after the first year very often move out into shared accommodation. It is very important for them to be acclimatised to that life and to have the company and assistance of people who are perhaps studying in the same area. One of the significant features of the hostels is that last year 63 per cent of the people in hostels to be closed were women. I do not have to prove to Senator Ryan that women students are a disadvantaged class who surely come within the Australian Labor Party policy as people requiring help. Such people will be great sufferers if this action is taken.

It is unrealistic to expect people who want tertiary education to be able to find accomodation elsewhere. They leave their homes. They must have accommodation under supervision and this is what the hostels offered them. They provided fairly low cost accommodation. It is important to realise that these hostels were not for students from wealthy backgrounds as might otherwise be thought. The evidence which has been supplied to me indicates that they came mostly from state high schools or state schools. Also, on the whole, they came from fairly low income families. The academic opportunities which students had will now be denied to many of them. I will read two extracts from some of the many cases which have been brought to my attention. For example, the Shire of Metcalfe has written to the Hon. John Radford in these terms:

Those of us who have children at tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area know how difficult it is to arrange for them to obtain private accommodation and we know of the personal problems that can occur when private accommodation is found because it is not always possible for these students to have a room available in which they may study privately. Hostels offer the most suitable form of accommodation for country students and their closing could well have the effect of denying adequate secondary and tertiary opportunities to country students.
Another shire, the shire of Marong writes in these terms:

Council considers such a proposal represents yet another action by the Government to discriminate against country students and country people in general. By eliminating what is reported to be eight hostels the Government is effectively subjecting students from the country to hardships not encountered by the majority of city students.

I move to the next question. If student accommodation hostels are to be closed, what are the alternative types of accommodation? Is other accommodation available that would be equally satisfactory? The answer, of course, is no. The Student Housing Officers' Association has provided considerable evidence of this . There are colleges and halls of residence at Melbourne University and elsewhere which have limited places but their median price is $70 a week and up to $120 a week. Of course last year this Government cut the subsidy for accommodation in colleges by some 25 per cent adding to the difficulties there. Other alternatives, like full board, are hard to find. Offers have dramatically declined in recent years and few of them are to be found in the vicinity of campuses. They are also costly. In public housing the State Government has a program called the shared housing program but the waiting times are so long that it is unsuitable. Generally people are required to take the accomodation for up to two years which may not be what is required. Very often after the first year a student will share accommodation with someone elsewhere. Likewise private rental is hard to find at a reasonable price.

What is the attitude taken by the Victorian Government and the Federal Government to this problem? Neither government will accept responsibility for providing tertiary housing in hostels. So far as the Victorian Government is concerned it is interesting to note that the ALP State policy on the sale of property of the Department of Education-which of course this is-is as follows:

1. All decisions about disposal of education land and buildings must be made democratically having regard to statewide policies and needs as well as those at the local level. The procedures must involve the local education community and the statewide education community.
2. No changes must take place without detailed study of the impact of the changes proposed at all levels (local and State). All studies must be conducted publicly.

It is quite clear-it has been pointed out by the Hostels Emergency Action Team- that many of these details have been forgotten by the State in its decision to close the hostels. No regard has been paid to needs, nor have the local or State communities either education or otherwise been consulted and nor have they had any part in making the decision. Finally, there has been no public detailed study of the impact of the changes. There does not appear to have been any study at all. The Premier, Mr Cain, when he was Acting Minister of Education wrote to Mr Radford in January. After saying that he had considered the matter carefully and that he was reluctant to do it he stated:

The Victorian Government is obliged to assert its priorities which must be on the provision of services to schools. The Federal Government in 1974 accepted responsibility for tertiary education, and this included the provision of student welfare services, the time has now come when the State Government must reduce its commitment in this area.
The hostels to be sold have been offered to the Commonwealth Government in the hope that they will continue to be used for tertiary students.

Before that letter was written the Minister of Housing in Victoria Mr Cathie passed the buck to the education ministry saying that it was not really housing' s responsibility but that of the Education Department. In this letter the Premier of Victoria said that it is not the responsibility of Victoria but is a responsibility that must be passed to the Commonwealth. It is not as though a big cost is involved in keeping these hostels going. In 1982-83 the cost of a subsidy for the cheaper meals and upkeep of the houses was $500,000. I think that at time that was spread over something like 16 hostels. We are not dealing in a State education budget with anything other than a small pittance in money but it is an enormous thing to deprive persons of the opportunity for tertiary education.

I see by the correspondence that in October Mr Fordham the State Minister of Education applied to Senator Ryan's Department for funds. This application appears to have been knocked back. The timing of the State Government's decision is, I think, a very cunning one. One notes that it has been done towards the end of the year. It has given the Federal Government an opportunity to buy the hostels which it will not do. Of course the Federal Government says that it will not bring down its Budget until next August so it has already made its financial commitment for education for 1984. Therefore in the period in between there will be no provision for students. The Federal Government is, apparently, unable it says to do anything to resolve the accommodation crisis facing students. Yet I remind the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs that her Federal policy is one which requires equity of participation for disadvantaged groups. I put it to her that country students and the women students in particular surely come within the area of the disadvantaged. This is an area for which the Government should accept responsibility.

All that the Minister is able to say is that she will come up with new proposals for the next Budget but that is not good enough. That is why I have moved the motion. I see that the honourable member for Bendigo, Mr Brumby, who got an unfortunate serve yesterday from his ministerial colleague, on 5 November once again spoke gloriously of the 3,000 new places in tertiary education that this Government is providing. What hypocrisy, what a shameless charade it is, to say that in one breath and to take away the opportunity of education for a number of students in this way. If these hostels are closed and not reopened there will be a clear discrimination against country students and country people in general. It is not surprising that throughout the rural areas there is a great deal of concern. Many country students have already been forced to withdraw from tertiary courses because they cannot find places to live in Melbourne.

Material is available from a number of sources which demonstrates that this is so. Mr Vince Callaghan, the student service co-ordinator at the Melbourne College of Advanced Education, believes that about 200 students throughout the State tertiary institutions have had to give up their studies because of this decision. Dr Geoffrey Vaughan, the Chairman of the Victorian Conference of Principals of Colleges of Advanced Education, said that there had been cases of students not being able to accept course offers or to continue their studies because of the accommodation shortage. He further said:

It is incongruous for the Government to encourage higher participation rates in tertiary education at a time when there is an acute shortage of suitable accommodation in Melbourne and in country centres.

Other experts such as Dr G. Elsworth who wrote a paper in 1982 called 'Rural Disadvantage in Transition to Higher Education' have made it very clear that opportunities for rural students are very poor. They were already bad before this decision was taken. In fact the percentage of students coming from the country-I think the participation rate was 18 per cent for rural males-reduces by the time they take up positions to 11 per cent. So there is already a great loss for people who have talent but who are under a considerable disadvantage because of the additional costs of education in the cities.

I point out a couple of other factors. Page 21 of the excellent submission presented quite recently by the Student Housing Officers Association in Victoria to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission states:

There seems little doubt that the provision of student housing is a joint Federal/State responsibility. The Federal Government through the CTEC has already set a precedence in this area as it has always provided funds to the Universities to build their Collegiate Halls of Residence and subsidizes continuing operations . . . Likewise, the Federal Government has specific policy concerning a greater equity of participation in higher education for disadvantaged groups.

The submission points out the fact that 63 per cent of this group is women. Lest there be any suggestion that these students are rich children from rich families in the country, the Student Housing Officers' Association discovered in its survey that:

The profile of country students living in the city hostels is that most come from families earning less than the average income (approximately $360 per week) , nearly two-thirds are in receipt of at least some Government financial assistance TEAS and 83 per cent will need employment, whether part-time, casual or vacation in order to complete their studies. Further, the majority of students in the hostels are female and more than two-thirds of respondents attended State High Schools. In short, these students come from families that are far from wealthy.

So I suggest that this has been a disastrous decision by the State Government of Victoria. It is a disastrous decision by the Federal Government and cannot be allowed to fall between the interstices of Federal and State juggling to avoid responsibility. The responsibility is on both Governments to get together and find a way out of this mess. For that reason I have moved this motion. It is a moderate motion because the situation is probably even worse than I disclosed in it. But it is causing tremendous concern throughout the community in Victoria and particularly the rural community. I suggest that it cannot be passed off or left till next year but is a matter which is of urgent necessity for this Government to attend to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must explain to Senator Macklin that I rise because I am informed that the time for this debate is almost finished and I feel that I must make some response to what Senator Missen had to say. I do not question the problems and difficulties faced by many students seeking places in higher education in Victoria as outlined by Senator Missen. I do not quarrel with his presentation of the view that there is a desperate shortage of places for higher education. Of course students who have to travel from country areas and seek places in city institutions are faced with enormous difficulties if they cannot find suitable accommodation. I would deny none of the difficulties Senator Missen set out tonight. But I say to Senator Missen that although I agree that the difficulties of these students have been compounded by the decision of the Victorian Government to close down a number of hostels that were previously available for tertiary students, his complaint about this ought really to be directed towards the Victorian Government. The Commonwealth Government does not have responsibility for these hostels. When the Commonwealth Government assumed responsibility for the funding of higher education in 1974 the Victorian Government did not seek any recurrent assistance for these hostels. Of course the hostels are a carry over from earlier times. I understand that the Victorian Government had its own pressures and its own need to rationalise its activities.

SPEECH.PARA: There is indeed a crisis in student accommodation. Indeed, there is a desperate shortage of low cost accommodation for young people, whatever their circumstances. I submit that probably young people who are not students and who are perhaps unemployed have even worse accommodation problems than those that Senator Missen has outlined tonight. I do not want to get into a position of defending a situation which is not defensible. We need many more suitable hostels for young people, including students. In recognition of that fact our Government has asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to review future arrangements for support for student accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't report for another year.
—Yes, I am expecting to receive this advice in April of this year.
—But that would be May.

—Senator Macklin and, indeed, Senator Missen in his remarks, suggested that somehow the Commonwealth Government can magically find the money at the end of the triennium after all moneys have been allocated to step in and fill a gap which has been left suddenly by a State Government. It would be desirable for that to happen but it is simply not the case that the finances of the Commonwealth were left in the situation where excess money was floating around which could have been used for these purposes. It is also the case that accommodation problems are experienced by students all over Australia, not just by those who might have found places in Victorian hostels. If we were magically suddenly able to find money to solve the problems of the Victorian Government in respect of these hostels, I am sure that Senator Macklin from Queensland or some other senator from Western Australia or New South Wales could suddenly say: 'We have accommodation problems for our students too'.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not enough time for me to make a lengthy exposition of our approach to this. I say just a couple of things. The Government is reviewing comprehensively the needs of students for accommodation and, in that light, reviewing the needs of those students who prefer hostels and, those who seek private accommodation. Indeed, it is reviewing the situation of those colleges within universities and colleges of advanced education which at this stage receive a substantial subvention from the Commonwealth. We cannot take a one-off decision in respect of hostels for which we have no responsibility. If indeed we did that would simply be seen as a precedent for other States which also have their problems.

I point out too-I think that Senator Missen at one stage used the word ' hypocritical' and I do not want to retaliate in that vein-that the crisis in accommodation, like the crisis of the excess of demand for higher education places this year, is the result of the rundown in capital funding of higher education over a number of years. I am sure that Senator Missen, being an honest and sincere senator, would not deny that. I have the figures here, but time does not permit me to go into them in any detail. But everybody knows that in each successive Budget under the Fraser Administration there was a rundown in capital funding to institutions of higher education. That meant that their capacity to provide student places was greatly reduced. Therefore, the demand for other forms of accommodation-that is, forms other than the accommodation provided by universities or colleges of advanced education-has become consequently greater and greater. This year, as I have pointed out before, we have an enormously high demand for places in higher education. That is something the Government has encouraged. That is something we have welcomed. But we are not able immediately to make up the deficit in accommodation, be it accommodation for study or living accommodation, that we have inherited over seven years.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
