SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate (9.34)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think this item will be dealt with as quickly as the last. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That proposed new standing order 36AAA, as set out in Attachment A, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard this matter as one of considerable seriousness and concern for the Parliament and the public of Australia. Therefore, on behalf of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That' and add the following words:
Proposed new standing order 36AAB (Attachment B) as recommended by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee be adopted.

The amendment will be seconded by Senator Tate, the Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The proposed standing order which was considered and amended by the Standing Orders Committee has been circulated to all honourable senators in the chamber today. Before going into the details of the report before us, practically all of which I regard as extraordinary and inaccurate, I remind this chamber that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was appointed on 19 November 1981 after a somewhat hectic debate and some divisions. It was appointed on a temporary basis with the same membership as the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It was appointed on a trial basis and was to report by 30 June 1982. The Committee was given temporary standing orders. The Committee did report, and the ninth report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee of 20 May 1982 sets out the reasons why the Committee, after investigation, decided that certainly the operation of the Committee had been successful. I will say dogmatically that it seems to have been accepted in the Parliament and in the community that the emergence of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has increased the facility of the Senate and that the type of legislation we have passed has been improved by it. Although the then Government was very critical of the Committee's appointment and thought it would hold up legislation, it readily acknowledged some months later that it was not having that effect. Both that Government and this Government since have accepted that it is doing an effective and useful job.

The notice of motion given by me on 20 May 1982 was to put the Committee on a firm basis. Unfortunately it does not appear in that fashion in the report of the Standing Orders Committee. In a moment I shall go through the sections of that report paragraph by paragraph to show where it is in error. The motion was adopted on 25 May 1982. The Committee had the same membership but then became a permanent committee of this Senate. It is contingent only upon the necessity for its recommended standing orders to be considered by the Standing Orders Committee and reported upon. It has taken all this time, nearly two years, for the Standing Orders Committee to get debate on this matter before this chamber. I hope that some honourable senators are listening because I point out first and foremost that the Committee has been operating under the Standing Orders-

TALK.START.PARA: —We are listening.
—I know some are, but others are not. It is a Committee of this chamber and perhaps concerns back bench senators more than executive officers. They have a bit of a conspiracy--
—We are all equal senators.
—We are all equal senators, but unfortunately the conspiracy against this Committee is coming mainly from executive sources.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. I cannot compel attention ; I can compel silence.

—We have got some scars over the last couple of years from the treatment we have received at the Standing Orders Committee. I shall talk about them tonight. What has to be realised is that those standing orders which have been rejected and mutilated by the Standing Orders Committee are the standing orders under which we have been operating almost for the last two years. I challenge any honourable senator to show that we have misused them or that in any way their use has been shown to be objectionable. As to the Standing Orders Committee, we had a great deal of trouble even getting this report out of it. At the end of 1982, prior to the last election, it will be remembered that I made a somewhat critical speech in this chamber on 17 November. I shall not repeat the criticisms that I was then making at the delays in the Standing Orders Committee work.
—You threatened to resign.

—That is true. I lost my chairmanship with the change of government not long after that, so it would not have made much difference. I want to remind honourable senators of the other factors. The Committee was reappointed on 22 April 1983. The membership, despite the fact that it was supposed to be the same membership as the Standing Committee on Constitutioned and Legal Affairs, has been altered quite a bit since then, because people have wanted to drop out. So we have been in a very awkward position of allegedly having to be of the same membership as the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee but having lots of variations in the meantime. Now comes this report which is the cause of the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me speak of some of the things in this report. Something is ignored in paragraph 5, in which it is said:
. . . in May 1982 . . . the Committee
-that is our Committee-
recommended a new standing order for this purpose, and this standing order was referred to this Committee for consideration.
It ignores the fact that the report was adopted by the Senate without the slightest dissent. What was sent to the Standing Orders Committee was the vetting of the proposed standing order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may mean that no one read it.

—Ignorance of the law is no excuse, Senator, and I should think that ignorance by senators of reports is no excuse, either. We set out in that report what were the necessities for the Committee, and it was adopted. The Committee report then goes on to speak about the proposed new standing order, the one that was criticised, and says that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . contains a number of provisions which were not contained in the original resolution appointing the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on 19 November 1981, and which are taken from Standing Order 36AA, relating to the appointment and functioning of the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees.

That is quite so. What the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has done is to recommend that it should have the same powers, basically, as have those Committees that have been set up since 1970 and not the outdated and very inadequate standing orders which the Joint Select Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has had to work under for some years. It has been in existence for 50 years. I served as its chairman for two or three years. Of course it is so that there are a number of things in the standing orders of that Committee which should not be duplicated. In fact, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee's standing orders ought to be reformed and brought up to date. That is what is necessary-not to send another Committee into the burdens under which it has, therefore, to suffer .

Let us look at the various things on page 5 of the report which are apparently concerning some of the members of the Standing Orders Committee. Among them is the holding of public hearings. Every other Standing Committee is entitled to have public hearings. What goes with that is the daily Hansards, and so forth, which are all to be struck out of the standing order. The idea is that it would meet in private. As is said further down the page:
. . . the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which works by deliberating in private upon the legislation . . .

It does not always meet in private. It calls public evidence on occasions. It calls witnesses before it. People can attend. But it has no specific right to sit in public or to have Hansards. Those things are put in the later standing orders. One of the other powers that has been objected to is the power to admit other senators. There is a specific provision that we have put in the standing orders, the same as for the legislative and general purpose committees, that other members of the Senate should be able to sit in, where they are interested, and take part in deliberations. They would not vote, but that is exactly the same power that eight other committees of this Parliament have but which was to be denied to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is the same with the admission of representatives of the news media into its presence. Furthermore, as to the general power we inserted into this to have advisers, it was suggested that we should have only counsellors, not advisers. I suppose that we might become very extravagant and invite all kinds of people to advise the Committee and that would cause a lot of cost. Of course, the answer to that is that the President has to vet any such things. With counsel, advisers or anyone, he has to be satisfied that such advice is justifiable and that expenditure can be made available for it. There is ample proof; there is no suggestion that this is wrongly used by the other standing committees. Why would it be wrongly used by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee?

I had the opportunity of appearing before the Standing Orders Committee last year. Senator Tate was absent at the time and I represented him. There was certainly no indication there of substantial objection. I was asked questions about these matters and asked whether we would use those powers. I said that we had not used a number of the powers yet but that we may use them, although we did not have any plans to do so in the foreseeable future. But it is set out in this report as though we will not use them in the future. The fact is that we may well do so, and there is no reason why the Committee should not have those powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what occasions would you use them?

—Where there is a Bill to which there are critical or technical objections and a lot of public interest in its terms, we may well want to sit in public to allow people to attend. Another thing that we want is to be able to move out of Canberra. Under the standing order which we propose, we could do what other committees can do-sit elsewhere in Australia. Other committees can sit elsewhere outside the country if they get permission. But that was to be denied to this Committee and therefore it could not go to places where there might be particular objection and where, for the convenience of the public, one ought to be able to go to hear people's views.
—If there were a question of retrospectivity, would you be able to call a witness before you to establish whether there was retrospectivity, such as the Commissioner of Taxation, or some such person?

—I suppose so, yes. I do not think that there would be any reason why we could not call a person for that purpose. I do not think that the matter has cropped up. I think that retrospectivity generally appears on the face of the legislation and we do not seem to have much trouble in finding retrospectivity here, there and everywhere, as the Regulations and Ordinances Committee does with regulations, as Senator Lewis knows. I do not think that one would have very much difficulty in finding it, but one might want to know why it was there and what was the purpose of putting it in.
—What about policy?

—This Committee does not go into the policy of these matters. It advises particularly on matters such as retrospectivity, things which might be contrary to the civil liberties of the community, and so forth. Therefore, it asks the Minister why he has put it in. Quite often it writes to him and asks him. So there is no reason why it should not find out from people who would know why there might be a good reason why they should not complain about that retrospectivity. So I suppose that it verges on policy. Sometimes both of those Committees have problems which verge upon policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is, as I say, that the various powers which were sought by the Committee are available to the other committees of the Parliament, and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has had these powers for some 22 months now. If they are taken away by a vote tonight, it will obviously be a vote of no confidence by the Senate in the operation of that Committee. I would think that it would be a matter to be taken to the public, to see whether people would accept that this reform, probably the best reform of the previous Parliament in a parliamentary procedure sense, should be truncated in this way.

Among the other things being taken away by the proposal in this report is, of course, the power to have sub-committees. Why should the Committee not have sub- committees, particularly if it were able to move--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr Chairman, would the Committee be inclined to give Senator Missen a short extension of time? If so, I would be pleased to move it.
—It can be done, but of course in Committee honourable senators have the right to speak more than once. It is perfectly in order to move an extension of time.
—No, I do not think I require an extension, Mr Chairman. I think I have mainly covered the points I want to cover and Senator Tate will be speaking to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on this matter as a member of the Standing Orders Committee which I think I can characterise as having approached this topic with an open mind, at the front only, and with a fair degree of good will and favourable disposition towards the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I say at the outset that I think Senator Missen's speech, particularly the last part where he said that it would be a vote of no confidence in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee if the proposal which he has suggested were not adopted and that the Committee would take the matter to the public if necessary, really--
—Would it block Supply?

—Perhaps. I think that really was a little too much of an over- reaction to the suggestions made by the Standing Orders Committee in relation to this matter. The character of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-I use the word in its most favourable sense-is not in question in what is suggested by the Standing Orders Committee. We considered the matter for some time. We had a pretty frank discussion about the proposal and then we had the benefit of hearing about it at some length from Senator Missen. It was after we heard from him that we decided that we could not agree with the view that was being put and which is being put in the Committee of the Whole tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen in the course of his remarks said that he thought he had covered most things, but he really has not covered two points which I think are quite crucial to the decision of the Standing Orders Committee. Before I go to those points I just remind him of paragraph (9) on page 7 of the report of the Standing Orders Committee. It states:
Should it appear in the future that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee requires any or all of the provisions in question, it may be appropriate for the Senate to consider the matter again.

I mention that only because the Standing Orders Committee was not satisfied in any way that the powers of this Committee would be exercised when necessary and as sought by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The essential point to which Senator Missen did not refer is contained in paragraph (7) where the Standing Orders Committee draws a distinction between a committee such as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which it sees as akin in character to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and the legislative and general purpose standing committees of the Senate-those committees which were established, as Senator Missen pointed out, in 1970. There seems to be a number of things in the standing order which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee sought to have adopted by the Standing Orders Committee-proposed standing order 36AAB, which appears as Attachment B in the report-which draw attention, in the Committee's view, to the differences between the class of a committee such as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the legislative and general purpose standing committees. For example, the last paragraph of the proposed standing order reads:
The Committee may authorise the televising of public hearings of the Committee, at the discretion of the Committee, and under such rules as the Senate may adopt .

I do not think we have got very far down the track with the question of televising the deliberations of parliament. Plenty of senators, including myself , would be opposed to that course. The strongest advocate of televising parliamentary proceedings with the greatest respect, would not begin with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee as a body which would attract the interest and the ratings of the Australian masses.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you deny the possibility.
—Senator Missen says that it is a possibility. I just make the point that I do not think it is a possibility.
—No, I said you deny the possibility.

—No, I do not deny the possibility of almost anything, but I come pretty close to it when I contemplate the Scrutiny of Bills Committee being on television, which is as close as I will ever get, probably.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matters mentioned in proposed standing order 36AAB are the public hearings of the Committee, the right to admit the media, the right for honourable senators to attend with a capacity to ask questions but not to participate in decisions and so on; that is, to make the Committee's activities much more public and to make it, as it were, something of a showpiece which it is currently not. It has been performing its function best, and very well in my view, as a relatively private committee of the Senate as the Regulations--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?
—Because I read the reports and they are of outstanding quality.
—But you have nothing to compare it with.

—There is plenty to compare it with. There is the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, which also does an excellent job. Those committees, in my view, and I think the view of other members of the Standing Orders Committee, are very outstanding functional committees of the Senate. They perform very important functions, but they are not functions which, in the opinion of the Standing Orders Committee, should be exposed to the sorts of procedures set out in the standing order suggested by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the important point of the Standing Orders Committee report is contained in paragraph (7) of the report. I speak on this matter because whatever results from this debate I would not want Senator Missen to go away from this chamber thinking that the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was anything but admired, as I believe it is, by a vast majority of honourable senators. The importance of that Committee is very much recognised, but the Standing Orders Committee was not prepared to take the next step and say that because we hold that belief these things should follow in terms of the Standing Orders. I think that is the essence of the judgment of the Standing Orders Committee and, I hope, the Committee of the Whole. I commend the Standing Orders Committee's report and the motion to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general I support the remarks made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I did not attend the meeting of the Senate Standing Orders Committee when it considered this matter, but I listened to what Senator Missen had to say with very great interest. In a sense I regard myself as the father of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee because it was conceived when I had a very brief flirtation with parliamentary reform before I became a Minister and decided that parliarmentary reform was highly undesirable. I had the embarrassment of objecting on behalf of the Fraser Government to the establishment of this Committee. I must say that I was deeply relieved that the defeat was quick and the success was so obvious. I join particularly with Senator Button in saying that I think there is a very widespread view in the Senate and beyond the Senate that the Committee has functioned very well. I think that is evident from the very significant number of amendments which have been made to Bills because of the Committee's suggestion. It was somewhat ironic that, having opposed its establishment on behalf of the then Government, I was, I think, the first Minister to accept amendments put forward by the Committee, which were directed to Bills which I was looking after on behalf of the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon. I was impressed by the very reasonable way that both he and his Department responded to the very sensible suggestions which were made by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The real reason this Committee is needed is that there has been something of a change in the way honourable senators have approached their work. There is a great deal of committee work. I believe that most honourable senators work very hard but I think fewer and fewer honourable senators read Bills. By that I mean read them in the careful way in which some of the former honourable senators such as Sir Reginald Wright did with careful regard to the technical content of the legislation as against the broad policy considerations. I think it is essential for those of us who deal with the great flood of legislation that comes to the Parliament, except perhaps during this session, to have the feeling that there has been a checklist or a checking out of the legislation to make sure that, in a technical sense, we are not unwittingly infringing the liberty of the people we represent.

I think it is true that the rather dry way in which the Committee proceeds, with its reliance upon counsel rather than advisers, the fact that it meets in the way in which the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has met for so long and so successfully, gives its reports an authority which a different approach might do something to reduce rather than increase. I certainly accept that, if it could be shown that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee or the Scrutiny of Bills Committee were being hampered in their operations, they simply could not perform because of some difficulty arising from these restrictions, then the Senate would have a duty to quickly examine that to see whether we needed to change the rules.

But, having listened very carefully to Senator Missen whose views are worth listening to because he has had a great deal to do with the early success of the Committee, as has Senator Tate who is in the chamber for this Committee discussion, my own judgment would be that his views are worthy of serious consideration. Having listened to him carefully I think that the Standing Orders Committee was right to adopt the approach that it has. I believe it would be better if the Committee proceeded along the track that has already been established knowing that, should there be restrictions hampering its work, because of the value that has been placed on its work by the Senate and indeed by successive governments, any approach to the Senate based on real problems would be likely to receive sympathetic consideration.

But I would be full of regret if Senator Missen, Senator Tate, or any of the other people who have succeeded in a very short time in establishing the reputation of this Committee were to regard the view that I have expressed or the views that have been expressed by Senator Button as in some way an adverse comment on the Committee. Rather it is the reverse. I simply think there would be some risks in interfering with a formula which, in the case of Regulations and Ordinances Committee, has been successful for 50 years. In the case of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee it has been successful for a number of years. Indeed that success has far exceeded the ambitions which I initially had for this important reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. It has occurred to me that I should reply to some of the criticisms of the Senate Standing Orders Committee that were voiced by Senator Missen. Firstly, Senator Missen seemed to be aggrieved because the Standing Orders Committee took two years to come up with the decision. He has taken that somewhat as a personal affront. Having served on the past two Standing Orders Committee I assure Senator Missen that its deliberations are always extremely slow, so much so that at times I get frustrated. We do not just single out Senator Missen for obstruction and delay. We tend to spread that right round to every group which approaches us. I hope Senator Missen does not feel offended because of that delay. Secondly, dealing with Senator Missen's threat to take the matter to the public, I suggest that he does that before the hearings of Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills are televised because he will not get much support after they are televised. I wish to voice my only objection to the increased powers for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I must say that I was not a partisan in this matter . The whole matter has not concerned me greatly. But I worry about one aspect and that is whether the Scrutiny of Bills Committee will be turned into a circus . It is looking at legislation. If we start televising the hearings, calling public witnesses and moving all round Australia-
—That is true of all the committees.

—I am sorry, not all committees look at all legislation that comes before them. What worries me-it should worry Senator Crichton-Browne-is that all legislation will go to this Committee if it goes into public hearings. It will be touted all the way round Australia and all the debate on the legislation will be done through that Committee with all the publicity. People will try to misuse it. It will be very hard initially for people to misuse the Committee when either Senator Tate or Senator Missen is chairing it. But I look to the future, not just the present. It worries me that we will move to a sort of American committee type of system where people misuse committees for their own purposes.
—Has it happened with any other committees?

—In my view it may already happen to a degree with existing committees. But I think it would be a committee that covers all legislation. All legislation is referred to it. It could become a far more serious problem. We could start to get delays in reports of this Committee. The Committee itself has been lauded in the chamber tonight. I presume that it is doing a good job. I must say that I have never concentrated on its reports. I have left that to others. If the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is finding under the standing orders we propose that one or two extra powers are needed, they should be granted. But I do not see any need for the televising of its proceedings. I do not see any need for it to have the right to move around the country. It has been doing quite a good job by operating in Canberra and I think that should continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to talk about the standing orders which are sought for the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. That Committee, as has been conceded right around this chamber, has proved to be remarkably successful in its short history. I think its success has been somewhat unexpected as Senator Chaney pointed out. There was the initial reluctance, indeed obstinate refusal, of the previous Government to countenance the creation of such a committee. Then again Senator Robert Ray's speech stemmed from a fear on the part of the governments that such a committee would frustrate , impede or slow down the passage of legislation through this Parliament. That has not proved to be the case. In fact I submit that, by the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee taking account of those technical but, nevertheless, fundamental matters early in the piece, talking to the responsible Minister, and then ensuring that these matters were fully before the Senate when a Bill came into the chamber, this would probably save the time lags that occurred when Sir Reginald Wright had a flash of intuition that something was wrong with a particular clause and filibustered for several days in order to get the matter sorted out. I believe the Committee has worked in a way which has aided, if anything, the speedy passage through the Parliament of Bills which the Government desires and which can be explained in the face of the report of the Committee. It has not been obstructionist and, as I have said, it has not impeded the passage of legislation. Let us face it, what is really behind the attempt to force a constricted standing order on this Committee is a fear, as was well expressed by Senator Robert Ray, that somehow this Committee will embarrass or impede the Government in putting forward its legislation.
—That is not so.

—That is how I heard Senator Ray. I think it is a fundamental mistake on two grounds: Firstly, it should be released that what the Committee is being asked to do tonight is not to empower this Committee to have all these extra powers but to strip them away. In fact the Committee has had these powers for almost two years since May 1982. There has never been a hint of abuse or lack of political commonsense in the making use of these powers.
—Abuse or use.

—As Senator Button has pointed out in his interjection there is a distinction between a power and the use of that power. That is quite right. The transition is made by the judgment of those on the Committee who would have to vote, for example, to allow other honourable senators to participate in the proceedings-not in the voting, but in the general discussion on a particular matter where, for example, an honourable senator may have a point of view to put forward. It is only with the vote of the Committee that these extra powers-that is powers shared by the general committees-could be brought into operation. I cannot see such a committee putting itself in a situation where it embarrassed or impeded the Government by carrying on in a circus-type fashion as feared by Senator Ray. Why would we, as a committee, put our cordial relations with Ministers-which is what this whole process is about-at risk by such a process? I do not think we would. If the underlying fear is that the government might be embarrassed, frustrated or impeded in some way, let us not forget the voting pattern of the Committee. It is a six person committee with the Chairman having a casting vote, and it is unlikely that a government chairman would vote for a process, procedure or the exercise of a power which would involve that sort of situation developing which Senator Robert Ray pointed to. I do find overall the tone of the Standing Orders Committee report a touch patronising particularly in paragraph 7, where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: It will not be wise to endanger the successful operation of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.
I find that a little bit too paternalistic or maternalistic, whatever the common word is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fraternalistic.

—No, not fraternalistic either. There must be a phrase which covers the treating of the committee as children. I do believe that senators ought to be clear that they are being asked to strip the Committee of a power which it has had for two years, which it has not exercised in a way which is embarrassing or frustrating to the Government or the passage of its legislation and which is unlikely to be used in such a way. It ought to be left to the good sense of the Committee as to the exercise of those powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to contribute only a few thoughts. Really what is before the Standing Orders Committee is the task of putting down the right kind of standing order, and an ad hominem kind of argument about the admirable way in which the Committee has operated or is likely to operate is not really relevant. Our task is to identify what we think, for better or for worse, is the right kind of standing order and the right kind of relationship which this Committee should have to other committees of the Senate. I am attracted to the argument put down by Senator Button and Senator Chaney. I might just say one thing about some of Senator Missen's criticisms. It is not really appropriate to come in here and say the Standing Orders Committee is, in some way, not representative of the Senate, and its members in some way have other allegiances or other loyalties.
—Representative of the Senate-that is what it is.

—I heard what the honourable senator said and really, as a colleague and a friend, I would like to put to the honourable senator that we are senators too. We are all members of the Senate, and the Standing Orders of this place are as much the concern of one senator as they are of any other senator. It does not matter where one sits. It does not matter what one's position is: The Standing Orders are the same for the whole lot of us. The people who make up the Standing Orders Committee-I am not on the Standing Orders Committee any more-are working for the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I really think it does not help in this kind of debate if a finding is brought down which is adverse to what we might want to do other than argue it upon its merits. This is a difficult situation. Two cases can be made: Firstly, the one which has been argued eloquently by Senator Missen and by Senator Tate and which we understand; and secondly, the other position which has been put down by Senator Button and Senator Chaney. Anyone who votes on this eventually has to choose one of those positions. The fact that they choose one does not mean that they do not appreciate the arguments put the other way, but we are forced, in the end, to come down on balance for one or other view. I think we should just try to keep a level of good dealing between colleagues. I just hope that we will not at the end of this debate be putting criticism on the Standing Orders Commitee for carrying out the task which we as a Senate asked its members to do when we appointed them to that Committee to do the job for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney said that he was the father of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.
—I have had some phone calls that start like that.
—In all truth it appeared he did not sound as if he was too thrilled at what he had fathered. One perhaps ought to ask whether he had any assistance at all, whether it was an IVF or an AID--
—Or did he have a legitimate birth.

—Whatever way it was, Senator Missen, the child has come out extremely healthy and it is not the sort of retarded child that some of the comments in the Standing Orders Committee reports would make it out to be. It is in fact-I say this with all due modesty being a member of the Committee--
—As you always do.

—Indeed, as I always exhibit, Senator Baume. It is in fact a quite gifted child, considering that it had to fight through some odds simply to survive. Senator Tate is quite correct, the Standing Orders Committee comments in the report are patronising and condescending. Honourable senators talk about whether it is wise to endanger the successful operations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in the same sort of tone one would use in talking about whether it is wise to give a child a loaded gun, for goodness sake. There is no reason for taking this sort of attitude. Senator Button's argument that because we have not used certain powers is no reason for us either retaining them or adding new ones is not particularly sensible or rational either. It is certainly not the sort of argument that would be sustainable in real life. We do not argue that about any other sort of area.

SPEECH.PARA: What this argument is really about and what the whole debate is about is whether this Committee should even exist and whether or not the Executive wants the Senate or one of its committees, particularly one which looks in such close detail at Government legislation, to get too big for its boots. That is basically what this is all about. It is about containing and controlling a committee which has had more success than its father ever thought it would have and certainly, as part of the off-spring, I am very glad indeed that it has had that success. I might add that some of it has been due to the good offices and attention that Senator Macklin has paid to the Committee's early reports in picking up some of the anomalies and infringement of liberties that were pointed out by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. This certainly gave the Committee members in those early stages a bit of a boost when they thought that, in fact, they had been pushed into a back room and were being left to die. So certainly the Committee has developed in a way that perhaps was not anticipated and has been successful in a way that was not anticipated. In fact, I understand that it is now common practice in departments for the bureaucrats to consider what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would do to a Bill and to clauses in a Bill before it puts a draft to the Minister. I think that in its own right is a fantastic achievement for this Committee. If in any way at all allowing it to retain the powers it has or to expand them can extend the value of that Committee I would give three cheers. It is about time the Committee was treated as a grown up member of the Senate committee system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a moment tonight Senator Button almost sounded very reactionary and conservative to me. I did not realise quite how being in goverment changes ones character. I must say that listening to the debate so far and at the risk of sawing sawdust I am inclined to the view that there is no threat to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's capacity, confidence, integrity or ability by providing it with extended standing orders which it seeks for itself. It has had standing orders now for something like twenty-two months and there have been no disasters, no embarrassments and no upsets. Nobody sought to demonstrate tonight that by being cloaked with those powers there has been any aberrations that would cause the Government or members of the Committee embarrassment in any way. As an original member of this Committee I know that it was discussed by our side of politics with some reservations. I suspect in the hearts of many people the reservations were that it might embarrass the Government or impede legislation. Of course, all those concerns and anxieties are being found to have no substance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has performed very well. It has had these powers for 22 months. I do not believe-I can be corrected-that there has been a call for the use of the powers which caused concern in the past. I do not believe it is necessary for the Committee to call for them in the future. I would have thought that government ought not to be frightened about public comment in respect of legislation that falls within the terms of reference of the Committee. In fact, they should encourage it. I understood the Labor Party to have been talking about consensus and public participation. There are Standing Orders which are embraced by all of the other standing committees. I do not believe there have been occasions when there has been concern that they have those provisions. In regard to the arguments put forward by Senator Ray, almost without exception most standing committees can take upon themselves terms of reference which would be just as wide and as encompassing in many respects as those which are enshrined by this Committee. There is no logic in drawing a distinction between this Committee and any other committee, particularly as for the last 22 months this Committee has performed under those Standing Orders which it seeks to have continued for the Committee in the future. I do not believe anybody has put forward an argument so far that they should be removed, except to say there might be some concern for the future, and so far that has not been demonstrated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak as the Chairman of the Senate Standing Orders Committee in order to defend the reputation of all members of the Standing Orders Committee. I assure Senator Crichton-Browne that it is not a Government committee. The Standing Orders Committee is a committee of the Senate, representing all points of political view that exist within the Senate. I think it is fair to say that all members of the Senate Standing Orders Committee who were at the meeting heard Senator Missen address the meeting. He was given complete liberty to say anything he might wish to say in support of the claim by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. After he had spoken he was asked a number of questions. After he left the meeting the Committee considered the matter and all members of the Committee, I think without any demur, agreed to the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, there was expressed at the meeting the highest respect and laudation of the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Indeed, I think everyone knows that Senator Missen and Senator Tate were sent by the former President of the Senate- it was subsequently supported by me-to Canada last year to the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation to talk about the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. That is what the Senate thinks of the work of that Committee. At a meeting of the Commonwealth Presiding Officers in Wellington last January I spoke highly of the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and suggested to those Presiding Officers that they should recommmend to their parliaments that they introduce a form of scrutiny of legislation, as we have in the Senate. I mention that to indicate to all who have spoken in support of Senator Missen's proposition that, as far as the meeting of the Standing Orders Committee was concerned, there was no hostility towards the work that the Committee carried out.

The case of the Standing Orders Committee briefly is set out in paragraph (7). The history of the Committee indicates that it was intended to operate, and has in fact operated, in a manner similar to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which works by deliberating in private upon the legislation which stands referred to it by corresponding with responsible Ministers and by reporting to the Senate. This method of operation has been instrumental in ensuring the success and acceptance of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee during the 50 years of its existence and of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee during the brief period of its existence.

If one then turns to page 2808 of today's Notice Paper, one will see that there is a difference between the titles of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and the legislative and general purpose standing committees. The two committees to which I refer, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, are specifically referred to as legislative scrutiny standing committees. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is world acclaimed for the excellent work that it has carried out during its 50 years of existence. Never once has it had to have a public meeting; never once has it had to have a daily record taken of its proceedings; never once has it asked that its deliberations be televised, or anything of that nature. All of its deliberations have been conducted privately. It has become the watchdog in this Parliament of the rights of individual members of the Australian community.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in the short time that it has been in existence, has joined in the excellent work of the Regulations and Ordinance Committee. We have genuinely believed that those two committees should continue to operate in that fashion and, as Senator Button has said, the Standing Orders Committee says that, should it appear in the future that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee requires any or all of the provisions in question, it may be appropriate for the Senate to consider the matter again. I firmly support the recommendations of the Standing Orders Committee because I believe that it is in the interests of the Senate that that attitude be adopted by this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to the comments made in the debate-it is one of the most serious occasions I have known in the Parliament-to try to repair the situation before it goes too far. I believe that the vote on this matter is a vital one. I am sorry that so many back bench members of the Parliament are not present, have not taken part in the debate and do not appreciate what is going on. I want to deal first with some of the individual contributions in the debate.
—Not harshly, I hope.

—I regard this matter very seriously. I regard it as a matter of life and death for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I will fight to the end to see that this Committee does continue and does not go down the track which I fear it may well go down if it is slapped in the face by the removal-and that is what it is-of the powers it has had for some period. Of course the Committee has been praised overseas. Senator Tate's excellent paper on the Committee was warmly received at the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation. As the President had indicated, many other countries may choose to follow the same path. It is now reported that, unfortunately, the Committee's powers will be reduced to the archaic terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which we all had to suffer on that Committee. I was Chairman and a member of that Committee for a number of years. We will find that we are going backwards with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, instead of bringing forward the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button tried to suggest that there were two things to which I did not give attention. The first was that if the powers were found to be inadequate it would be appropriate to consider the matter here again. How often have I head that statement in reports tabled in this Parliament and how little consolation it is. I did not take that statement as being very important. Of course we can come back. But we know that if we lose this battle now we have probably lost it for good. The second thing that the honourable senator raised was paragraph (7) of the report, to draw the distinction between the regulations and ordinances type of committee and the legislative and general purpose standing committees. The President and others have tried to say there is some distinction between them. The secret, of course, lies in the next thing that the honourable senator said. We want to have, and continue to have, the power to have senators come to the Committee and ask questions, and to make it more public or a showpiece-that was what Senator Button said the Committee would become if it had these powers. Senator Robert Ray, who had the honesty to say that he had not taken much interest in the Committee, said that it would become a circus-type committee. Of course, there is not the slightest evidence to back up any of those assertions that it has, or will become, anything of the sort. It will always be subject to the control of the Senate, anyway, if it shows any predilection to move in that direction.

Senator Button said that the Committee might become more public. What horror! How terrible! Is it not the trouble with this-it is the trouble, too, with the regulatory process in this country-that it is not more public? The whole system is poor because we do not publicise regulations before the event, because we do not give the public an opportunity to appear before these committees and the public do not know about them.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express the bitter disappointment not only of myself but also of the people of a large proportion of Tasmania over the most recent action of the Federal Government in withdrawing the somewhat farcial offer to do some work to Wynyard Airport. I think it needs to be put in the context that the Federal Government since taking office has not only stopped the west coast hydro-electric power development that was under way but also has cancelled the redevelopment of Wynyard Airport which had commenced, eliminated various water schemes that had been approved and has subsequently rejected other airport development as well. In spite of all those things on the debit side, not one thing has been given in place. The west and north west corner of Tasmania services businesses such as four of the seven major dairy factories in Tasmania, two of the six major abattoirs, one of the four vegetable processing plants, all of the major mines producing tin, copper, zinc, lead or iron ore, the major timber mills of the State, the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd Burnie plant, dioxide, the pelletising plant at Port Latta and over a quarter of the population of the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Wynyard Airport is not a Johnny-come-lately or anything else. Wynyard, of course, was one of the places on Bert Hinkler's trip around Australia in 1929. It had its first air pageant in 1932. That was very largely due to, and I give credit to, the late Owen Waterworth who was the main instigator of that airport, realising that Wynyard was of geographical importance in servicing King Island and that it was within distance of Melbourne. As from 1936 W. M. Holyman and Sons Pty Ltd was running regular air services in and out of Wynyard. The figures in favour of the case which have been so totally ignored make the Government's decision an absolute nonsense. On looking at the figures for other airports around Australia I find that Wynyard Airport, now being denied upgrading, handles regularly at least 60 per cent more passengers per year than many of the upgraded airports.

Tasmania generally is a very good example of practical decentralisation. The strength of Tasmania, which is largely the envy of other States, is that it has this decentralisation. I find it quite extraordinary that postponement has even been suggested, let alone carried out on the basis of what is loosely referred to as alleged cost. If the upgrading is a matter of cost what is the cost of not doing the upgrading? Non-development is another matter. What would happen with non-development? Would it increase the cost of all those major industries and the 60,000 people involved? Of course it would. Would it tend to cause industry and business to relocate now or in the future. Again, the answer is yes. Would it destabilise land and rental values in the far north west coast? Of course it would. Would it affect the traditional sociological balance? Of course it would. Would it cause much higher costs in perpetuity? The answer again is yes. How do those costs compare with the once-up cost of upgrading the Airport? The cost of upgrading would be minimal compared with the continuing costs. Anybody with half a mind can see that. The decisions that seem to have been taken and some of the ridiculous comments that I have seen in the Press and heard people make are invariably made by people who do not live there and who could not possibly know the position of the area anyway. I do not think there would be anything wrong in those who are responsible for making these sorts of decisions at least taking some notice of the people who live there. If they did I think they would find the decision fairly clear and the reasons very plausible.

Wynyard basically is a business airport. It is not very heavy on tourists but it is on business. I believe that that in itself makes the airport very important indeed. None of the major hire car firms even run Wynard as a major depot for tourists any longer. However, business people still use it very heavily. Where else in the world would any government be trying to encourage centralisation. Where are governments not trying to see that people are spread a little more evenly to avoid the large buildup such as we so often see strangling isolated countries. Australia, in particular, is the best example we can find of this. This whole area of Tasmania needs a little encouragement now. I ask honourable senators to remember that it is highly productive in mining and farming, producing vegetables, meats and dairy produce. Right now there is a real problem internationally with minerals. Prices are down, tin quotas apply, money is short and unions in the area are jumpy. None of this is the responsibility of the particular area. It has been caused by external forces. The whole area needs stability and encouragement to see it overcome the current problems.

I promise that there is also no boom in the farming area. I ask those who make the decisions whether they have any idea of what the entry into the Closer Economic Relations agreement with New Zealand has done to destabilise the area. Do honourable senators know what the weather has done in the last two or three years? It is drier in that part of Australia than it has been over the last two years which, as anyone would know, has been dry. Do honourable senators know what the increase in shipping costs has done to many of the industries of the area? Maybe honourable senators do not know. I do not really expect that everybody should follow what happens in that area. However, I assure honourable senators that those who live and work in the area and who are trying to maintain their productivity certainly know.

As a result of the indecision over the airport several businesses have withheld expansion and development plans. There have been withdrawals, amalgamations and rationalisation while the airport business is still being fiddled about. I understand why some of those businesses have taken these steps right now. It is most unfortunate that as a result of this ridiculous short term decision long term commercial commitments are being made. I cannot understand how the Government could possibly have accepted advice which by any standards is so patently wrong. It is absolutely ridiculous on a whole range of bases, as I have demonstrated. In fact I cannot find one basis to support the pettiness and silliness that has resulted in this decision. Naturally the efforts to right this nonsense will continue. Naturally the present Government representatives for Tasmania will be invited to be identified with their State colleagues in the program to try to put it right. I assure honourable senators that the people of the area will be pleased to continue to press for the right and proper action to be taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate. What we just heard was a parochial speech by Senator Archer in support of his views on Wynyard Airport. I think I should point out some of the more ridiculous arguments that he used. One of the last arguments that he used was that this was an example of the Government indulging in centralisation. It should be on the Senate record that we have an airport in Hobart, an airport in Launceston and an airport in Devonport which is being upgraded to jet standard because of the farsightedness of the Devonport people. A few kilometres away we have an airport in Wynyard. This is no more an example of centralisation than any of the arguments that Senator Archer used.

SPEECH.PARA: He pointed out quite correctly that on the north-west coast, particularly the far north-west coast-I suppose I fly in there with a frequency second only to Senator Archer-we have dairy factories, we have timber mills, we have dioxide, we have mining, we have vegetable processing and we have vegetable growing. Senator Archer seemed to be suggesting that because Wynyard Airport was not going to be upgraded those industries would be relocated, that people would pick up their dairy farms and take them away and that people would take their mines away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be damned ridiculous.
—That is what the honourable senator said when he made his speech .
—You heard what I said.

—I heard what the honourable senator said. He said that as a result of he airport not going ahead there had been withdrawals, amalgamations and rationalisations. He gave us not one example. The problem is that in situations like this when industries are not doing well, of course they will blame something like this. The honourable senator did not give one example and he should.
—I will give you an example.

—If the honourable senator wants an example of why the upgrading of Wynyard Airport has not proceeded, I will give him one. In 1983 there were 70 ,655 scheduled airline passengers and in 1973, 10 years before, there were 82, 137. People who are using airports on the north-west coast are marching with their feet. In those 10 years there has been a reduction in the number of people who use that airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer knows what the real problem is. The previous Government introduced the local ownership of airports program. I do not argue about it; I think there is a place for it and there is also not a place for it. The people in Devonport realised what was going on. They got themselves organised, got their airport upgraded and did the right thing. The people at Wynyard did not because Mr Groom, the honourable member for Braddon, and Senator Archer told them not to do it; to keep right out of it. If people talk to the locals they will tell them that they were misled by their two local members. They were left out of it. If they had gone into the matter earlier it might have been a different situation. Wynyard Airport may have been upgraded and Devonport may not have been upgraded.

Let us not wring our hands in this place and tear out our hair and say: 'This terrible Government is not upgrading Wynyard Airport when it should be doing so and when Wynyard Airport could have been upgraded'. This could have happened if Wynyard's local members had not got to the local people-do not deny it-and said 'Do not have a bar of our Government's proposals', that is, the former Government's proposals. The Devonport people said: 'We will be left in the lurch if we do not'. They went ahead, they were progressive. What has happened? Their airport has been upgraded and Wynyard Airport has not.

Wynyard Airport will eventually be upgraded. Of course it will be upgraded, but it will be upgraded in the normal pattern under the normal set of priorities that should be used in this area. To blame all the ills that may exist on the north-west coast on the fact that Wynyard Airport has not been upgraded to Senator Archer's satisfaction now-he was not so interested in it a few years ago -is nonsense. I will refer the details of the matter to the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley). I am sure that the Minister will give the honourable senator an appropriate answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to speak on a matter on which I have been misrepresented. If the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) can produce one line in which I have stated, or one person has ever heard me say , that Wynyard Airport should not be upgraded I will give him $1,000.
—I did not say that.

—You did. I do not wish to debate this question. The Minister said that the local representative and I had urged people not to participate in the local ownership plan. I will give the Minister or anyone else that he would rather I give the money to at least $1,000 if he can produce one line or one person to substantiate that I ever said anything other than that Wynyard should adopt local ownership. When the Minister has checked that out with whoever he likes, I will be pleased to accept his apology. I do not wish to have this sort of scurrilous remark passed about me or the cause I am here to sponsor. I will be happy to give him a list of the witnesses-
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw the word ' scurrilous'.

—I withdraw the word 'scurrilous'. I do not know what to replace it with but, Mr President, you know what I mean. I still object to this type of totally incorrect, wilfully wantonly and deliberately untrue statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.47 p.m.
